TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life to all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 658 citizens) and McLean (from 486 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon the Senate to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a refusal of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and a denial of information to print-handicapped Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Calvert (from 62 citizens) and Vanstone (from 169 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: AIDS Commercial
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners request that the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health cause to cease immediately the broadcasting of any AIDS commercials which have as their premise that the use of condoms makes casual sexual activities acceptable particularly amongst young adolescents because of the detrimental effect which such campaigns have upon the morals of our society.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Office: Mandurah, Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled.

The petition of residents of Mandurah in the State of Western Australia draws to the attention of the Senate, that we the undersigned request a Medicare Office be situated in Mandurah this financial year, to cater for the needs of the residents, particularly the many Senior Citizens.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Members of the Senate will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

2. The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
3. These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitions request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Immigration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that;
The following distinct areas of sponsorship be also considered under the family re-union preferential category, viz:-
(1) Adult children whether married or single when sponsored by parents who are Australian citizens;
(2) The last remaining member of the sponsor's family, whether married or single;
(3) Immediate family members, when the sponsor has come on a Certificate of Identity, thus demonstrating their total commitment to Australia, having forfeited the right to return to Burma.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

Dear Senator Giles

I refer to your letters of 11 March and 11 April 1991 concerning your Committee's various concerns and inquiries following its consideration of the amendments to the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations contained in Statutory Rules No 460 of 1990, which were Gazetted on 21 December 1990.

These Statutory Rules implement new controls over the importation of firearms, and give effect to the resolution of the Australian Police Ministers' Council concerning firearms control, which was settled jointly by the Commonwealth and State and Territory Governments at the 19th Meeting of the Council in Alice Springs on 22 November last year.

In your Committee's two letters, concerns have been expressed about an apparent unlimited and unreviewable discretion vested in Commissioners of Police to exempt one category of firearms (ie handguns) from the import prohibition (your 11 March letter refers), and about a possible retrospective effect of the amendments (your 11 April letter refers).

I am also aware that these two issues were the subject of your 14 March 1991 Notice of Motion on behalf of the Committee for the disallowance of these Statutory Rules, which must be called on or withdrawn on or before 28 May 1991. I trust the following will address your Committee's concerns, so that the Notice of Motion can in fact be withdrawn.
(i) The unlimited discretion vested in Commissioners of Police to exempt handguns from the import prohibition

The firearms control regime which Statutory Rules No. 460 of 1990 has introduced is essentially an absolute import prohibition of all ``firearms'' (defined broadly in sub-regulation 2(1) to include all but a very limited number of special purpose guns), unless the firearms are ``exempt firearms'' (item 24 of Schedule 1 refers).

The three ``exempt firearm'' categories defined in sub-regulation 2(1) give legislative effect to the policy desire of the Australian Police Ministers' Council that the new firearms controls specify the categories of ``permitted imports'' to this country. Such permitted imports of firearms must satisfy the definitional requirements pertaining to that particular category of firearms, and all such firearms must satisfy safety requirements, as prescribed in Part 2 of Schedule 3 to the Regulations, unless the firearms come within one of the limited classes of exemptions to the safety testing requirement (item 5 of Part 1 of Schedule 3 refers).

With regard to the three defined categories of ``exempt firearm'', your letter of 11 March drew attention to the second category, paragraph 2(1) (b) of the definition of ``exempt firearm'', relating to handguns.

That paragraph purports to exempt handguns from the absolute import prohibition on firearms where either the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police or a Commissioner of a State or Territory police force has certified that the relevant police force has no objection to the handgun's importation.

Your Committee was rightly critical of the apparent lack of independent review of this discretion. That criticism was repeated in your 14 March Notice of Motion, together with a further concern that the discretions were vested in persons not all of whom are Commonwealth officials, which could render independent review unenforceable on jurisdictional grounds

The Committee's comments in this regard are well made, and its concerns well taken. In fact, the purpose of the certification by a Police Force Commissioner was intended to do no more than evidence the fact of whether or not the intending importer is licensed or authorised to possess the handgun in the jurisdiction into which the handgun is to be brought. That evidentiary requirement existed for handguns prior to the new control regime (the B709 Weapons Import-Police Endorsement), and was meant to continue under the new regime.

I concede however that as presently drafted the paragraph is not so restricted; indeed the objection which a Police Commissioner might take is apparently open-ended. I consider this issue can be satisfactorily resolved by an amendment to the Regulations to make the pre-condition for ``permissible'' imported handguns rely not on a Police Commissioner's discretion, but rather, on the fact of whether or not the importer is licensed or authorised to possess the handgun. A certificate from the relevant police force to that effect would involve no administrative discretion, and therefore should allay the Committee's legitimate concerns on this point

I undertake also to make that amendment retrospective to the 21 December 1990 commencement of the Principal Regulations the subject of your Committee's concerns, although the administration of this paragraph has proceeded on the basis of whether the importer in fact has a relevant licence or authority to possess the handgun, and not on the basis of any discretion. I have instructed officers of the Australian Customs Service to process the above change in the next available Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations amendment.
(ii) Possible retrospective effect of the amendments

In both your Notice of Motion in the Senate, and your second letter of 11 April 1991, you have raised on behalf of the Committee concerns about a possible retrospective effect of the new firearms prohibition, especially with regard to firearms imported prior to 21 December 1990. Your Committee has sought advice as to whether firearms lawfully imported prior to 21 December 1990 can be made subject to seizure action or pecuniary penalty for unlawful possession on the ground that such firearms now might be prohibited imports (ie since 21 December 1990).

With regard to seizure action under Commonwealth legislation, I am advised the relevant provisions for your Committee's information are sub-section 203(2) and paragraph 229(1)b of the Customs Act 1901; the first provision provides the general right to seize any forfeited goods, or any goods that an officer of Customs, police or the Defence forces believes on reasonable grounds are forfeited goods, and the second provision ``defines'' prohibited imports as one of the categories of forfeited goods.

The Customs Act 1901 provides an express head of power in Section 50 to enable the prohibition of the importation of goods into Australia to be done by Regulation. As a consequence of this being effected by subsidiary legislation, any such prohibitions are expressly prohibited from operating retrospectively by sub-section 48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

In the instant case, as Statutory Rules No. 460 of 1990 introduced a new regime prohibiting the importation into Australia of certain firearms, I am advised it is expressly caught by the prohibition against retrospectivity in sub-section 48(2); the new firearm control regime can therefore only attach prohibited imports status to firearms imported on or after 21 December 1990. The corollary to the above is that the seizure power referred to earlier can only lawfully be exercised under the new regime over firearms imported since that date, where such firearms come within the terms of the new regulation. In short, the Regulations cannot retrospectively make firearms imported prior to 21 December 1990 prohibited imports, and as such there is no Customs Act power of seizure over such goods on that ground.

With regard to penalty action for the unlawful possession of prohibited imports under Commonwealth legislation, I am advised the relevant provisions for your Committee's information are paragraph 233(1) (d) and Section 233 AB of the Customs Act 1901; the first provision provides the offence for the unlawful possession of prohibited imports, and the second prescribes the pecuniary penalty applicable to that offence.

Your Committee in the second paragraph of your 11 April 1991 letter has quite correctly assumed that articles which were previously lawful to possess and which may have been in a person's possession for many years, cannot be effectively made unlawful to possess by Regulations. The event of importing goods which are not ``prohibited imports'' at that time brings with it the right to possess those goods. It is giving the Act and Regulations quite inappropriate retrospective operation to treat the legislation as intending to alter that right by changing the position of the law in relation to that event at a subsequent point of time.

For the information of the Committee, I have attached a copy of an opinion from the Chief General Counsel of the Attorney-General's Department on this very point, which was provided to the Shadow Attorney-General, the Hon Andrew Peacock MP, following his similar question on this Regulation.
Counsel's advice both on the question of whether
(a) paragraph 233(1) (d) applied to the possession in Australia of goods that had never been imported,
and whether

(b) the paragraph applied to the possession in Australia of imported goods that are ``prohibited imports'' at the time of the possession but were not ``prohibited imports'' at the time of importation,
was an emphatic No.

As a final matter, your Committee has raised in the final paragraph of your 11 April letter the question of whether the new import prohibition applies to goods which were in transit on or after 21 December 1990, or awaiting Customs clearance on or after 21 December 1990.

I am advised these two scenarios are no different to those which apply every time a prohibited imports or exports control is introduced or amended. In the first scenario, in transit goods are subject to any new control, for the simple fact that such goods have not yet been imported into Australia. It would be a curious result indeed if having determined goods to be undesirable in this country, we were obliged to let into the country a quantity of such goods, simply because their journey to this country had commenced.

In the second scenario, (ie the goods awaiting customs clearance) the opposite result applies, this time because the act of importation has been completed, and therefore, because at the time of importation the importation of the goods was not prohibited, nothing subsequent to that fact can be done by Regulation to alter that result.
I trust the above addresses the concerns of the Committee.
Yours sincerely
DAVID BEDDALL

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Regulations 13 to 20 inclusive of the Austudy Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1990 No. 443 and made under the Student Assistance Act 1973, be disallowed.

I must stress at the beginning that this is an urgent matter. We cannot delay yet another year and wait for the 1992 regulations before dealing with this issue. As the rural crisis deepens, those students who have moved into upper secondary education, and particularly those students who have moved into tertiary education from rural Australia, are going to be asking, `Can we continue? ', `What is our future?'.

Time is of the essence. We do need to remove the assets test. The greatest benefit from removing the assets test will be to farming families and we must act now. If we wait until 1992 to act then another year level of students will be uncertain of their future and, indeed, many of them will miss out on an education. Those now in year 10 in most States will be looking towards work experience. What particular job will they be looking towards? Can they set their sights high or, indeed, will they be looking at not continuing at all? Those in year 11 are looking to setting courses for year 12. Those who are now attempting to complete year 12, with the already enormous pressure the rural crisis is placing on them, have to consider whether it is really worth it because they may not be able to continue on to tertiary study.

Those who have risked it now and are in tertiary institutions are finding that they are not able to get part time jobs in the cities. They rely more and more on their families, and those families are facing greater and greater hardship. We simply cannot watch as many of our most talented students from country areas-and it is really irrelevant how talented they are-simply miss out. We cannot stand by and witness what is a loss to all Australians as this group of very talented young people are forced to discontinue their education.

There are also many additional costs that face farming families. This move has generated some criticisms and I agree with those people who say that this move is not the only answer. If those concerned are unable to at least get Austudy, it is certain that the vast majority of them will not be able to go on. There have been a number of reports of late that have dealt at length with this problem, and I shall be looking at only two of them today. The first is the March 1991 report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training into student financial assistance. The finding in paragraph 3.10 is:

Rural Australians have lower participation rates in education and training than their metropolitan counterparts. Sheer distance, low population densities and widely disparate populations make it difficult for many people outside capital cities or major urban centres to gain access to education and training. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy stated that Austudy has a vital role in facilitating the participation of rural students by easing the financial strain associated with study.
The report continues in paragraph 3.11:

The Department of Primary Industries and Energy stated that the assets test has been a constant source of frustration for agricultural producers. Agricultural industries in 1989/90 were estimated to have had a rate of return, excluding capital appreciation, of 2.5 per cent. This means that in spite of having significant assets holdings many farmers have low incomes. Farmers have little or no control over the prices they receive for their produce. The Department advised that for 1990/91 the net value of production will fall between 60 and 65 per cent. This is mainly due to falls in commodity prices which are determined by overseas markets. The Department concluded that fluctuations in world markets are likely to continue while the international trading environment remains distorted.
Then paragraph 3.12 reads:

A report on rural Austudy concluded that the claim that the introduction of the assets test could be justified for reasons of equity requires more careful investigation from the point of view of people living in rural areas, particularly farmers. The report commented that there was cause for concern when farmers and owners of small businesses in rural areas were entitled to Austudy payments for their children on the basis of income tests but did not receive them because their assets were reported to be over the limit.
The last quotation from the report is from paragraph 3.15 which looks at the contribution of the National Farmers Federation to this inquiry:

The Federation stated that the assets of a farm and many other small businesses are not readily divisible or saleable as a means of providing living expenses. Sale of part of a farm may render the remainder too small to be viable. In a recessionary environment business assets, especially in agriculture, may not be readily saleable at any realistic price. Seventy-five per cent of farms have net assets exceeding $400,000.
The report also points out that about 50 per cent of farms have net assets in excess of $700,000-in other words, out of the Austudy requirement-and the average net asset is $910,000.

The second report to which I wish to draw attention is a project carried out in Victoria entitled Austudy-Rural Inequities. It was a joint project of the Country Education Project at the Office of Rural Affairs and the Victorian Country Youth Affairs Network. I quote from page 47 of that report:

If the assets limit is exceeded then students receive no Austudy allowance. There is no provision for partial allowances as with the income test. In addition there are no hardship provisions or concessions where the assets limit is exceeded.

Cases of particular concern are those where farmers or owners of small businesses have assets worth more than $645,500 but have low annual incomes, that in the absence of the assets test would entitle their children to receive Austudy.
The introduction of the assets test in 1989 is perceived by farmers particularly to be inequitable. One parent expressed her frustration with the assets test as follows:
I am concerned about the assumption that is made that landholders are wealthy-you can't eat dirt and buildings.
That was said by a parent from the Wimmera. Examples such as this were encountered many times among farming families interviewed during the data collection phase of this project.

A rural counsellor working in north-western Victoria provided several instances of families who were entitled to Austudy on the basis of their incomes, but received no entitlements due to the assets test. Three examples of farming income are included in this report, which show incomes on a three-year average as low as $6,000 and $7,000. The report goes on to say:
Students in this study commented:
``Farmers' have assets but they are tied up in land and stock. (AUSTUDY) doesn't take into account that farms need a lot of assets just to function normally.''

``As it may seem that the parents received a very high income much of those funds may have to be directed elsewhere such as supplies, fertilizers, seeds, etc. Or they may have to pay large sums for natural disasters and disease etc.''
I must add that this report was written in particularly good times-times that are rapidly deteriorating.

Farm incomes are now indeed minimal if not negative. I have just spent some time travelling through rural South Australia. In particular, I spent several days on Kangaroo Island. On the island more than 90 per cent of farmers are almost totally reliant on wool. Incomes for this year are expected to be as low as one third of last year, and severe financial difficulties are being experienced by the majority of farmers on the island. Stock agents often have first call on any income, the banks are closing off cheque accounts and local stores have stopped credit facilities.

I spent some time talking to the rural counsellor. He told me of more and more cases coming before him where extreme hardship is being experienced. His comment was that many people are really leaving it too late to get in touch with him. He had arrived on one farm to find that the owners had absolutely no food in the cupboards. Fortunately, the Minister's fraternal on the island now has a small fund where the council can draw up to $100 for emergencies such as this.

Families are finding that they cannot pay fuel bills. This not only inhibits work on the farm-indeed, some of them are going back to working their properties on horseback-it also means that farming families cannot get into town. They are cut off from social contact and, as one of the ministers pointed out, they can no longer go to church. Businesses in Kingscote, Penneshaw and Parndana are in financial trouble as farmers cannot pay accounts. The assets test is particularly crucial to farmers on the island because it not only excludes them from Austudy but also excludes families from any support under the family allowance supplement or unemployment benefits.

Students now in years 10 and 11 will be asking themselves a number of questions. Where should they be looking for their future? Should they be looking to go on to agricultural college and then move back onto the farm? Unfortunately, more and more of them are finding that there is no place for them on the farm. The option of staying on the farm is no longer viable, certainly not for more than one child in the family. Often the family can simply not afford to keep all its young people at home. However, if these regulations stay in place and young people move off the farm and go to Adelaide and then seek Austudy, they still do not qualify because the value of the farm stays with them until they are 25. So one way or another they will not be able to get an education.

There have been some suggestions that we need another review to again look at the problems and to start talking about providing hardship provisions. These are long term suggestions. I argue that they will not be nearly as effective as removing the assets test now. We cannot wait until 1992 to try something else and to look at this problem again.

Unfortunately, what is needed now is the removal of the entire assets test. But that is simply the legal requirement. We in the Senate cannot amend; we must either allow or disallow. Therefore, we are asking that the Government rewrite these specific regulations in a form that provides that specifically farming families, and also small business families-although there will not be nearly as many of those affected-are excluded from the assets test for Austudy. It is very easy to do. Indeed, we would be more than happy to volunteer to assist with the rewriting of those specific regulations. But we have no choice at this point, other than to disallow them, to exclude tools of trade from the assets test.

There is one other problem relating to the assets test, and this is the problem of revaluation. At the time a family actually fills out the application forms for Austudy nowhere does it say that the valuation must be done by the Australian Valuation Office (AVO). Family after family has got in touch with us in Adelaide and shown that, despite the fact that they had put down their best possible estimate of the market value of their properties-and they had relied upon reputable organisations, such as Elders, to come in to do a valuation for them or they had looked at their State valuation or council rates; in short, they had done the best they possibly could-over and over again, in fact in the case of about one-third of the revaluations which were done in South Australia, farming families, despite having qualified previously, had been cut off. Not only had they been cut off, but also they had been asked to repay up to $16,000.

These AVO checks have apparently been done-some information was provided by Senator Bolkus's office yesterday-on 618 families. The assets of 208 families-that is over one-third-have been valued at just above the limit and the families have, therefore, been cut off from Austudy. In many cases, people have been asked to repay money.

Despite the fact that land values are falling rapidly, the AVO is not taking this into account-or it certainly was not throughout last year. I will give some specific examples from South Australia where the majority of the revaluations took place. For example, in the mid-north of South Australia a family with two children, on the advice of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, valued its farm assets as per the local council rate notice-that is, less than the replacement insurance value of the house plus curtilage. However, the Valuation Office revalued the property as being over the limit and all payments were asked to be repaid within 14 days. The Commonwealth valuation was 22 per cent higher than the State valuation and the value of the home was deemed to be less than 50 per cent of its insurance value.

In another case near Kimba in South Australia, a family had its land valued by Elders at $68 per acre. It was revalued at up to $120 per acre, despite the fact that forced sales in the area at the time were getting no bids, no offers, and the latest sales had realised only $25 to $40 per acre. Their children have no choice; they have to go away to complete schooling after year 10 as the local school only goes to year 10. Therefore, these children will be precluded from upper secondary, let alone tertiary, study.

There were also other problems with this valuation. In this case wool on the sheep's back was valued whereas it should have been only a carcass valuation. In other words, 18 months worth of wool was included in the valuation. An extremely small value was put on the family house. For those people who are wondering about the importance of this, that amount is actually taken off the total value of the farm. So by valuing up the stock and valuing down the house, one can see that the gap widens and widens. I know of several cases in South Australia where the valuations have been up to 79 per cent above the State Valuer-General's valuations.

Despite the fact that land values are falling rapidly, many farming families will not risk applying for Austudy. In fact, farmers have said precisely that to me. They will not risk it because they are near the $700,000 limit and they are worried that they could be faced with a revaluation at any point in time.

Again, this points to the fact that we cannot wait. The situation in rural Australia, as I have heard many honourable senators outline in this place, is serious. We cannot leave young people literally on the scrap heap for another year. It is a matter of justice. Why should young people-I stress again that this is young people up to the age of 25 years-be prevented from continuing their education purely because of the value of their family farm? This group of young people includes many whose families will be forced off the land.
I will quote from an article which appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser on Tuesday of this week. Mr Blevins, a Minister in the State Labor Government, said:
. . . two-thirds of South Australian steel workers had been forced to leave their industry and the State's farmers had to be prepared to do the same.
Two-thirds is the suggestion coming from a Minister in the South Australian Government. Whatever the figure, some people will certainly be affected-but let us hope it is nowhere near that number.

These are the very people who need an education most urgently. It is essential that they get a chance to study now and that they are not forced into the cities and into poverty. If compassion is not enough then hopefully economic argument will be. We need to look at the overall cost to this country of losing these talents and of then having to support these young people for what may be a considerable period of time. In the long run, we will all be the losers.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee is considering the Schedule and the amendments moved by Senator Cook. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Schedule, page 8, Part 3, proposed amendments of the Industrial Relations Act 1988, after the amendment to paragraph 18(2)(c), insert the following item:
``After section 19:
Insert:
Discharge of Commission's business
`19A. The President is to be assisted by the Vice President in ensuring the orderly and quick discharge of the business of the Commission.'.''.
2. Schedule, page 8, Part 3, proposed amendments of the Industrial Relations Act 1988, amendment to subsection 30(2), omit the amendment.
3. Schedule, page 9, Part 3, proposed amendments of the Industrial Relations Act 1988, amendment to section 40, omit the amendment, substitute the following item:
``Repeal the section, substitute:
Delegation by President
`40.(1) The President may, by signed instrument, delegate to the Vice President all or any of the President's powers under this Act.

`(2) If the President delegates a power to the Vice President under subsection (1), he or she may, in addition, delegate that power to a Senior Deputy President to be exercised when the Vice President is unable, for any reason, to exercise that power personally.'.''.

Essentially, we are moving two amendments but there is a consequential amendment, so there are three amendments before the Committee. Our amendments are directed at two elements of the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment (No. 2) Bill. Honourable senators will be aware that the new model of industrial relations was put in place by the enactment of the Industrial Relations Act in 1988. Substantial amendments were made to that Act in 1990, and in many respects we are now putting the finishing touches to that model. Much of what is before the Committee today is designed to strengthen the structure of the Industrial Relations Commission, which we have always argued is the cornerstone of the centralised model.

Indeed, when we had an urgency motion before the Senate two days ago, in some respects it was gratifying and yet a little confusing to hear Senator Durack saying on behalf of the Opposition that the Opposition also believes in a strong and independent Industrial Relations Commission. Yet we will find that when the Opposition is put to the test, probably in a few minutes from now, it will not support amendments which are designed to strengthen both the role and the independence of the Industrial Relations Commission. I viewed a debate on a Special Broadcasting Service television program last night. The shadow Minister for industrial relations, employment and training, Mr Howard, quite clearly reinforced yet again the position of the Opposition, which is essentially to emasculate the Industrial Relations Commission.

The Bill which is now before the chamber puts in place the recommendations of the Gleeson Committee. The Democrats have reservations about two of those recommendations, and that has become the basis of these amendments. The Bill implements the Gleeson Committee's recommendation that there be a new position of Vice-President. Certainly, we endorse that. In its report the Gleeson Committee stated:

. . . the establishment of the position of Vice President, with the functions and responsibilities proposed, continues to be appropriate, particularly for the reasons articulated in the Hancock report. [The Committee] believes-
that is, the Gleeson Committee-
. . . that the personal load on the President is undesirable and that a formalised structure ancillary to his power of delegation is highly desirable.

The Gleeson Committee made particular reference to the 1985 report of the Hancock Committee of Review of Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. The report of the Hancock Committee recommended the creation of the office of a Vice-President in the then proposed Australian Industrial Relations Commission. That Committee noted the growth in the size of the tribunal over the years and the increased scope and complexity of its work, with a concomitant increase in the President's workload. On page 400, paragraph 8.51 of the Hancock Committee report, it is recommended that the legislation designate as special functions of the Vice-President the provision of administrative support for the President, as well as certain other functions.

The Bill, apparently in the interests of managerial flexibility, does not specify the relationship between the President and the Vice-President, and our amendment seeks to elaborate on that relationship. The Minister addressed this matter in his second reading speech, observing that the Vice-President would assist the President, including in relation to the more important matters in the Commission's operations. Even so, it would be preferable to support this role in legislation. To do so, in our opinion, would be more consonant with the objectives of the Gleeson Committee's recommendations.

As already mentioned, such an approach was also recommended by the Hancock Committee. We believe that the words of the Australian Democrat amendment are in the spirit of the recommendations of both Gleeson and Hancock. In addition, given the seniority of the position and its intended role, it is entirely appropriate that, as is done in relation to the office of President, there be a legislative statement of the Vice-President's role.

Accordingly, we are proposing amendments which will clearly recognise that the office of Vice-President is to be an important element in the effective management of the Commission's business. This will be achieved by providing expressly that the President is to be assisted by the Vice-president in ensuring the orderly and quick discharge of the business of the Commission. This is covered in an amendment inserting a new section 19a in the Industrial Relations Act 1988. That is the essence of the amendment that I am now speaking to. The new provision will not, of course, preclude the Vice-President's involvement in other aspects of the Commission's work.

Complementing this amendment, it will also be provided that the President may delegate to the Vice-President all or any of the President's powers under the Act. To address the possibility that the Vice-President is unavailable to exercise a delegated power, the President will also be able to delegate that power to a senior deputy president, who will be able to exercise the power in such circumstances. These arrangements are covered in the proposed replacement section 40 of the Industrial Relations Act.

In this way, the aims of strengthening the Commission and providing the President with high level support will be more clearly and effectively achieved. That is the essential intention of the first of the Australian Democrats' amendments, and it gives rise to the third amendment, which is consequent upon what I have just said. It is worth noting that in the last 12 months the President, Justice Maddern, was forced, due to illness and other circumstances, to be absent for six months of the last year, which tends to emphasise the importance of this new role of Vice-President. That is also a reason for this amendment of the Australian Democrats.

I now turn to the second of the amendments which have been moved simultaneously. This relates to the structure of benches. The proposed amendment to section 30 (2) gives effect to a recommendation of the Gleeson Committee that greater flexibility in the constitution of full benches in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission be permitted. Regarding the composition of full benches, the Gleeson Committee report states:

The Government proposal provided for a more flexible approach to the composition of Full Benches since its proposal no longer required two Deputy Presidents and allowed the work to be shared by Presidential Members and more experienced and skilled Commissioners. Members of the AIRC have argued that this would diminish the authority with which decisions of Full Benches are viewed and this could result in a greater incidence of challenge to decisions of the AIRC. The Committee cannot accept this point. The authority of the decision of the Full Bench stems from the fact that it is a decision incapable of further repeal. Although the Committee does not support the creation of offices of Senior Commissioner, it considers that there would be advantage in increasing the President's flexibility in constituting Full Benches. There may be merit in changing the minimum requirement for constituting a Full Bench to not less than one Presidential Member and two Commissioners. This would not, of course, prevent the President from including more than one Presidential Member when considered appropriate.
It is recommended that:
- consideration be given to providing greater flexibility in the constitution of Full Benches.
That is from the Gleeson Committee report, which is being fully endorsed in the Bill before us. The Government has chosen to endorse all recommendations of the Gleeson Committee.

Even though flexibility in the affairs of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is to be supported, in our view the proposal has some notable drawbacks. This is clear when the range of matters which a Full Bench is permitted or required to deal with is considered. All are significant and warrant a highly qualified Full Bench. I shall give some examples: national wage cases under section 106; appeals under section 45; referrals by the President of matters of industrial dispute under section 107 (2); reviews of awards, et cetera; consideration of proposed certified agreements which under the general thrust and the spirit of enterprise agreements, section 105, assume special importance; review of the operation of certified agreements, likewise under section 117, but in the spirit of the new found identification with enterprise agreements; and the cancellation of awards.

There are various other provisions where a matter may be directed to a member in the Industrial Relations Commission or to a full bench normally depending upon the seriousness of the matter, for example, orders changing an organisation's representative rights under the Act, the insertion of bans clauses in awards, the authorisation of stand downs and the ordering of secret ballots.

The Gleeson Committee correctly noted that the particular significance of a full bench derives from the fact that there is no further appeal from its decisions. This contrasts with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT), for instance, which permits the Tribunal to be constituted by a presidential member and two other members. Not only is the nature of the matter dealt with by the AAT different but also there is provision for appeal to the Federal Court of Australia.

When one considers the importance of the matters coming before full benches and the absence of further appeals, it is difficult to foresee situations where it would be appropriate to have fewer than two presidential members sitting on the bench. That is what we are attempting to acknowledge in this amendment. To provide otherwise, as in the Government's proposed amendment, invites challenges of full bench decisions by prerogative writ before the High Court of Australia. Unsuccessful parties are likely to take the view, even if unfounded, that a full bench with one presidential member on it is a second class bench. This is particularly so given that presidential members have the standing of judges.

There are other anomalies. For example, in the case of an appeal from a presidential member, it is possible to envisage a situation where a majority of two commissioners could overturn the original decision, even though the presidential member on the Full Bench agreed with it. In other words, two commissioners on the Full Bench could overturn a decision which had the support of two presidential members, namely, the original decision maker and the appellant presidential member. Accordingly, on balance, one must conclude that the desired flexibility is impractical and inconsistent with the underlying objectives of the establishing Full Benches. It is in the light of these observations of the potential inadequacies of those bench structures that the Democrats put before the Committee the second of our three amendments, in accordance with the observations I have just made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not support the Australian Democrats' amendments. As I have already indicated, we believe that this whole section of the legislation should be excised from the Bill. We sought to do that with an amendment which we moved previously but which did not receive majority support in the Committee. Therefore, given our opposition to the propositions in this part of the schedule, we can see no good reason to support the minor tinkering which the Democrats' amendment involves.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the Democrats, Senator McLean, in arguing that the coalition should support this amendment, sought to misinterpret comments that he claims Senator Durack made a couple of days ago, to the effect that the Opposition supports a strong and independent Industrial Relations Commission. That may well be the case, because even under our policy, which will offer the opportunity for employers and employees to conclude by voluntary agreement their own deals with regard to wages and conditions, those deals will nevertheless remain subject to a minimum hourly rate of wage. Therefore, it should be noted that it is not the law of the jungle that applies under our policy, which the Minister has often claimed and which he has again claimed in this debate, because a minimum hourly rate will be required in any such voluntary deal that is agreed on. That is spelt out very clearly in the coalition's industrial relations policy.

Therefore, there will be a continuing role for the Industrial Relations Commission in at least determining that minimum hourly rate, even when, as we believe, the vast majority of employers and employees opt out of the general centralised system and go to voluntary agreements and genuine enterprise bargaining.

So on that basis we certainly believe in a strong and independent Industrial Relations Commission. What Senator McLean fails to recognise is that this legislation has nothing to do with a strong and independent Industrial Relations Commission. What it is about is laying the groundwork for the future establishment of a labour court. As I have said in earlier remarks in debate on this legislation, the coalition will not have a bar of the establishment of a labour court. We will therefore not support legislation to facilitate that development.

Senator Cook said last night in debate on earlier clauses of the Bill that we ought to support this legislation on its merits and not look to some future possibility that the Government is going to introduce a labour court. Again, though, what he ignores in saying that is that, if this legislation lays the groundwork for a labour court, as it does, then it is incumbent on us to oppose it. Why would an Opposition which opposes that direction want to assist the Government in laying the groundwork and providing the preconditions for the establishment of that court, when we oppose its establishment? For that reason, I reinforce our opposition to this part of the legislation and, in particular, to the amendments moved by the Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three amendments have been moved by the Australian Democrats to change the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) as presented by the Government. Although the amendments have been described by the Opposition spokesperson for this Bill in the chamber, Senator Chapman, as being minor tinkering, they go to important functional aspects of how the Australian Industrial Relations Commission operates.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I turn to discuss the merit of the proposals and give the Government's response to the proposals that have been put, I categorise the types of views that have been put by the major parties. The Opposition is opposed to the whole section. Now that the second reading has been carried, the Opposition does not choose to do what is not unusual in events of this nature: concede that it has lost the argument that the whole section should be removed and then look at how, from its point of view, the functioning of the section can be improved. It is still a flat-footed blanket opposition.

The Australian Democrats, who have supported the Government in recognising the merit, worth and value of the findings of the Gleeson inquiry, have turned their minds to seeing whether, qualitatively, those amendments provide the best on balance consideration functionings for the Commission and whether they can be improved. The Australian Democrats have come up with two areas in which they believe the functionings can be improved.

It has to be said, from the starting point, that the Democrats have taken a constructive view and the Opposition has taken a negative view in this debate. The Opposition has justified its negativity on the basis that things may happen in the future which are not related to this legislation now. I guess that things will always happen in the future which are not related to particular issues before the Senate.

These amendments spring from a report by three eminent Australians-experts in their field and independent of government-who have fearlessly and properly discharged their charge of office and examined what is the proper and reasonable functioning of a commission and made recommendations accordingly. The Government accepts those recommendations and we seek to translate them into law. For the Opposition to besmirch or discredit these findings on the basis that `Something else is intended somewhere down the track which may or may not happen but if it does we are opposed to it' is to take a head in the sand view.

Before I turn to the amendments, I say one other thing about the Opposition's case-it is a very interesting reflection. We have just heard from Senator Chapman that my remarks about the Opposition's industrial relations policy being the law of the jungle are not true and that it would allow the Commission to determine minimum hourly rates-I think they were the words he used-and that that would be a role for the Commission. The Opposition supports, in the terms presented by it, a strong and independent commission. That is a very interesting juxtaposition.

Two or three weeks ago I participated in a debate with the official shadow spokesperson, Mr John Howard, on the 7.30 Report, under the chairmanship of Paul Lyneham. On that occasion, Mr Howard said that the Opposition, if it were elected to government, would legislate a minimum wage for Australia, which did not seem to suggest, since the Parliament would take that responsibility unto itself, a role for the Commission at all.

I am pleased to hear today that perhaps Mr Howard was wrong in what he said, that Senator Chapman is right and that the Commission will now have a role in prescribing minimum rates. If the Opposition ever gets into government, we will look forward with rapt interest to see what becomes of its industrial relations policy.

I turn to the amendments moved by the Democrats; there are two substantive ones. The first amendment is a consequential amendment to rectify other provisions in the law should the merit of the second amendment be adopted. With regard to the first amendment-the duties of a vice-president and delegations to the Vice-President by the President-the Government has taken the approach, in drafting the amendments relating to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, that there should be considerable flexibility available in the arrangement of the business of the Commission.

It is for this reason that the Government decided not to spell out in the Bill the respective roles of members of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Instead, that was to be implied from the purposes of the legislation, the relative seniority of the members and the various provisions of the Act. In addition, the President was to be left to perform the statutory duty of directing the business of the Commission.

As well as those things, I made some observations about this matter in my second reading speech which I am sure would be recognised by all of the parties in these circumstances. I recognise the interest and enthusiasm of the Democrats to provide a provision here which is more explicit than the one we have provided. Looking at the terms of their provision, I have to say that it is a more reasonable expression than the terms of some of the earlier provisions that I saw.

In those circumstances the Government accepts, for the reasons advanced by the Democrats, that there is merit in specifying the administrative responsibility of the Vice-President, particularly in light of the standing of that office in the Commission. Accordingly, the Government will accept the Democrats' proposals for doing so. The Government reiterates that, under section 36 of the Act, the ultimate responsibility for directing the business of the Commission remains with the President. For those reasons I will accept the amendments moved by Senator McLean.

I now turn to the second amendment, which concerns the composition of full benches. The Democrats' view on this has been set out very fully in the speech to the motion. In that speech there are a number of comparisons, which I think are weighty and significant, as to how the importance of a full bench ought to be viewed given, in this case, that there is no appeal from that, as that is the ultimate body of decision. On this point the Gleeson inquiry talked about greater flexibility for the Commission. In effect, the Democrats' amendment would return the position to the status quo. In weighing the findings of the Gleeson inquiry, one could say that, reasonably, the inquirers would not be offended by the observations made by the Democrats and in fact could see the merit of the Democrats' view. The Government certainly sees the merit of it.

It should be noted that the Gleeson committee recommended that consideration be given to providing greater flexibility to the constitution of full benches. The committee pointed out that the authority of a decision of a full bench stems from the fact that under the Act it is incapable of further appeal. This point was made by Senator McLean. Moreover, the Government's proposal would have left it to the President to determine how a full bench should be constituted. Nevertheless, in view of the argument put, we accept the amendment and on that basis would be prepared to vote for it and thus amend our Bill accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot let the comments of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) pass without correcting him with regard to the application of a minimum hourly rate by a future coalition government. The fact that a future coalition government may choose to legislate for a minimum hourly rate does not in any way preclude the option of using the Industrial Relations Commission to establish the appropriate level for that rate. That distinction should clearly be made. So there is no contradiction between the continued use of judgments of the Industrial Relations Commission and the fact that we may legislate for a minimum hourly rate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Chapman for that observation. Certainly, what Mr Howard said was before the national wage case. It may be that the Opposition has a different view of the Industrial Relations Commission since the national wage case decision.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on the first reading of this Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91 to protest as loudly as appropriate in this chamber about the actions of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) calling on the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to review the guidelines for the conduct of ambassadors. It seems that this is being done because one ambassador has brought great disgrace on the ambassadors and high commissioners who represent this country in other places. The Government seems to be trying to cover up for Mr Burke's behaviour by bringing this to the notice of the people of Australia and putting all ambassadors under the spotlight. I regard it as absolutely outrageous that it should seek to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I am thinking in particular of some of the former members of this Parliament who have represented this country as ambassadors, including the Hon. Sir Robert Cotton, the Hon. Douglas McClelland and the Hon. Don Grimes. All are former members of this chamber who have represented Australia overseas with great distinction. I am also thinking of the present head of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Richard Woolcott, who was formerly Ambassador to the United Nations. I could take the rest of the morning listing names of very distinguished Australians who have served overseas, representing their country as ambassadors and high commissioners.

The Government now seeks to cast a slur over all of these people by suggesting that there is something wrong with the conduct of ambassadors. Most of those who have served their country have been in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade for a very long time before they are ever appointed to the position of ambassador or high commissioner. They have gone in as young men and women and they have served their country overseas in a number of positions before they ever get to that stage. They know perfectly well how ambassadors and high commissioners behave and our country has been served well by them.

It is absolutely offensive in the extreme to suddenly suggest that there is something wrong with the way ambassadors behave by wanting to review guidelines for their conduct. They know how to conduct themselves. But because one, whom the Government is seemingly trying to protect, has been behaving in a way in which I regard as reprehensible, considering some of the admissions that he himself has made to the Western Australian Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters, it is very clear that he has no idea how an ambassador should behave. One might even go so far as to say that he has no idea how a Premier should behave. For that reason, I wish to place on the record my outrage at this approach of the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to seek to lessen the behaviour of Mr Burke by drawing the behaviour of all ambassadors and high commissioners, past and present, into question.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows:
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1990-91

Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91, together with Appropriation Bill (No. 5) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), which I shall introduce shortly, comprise the Additional Estimates for 1990-91.

In these Bills, Parliament is asked to appropriate moneys to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures additional to the appropriations made for 1990-91 under Appropriation Acts (Nos. 1, 2 and 3) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act.

Although the Budget figuring contained allowances for prospective wage and salary increases, those amounts were not then appropriated, and funds are now required to meet increases resulting from the Structural Efficiency Principle and other award decisions.

Of the additional appropriations in the three Additional Estimates Bills totalling $1,000.2 million, $723.8 million is sought in Appropriation Bill (No. 4), $274.4 million in Appropriation Bill (No. 5) and $1.9 million in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2).

These amounts are offset, in part, by savings in the Appropriations made by Appropriation Acts (Nos. 1 and 2) 1990-91, reflecting the Government's determination to improve the efficiency of continuing programs. These savings, amounting to $270.5 million, are detailed under the relevant appropriation headings in the document ` `Statement of Savings Expected in Annual Appropriations, which has been distributed to Honourable Members.

The appropriations now sought represent a net increase of $729.7 million in payments to be financed from annual appropriations in 1990-91, an increase of 2.3 per cent on the amounts made available at the time of the 1990-91 Budget.

Including Appropriation Act (No. 3) 1990-91, which provided additional sums resulting from the Gulf War, the total gross additional appropriations for 1990-91 amount to $1,234.3 million. In net terms this is $963.8 million, or 3.1 per cent of the initial annual appropriations made available for this year.

I now outline some of the main areas for which the Government has found it necessary to seek additional provisions in the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91 to meet payments for the ordinary annual services of the Government.

$119.7 million, or an increase of 1.3 per cent, is included for increased running costs, of which some $65 million is to cover the costs of the Structural Efficiency Principle and other award decisions, while the balance is mostly the result of various minor initiatives and transfers between financial years.
Gross additional estimates of $278.2 million are sought for the Defence Portfolio in Appropriation Bill (No. 4).
The gross figures include:

- $32.2 million for running costs, reflecting costs associated with the Gulf deployment, approved civilian and service salary increases and increases in certain allowances for Defence Force personnel;
- $206.3 million which largely reflects adjustments for price movements and variations in progress on a number of projects, including payments for ANZAC Ships and submarine refit;
- $29.6 million for defence facilities, attributable to greater activity levels due to economic conditions and price increases; and

- $6.8 million for Defence Housing, reflecting an increase in the capital subvention to the Defence Housing Authority as part of the Government's commitment to spend $750 million on Defence housing over 10 years.

Taking account of all transactions contributing to the Defence function, including offsets provided from increased revenues and a reduction in the provision for contingent salary and related increases, total Defence Outlays are estimated to increase by $181 million.
In addition, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) provides:

- a further $29.6 million to meet insurance claims associated with defaults by Iraq on credit sales by the Australian Wheat Board insured under the National Interest provisions of the Australian Trade Commission Act;
- $19.1 million to pay out borrowings by Austrade on behalf of the Commonwealth to finance National Interest claims for rescheduled Iraqi cheese debt;

- an increase of $5 million for emergency aid to meet needs arising from the Gulf War. This amount includes a $2 million contribution to the International Committee of the Red Cross, a $1 million contribution to the United Nations and $0.5 million for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for emergency assistance for Palestinian Refugees;
- $41.3 million for the increased demand and fee increases for non-departmental hospital care for veterans, together with increased costs in Veterans' Medical Services;

- $23.0 million for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, including $8.2 million for Community Development Employment Projects, and $9.0 million for the National Aboriginal Health Strategy;
- a further $12.9 million for trade training, of which $10 million is for additional pre-vocational course places at TAFE Colleges and $1.8 million for Out-of-Trade Training Centres;
- an additional $28.7 million for AUSTUDY, reflecting increased numbers of recipients in the latter half of 1990, together with an anticipated increase in the first half of 1991; and
- $22.6 million for a major new overseas marketing campaign by the Australian Tourist Commission.

These additional appropriations are required to meet commitments that have been made by the Government since the Budget, as well as un- avoidable cost and price increases and other parameter changes since the Budget was prepared.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Motion
Motion (by Senator Bolkus)-by leave-agreed to:

That the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91, the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1990-91 and the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1990-91 may be taken together for their remaining stages.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 May, on motion by Senator Cook:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Appropriation Bills that the Senate is now debating-Appropriation Bills Nos. 4 and 5 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2)-comprise the Additional Estimates. They appropriate funds for certain proposed expenditure in addition to the amounts proposed by Parliament at Budget time last year. They provide additional funding for government expenditure to get the Government through to the end of this financial year on 30 June.

SPEECH.PARA: Appropriation Bill (No. 4) seeks ad-ditional appropriations of $723.8m to meet payments for the ordinary annual services of government. That amount is additional to the $234.1m that was sought recently in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) for the Gulf involvement and for the national interest insurance claims for Iraqi wheat payment defaults.

Appropriation Bill (No. 5) seeks ad-ditional appropriations of $274.4m for capital works and services, payments to the States, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory, advances and loans and other services.

Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) seeks additional appropriations of $1.9m for recurrent expenditure of parliamentary departments, including increased costs of televising parliament. No doubt later in this debate other speakers from the coalition will go into more detail on some of the items of the appropriations. I do not propose to go into detail.

I stress that the Opposition does not oppose these Appropriation Bills but, while supporting them, we continue to be appalled at the Government's continuing fiscal irresponsibility and economic mismanagement. For that reason, on behalf of the Opposition, I move the following amendment to the second reading motion:
At end of motion, add: ``but that the Senate condemns the Government for its economic mismanagement and fiscal irresponsibility which has resulted in a severe and protracted recession and led to
(a) a substantial shortfall in Commonwealth revenues for the year ending 30 June 1990-91:
(b) a major increase in Commonwealth expenditure for the year ending 30 June 1991;
(c) a reduction in the Budget forecast of an estimated $8.1 billion surplus to a possible deficit for 1991;
(d) an increase in the public sector's call on national savings of up to 3 per cent of gross domestic product in 1991 compared with the Budget forecast of a zero requirement; and
(e) an expected deficit starting point for the 1991-92 Budget based on the existing Forward Estimates''.

These Appropriation Bills for the Ad-ditional Estimates come at a time of a major unravelling in the Government's 1990-91 Budget which was introduced last August. Indeed, the degree to which a Budget outturn for the end of the year will be so different from the outturn forecast in the Budget itself is unprecedented. The Budget forecast for this year announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Budget Speech in August last year was that there would be a surplus of $8.107 billion this year. That figure, we knew, was ridiculously and unrealistically optimistic at the time, and every event since then has simply confirmed the Opposition's view, which was stated loudly and clearly on Budget night, that the $8.1 billion surplus prediction was highly unlikely to be achieved; indeed that it was almost impossible for its achievement given the economic circumstances facing Australia at the time. Our predictions have been confirmed week by week, month by month since then.

The net result is that the Government is estimating for the year as a whole that, instead of the $8.1 billion surplus, there will be a surplus of the order of $1.7 billion, which is a major deterioration. That figure of $1.7 billion is itself likely to be optimistic. There is a very real prospect that, far from having a surplus of that magnitude, there may not be any surplus at all this year. Indeed, it is not impossible that, come 30 June, the Government Budget could be in minor deficit. Whether it is minor deficit or minor surplus is irrelevant to the fact that there has been a major deterioration in the fiscal position.

That has enormous consequences for the overall finances of the nation. At the time of the Budget the Government predicted that the public sector borrowing requirement, that is, the call that the public sector as a whole-Commonwealth, State, and local government-might make on national savings this year would be zero. The Treasurer rightly said in his Budget Speech that the spending would have to be kept in check for a substantial period to create an exportable surplus in our national production. He said, though:
. . . these goals can only be accomplished if broad economic policy is kept tight. This Budget will more than uphold its end of the bargain.

That has not happened, nor have many of the States been able to maintain the degree of financial tightness and discipline that would be required for the public sector as a whole not to have to draw on the savings of the nation.

As a result of that blow-out at both Commonwealth and State government level, but particularly at the Commonwealth Budget level, the public sector will this year make a call on the savings of this nation of the order of $10 billion or thereabouts-a figure not far short of 3 per cent of gross domestic product. That requirement by the public sector stands in the starkest possible contrast to the correct statement that the Treasurer made to the Premiers at last year's Premiers Conference:
It is very important for Australia that . . . the public sector has not got its hands on the savings cookie jar of Australia . . .
What has happened this year has been that the public sector has once again put its hands into the cookie jar of national savings at the expense of the private sector.

Indeed, one of the Treasurer's much vaunted claims to his title as a respectable Treasurer over recent years has been his boast that for three years in a row-including this year, 1990-91-the public sector as a whole would be either in surplus or not in deficit. In fact, in only one of those years-the first of the three-will that objective be achieved.

I refer to the role of the public sector in terms of Australia's overall economic structure. Over recent years and, indeed, throughout most of the 1980s, it has been in absolutely the wrong position for what was required if it were to play its part in stimulating and encouraging an environment for private sector growth in investment and employment output. As I said before, throughout virtually all the period of the Hawke Government, with one minor exception, the government sector has been a major drawer on the savings of this nation. That, perhaps more than any other factor, is the reason why this nation has become increasingly uncompetitive, why there has been no increase in productivity during the period of this Government and why we have an economic recession which is deeper than at any other time since the 1930s.

The Australian economy is more recessed now than it has been for virtually 60 years. One only has to have a look at some of the statistics to confirm that. In the last 12 months unemployment has increased in this country by 263,000 or 51 per cent. Indeed, figures that will be released in less than 10 minutes time will almost certainly confirm another leap in that listing of human misery and hardship.

The rate of unemployment in the last 12 months has increased from 6.2 per cent to 9.2 per cent. In two States of Australia the figure is already officially over 10 per cent. If one talks about figures in the private sector and in government, there is no doubt that the real unemployment figure in Australia as a whole is already well over 10 per cent and rising.

The level of recipients of unemployment benefits over the last 12 months has gone up by 200,000 or 52 per cent. Job vacancies are down 52 per cent. There are now 28 people unemployed for every job vacancy. Only 12 months ago the number of unemployed for every job vacancy was about 9 1/2. In other words, the ratio has gone out in the wrong direction by a factor of almost three in the last 12 months.

It is true that the inflation rate in Australia has come down and will probably continue to do so for the next few months. But if a country as recessed as Australia did not have a falling inflation rate, the situation would be even more damning than it is today. Despite the fact that we have the greatest recession for 60 years, the great concern we all ought to have is that our unemployment rate is still higher than most of our major trading partners.

No changes have been made in the structure of the Australian economy to give one any confidence. When the economy recovers-as it inevitably and surely will at some stage, although I do not believe that it will happen for another 12 months; the Government has done little to change the basic underlying structure of Australia to get an improvement and a solution to the problems facing this nation-there is no doubt that the inflation band wagon will take off again. I believe that if any one factor above all else is incumbent on the Government, which is supported by business, the unions and every member of the community, it is to engender in Australia a psychology of an anti-inflation bent. We have to develop an anti-inflation culture in this country. We have to develop a pro savings culture and a pro productivity and competitiveness culture. Unless we do that, we will continue on the boom and bust road that we have had for many years now-a road which has been made increasingly bumpy by the incredibly incompetent mismanagement of the Hawke Government over the last eight years.

At the moment no long term joy can be derived out of the inflation rate, encouraging though the downward trend temporarily is. The economy has been in a negative phase of growth-depending on how it is measured-for four out of the last five quarters. Motor vehicle registrations are down annually by a figure of almost 36 per cent, dwelling approvals are down 13 per cent, manufacturing production is down 6.3 per cent and new capital expenditure is down almost 10 per cent. How will we get increasing productivity and a more productive climate in this country if we have the continuing downturn in real investment and capital expenditure that we have seen so sadly and eloquently demonstrated in the last year or so?

The state of the economy is of great concern. It is delusory on the part of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer and the Leader of the Government in this place, Senator Button, to talk about the worst being over. One would hope that the worst is over, but the worst is not over. There is more to come. I regret that there is a great deal more hardship and pain to be sustained by the Australian community before we start to see a sustainable upturn in the longer term.

The worst we could do would be to get an overstimulatory response to the present situation without at the same time tackling the fundamental problems that exist. That was the great tragedy of the so-called industry statement of 12 March. It was the Government's last chance to attempt to really tackle problems in a meaningful way in terms of creating a productive and competitive environment in this country.

The Government blew the opportunity that it had. It did admittedly take a decision to reduce the level of tariffs, but that decision only went along the route that had been advocated by many, including the coalition, for a lengthy period before that. That decision to reduce tariffs was correct. Where it went off the rails, though, in policy terms was that it was not in any way accompanied by the other measures to reduce costs and improve productivity and competitiveness in such a way that the need for continuing tariffs of existing levels was required.

The great difference between this Government and the Liberal and National parties is that the coalition has a package of economic policy measures of which tariff reduction is only one. But the package as a whole is designed to encourage the greater flexibility and the more efficient use of resources in Australia, which is the only route that can be taken if we are to have a long term and sustainably competitive future for this country, including all sectors of the economy and, most of all, our manufacturing sector. Under this Government the manufacturing sector has taken a beating that it has never taken in the history of our nation. The number of jobs that has been lost in manufacturing unnecessarily because of incompetent economic management in the last eight years is the greatest in our history. It is a shocking indictment of this Government that that has happened.

Manufacturing industry in this country ought to have a great future; just as there ought to be, and will be, a great future for the mining industries, the great rural industries of this country and the growing tertiary sector. But that will not happen-indeed, the opposite will happen-if the right structures of government are not put into place. For those reasons we in the Opposition are very concerned at the way the economy and the fiscal position of the Government have deteriorated over the last 12 months.

Therefore, the starting point for the next Budget-the Budget for 1991-92-will be extraordinarily difficult. There is now no doubt at all that the starting point for the next Budget will be one of significant deficit. For the Government to get its Budget structure for 1991 into the right phase it will have to take decisions which will require a degree of courage and fortitude which this Government has shown patently over the last eight years that it lacks almost entirely. So the problems and the prospects for the 1991-92 Budget look extremely difficult from a government fiscal position. The task ahead of the Government in the months ahead-to get an economically responsible and respectable Budget-is a very difficult one indeed.

Those government decisions need to foster various things. The first thing the Government needs to do is adopt policy measures which reduce costs in Australia. If the Government continues to take bad decisions, or fails to take decisions that do lead to reduced costs and greater competitiveness-particularly in the area of the labour market, land transport, rail transport, the waterfront and shipping industries-and if it continues to stall on structural reform in those areas there is no way in which we will become sufficiently cost competitive and restore our international competitiveness.

I interrupt myself and return to my earlier comments about unemployment. The figures that have just been released in the last five minutes confirm my earlier remarks.
