Seasonally adjusted unemployment in April has increased by 66,900 to make a total of 844,000 unemployed people. That is the largest monthly rise in unemployment ever recorded by the Australian Bureau of Statistics surveys. That seasonally adjusted estimate of the unemployment rate for April has brought a rise of 0.7 percentage points to now make the official unemployment rate in Australia 9.9 per cent. In fact, in five States of Australia seasonally adjusted unemployment exceeds 10 per cent. For the Government to say that the worst is over is a criminal delusion of those persons who have been thrown onto the unemployment scrap heap by this Government's policies.

The economic policies of this Government have caused this recession, this misery and this hardship. Not in one instance have those policies produced any hope that there is a better way or that there is any light at the end of the tunnel. The debate on these matters over the months ahead will be highlighted by several key issues. The key issue facing this country is: how will we adopt policies at the government level which will halt the hardship and the misery which are being caused?

Of course, the cruelest statistic is unemployment, but it is not the only statistic. In the last 12 months bankruptcies have increased by 53 per cent. The profits of most companies have plummeted, as has their cash flow situation, because of an interest rate policy which, despite the fall in nominal interest rates, still has real interest rates at a level of almost 10 per cent-at the moment the figure is about 9 per cent. The Government's economic policies, which cause real interest rates to be at that level, automatically mean that businesses will fail and people will go out of business.

There is a prospect that real interest rates will rise in the months ahead. As inflation, as a result of the dramatic recession that we have, causes perhaps further falls in nominal interest rates-the fall in nominal interest rates will not be sufficient to be able to match that temporary fall in inflation-so real interest rates will rise. The only way that can change is if the Government takes hold of its Budget decisions and takes measures throughout the economy in the areas of industrial relations, wage reform and structural reform which will allow us to get our real interest rates down. So the prospects in that area are of great concern also.

It is for those reasons that, whilst the Opposition does not oppose the Appropriation Bills-of course, Additional Estimates Bills are ones that, traditionally, are not opposed by the Opposition-we wish to use this occasion as a vehicle to draw attention to the criminally incompetent mismanagement of this Government. This mismanagement has now brought misery to 844,000 people officially and to well over one million people, if we really look at the figures that are involved. It has produced a massive rise in bankruptcies, corporate difficulties and has created problems for the future.

That situation does not need to exist. We have great prospects in Australia. We have the skills, the people, the natural resources and the technology to enable us to be a vibrant nation again; to be a competitive and a growing nation-particularly within our own region. There is no need for us in Australia to think that the recession we now have ought to have occurred. It ought not to have occurred. It occurred simply because of government mismanagement. This situation does not have to continue into the future and it will not continue provided that we have a government which is prepared, and able, to take the decisions that will lead to the great potential and capacities of our nation-our people, our resources and our prospects-being realised.

That is the task for the decade ahead. It is the task for the months ahead because, whilst we have long term potential for a good future, if we do not take the approaches now that are necessary in order to capitalise on our great opportunities we and the Government of the day will stand rightly condemned in the eyes of the Australian people. The only way we will solve our problems at a government level-given the fact that this Government has had not far short of a decade in which to try to run this country and has produced the greatest disasters in this nation's history-is to have a change of government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Appropriation Bill (No. 4), the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) and the Appropriation Bill (No. 5), I endorse the comments of my colleague Senator Short and take the Senate back 12 months. It was approximately 12 months ago that a number of new members entered this Parliament. Prior to their entry, during the election campaign, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and others consistently said, `There will be no recession' and, amongst other things, `We are on top of the economy'.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet today Australia faces the worst economic situation since the 1930s, and in many rural areas it is even worse than then. On a comparison of the claims made by the Government during the last election campaign with what it said in November when Australia suddenly had the recession that we had to have, that is one of the greatest lies ever perpetrated on the Australian community. I am sure the Australian public will long remember that lie.

It is very sad and disappointing for the honest, average Australians who get up every day to do a good honest day's work to find themselves in the situation where they do not have a clue where they will be in one month, two months or six months because the Government's economic policy is totally devoid of direction and new ideas. Every time somebody comes up with some idea to reform Australia's industrial relations system, the taxation system or the method by which social problems are handled, all those opposite can do is knock, knock, knock.

Three key factors-not the only ones but the important ones-are used to measure the state of an economy. The first is a comparison of how the country is going with the Budget presented at the commencement of the financial year. That measurement of economic performance applies to a government in the same way as it does to a businessman or any householder-how one is travelling now as compared with the estimates made at the beginning of the year. Currently, under the management of the Hawke-Keating Government, Australia is travelling very badly.

The second factor is the condition of the current account. Once again Australia is heading into a current account deficit of approximately $17 billion to $18 billion before the year is out. It has continued in this vein for a significant number of years with very little improvement. The Government's only way of bringing about any improvement in the current account-and probably the net result at the end will not be much different-is to screw people into the ground and destroy producers with an overemphasis on monetary policy. That overemphasis on monetary policy has sent many good Australian businesses broke.

Senator Short referred to the number of bankruptcies in the past 12 months or so. That number is running at a record level and will continue to do so. Only last week when I came through my home town of Ravensthorpe I was met by a couple of people, and on that very day the one bank in the town had issued 12 letters of demand against 12 businesses in the district. That was just one day of this year in one little town. The Government has a lot to answer for because people in towns like this have done nothing wrong. All they have done is work their butts off and try to produce as much as they can, not only for themselves but also for the Australian economy. Had they not been forced to pay interest rates of the order of 28 per cent many of these people would still be in business today. There is nothing wrong with their business management or their output but their costs were blown right out of the sky.

When we talk about reliance upon monetary policy and interest rates we must remember that it is not just the direct costs that are affected. The service industry has to hand those costs down through the system. The transport costs go up, the cost of parts goes up and the cost of every other aspect of the operation goes up.

The third factor used to measure the state of an economy is unemployment. I have just heard the latest figure-9.9 per cent as of now. In my State of Western Australia the unemployment figure passed 10 per cent last month and it is probably over 11 per cent now.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 11.1 per cent.

—I thank Senator Short. The present unemployment rate in Western Australia is 11.1 per cent. The most resource-rich State in the Commonwealth-Western Australia has everything-has an unemployment rate of 11.1 per cent. One cannot ignore the impact of this Government's relationship with its mates in Western Australia over the past few years not only in terms of its financial mismanagement but also in terms of the destruction of Western Australia's reputation as being a good place to deal with. I suggest that anybody who does not believe me should take a trip to Asia. Asian business people describe Western Australian business people as the cowboys of the world. That is an absolute indictment of the performance of the Burke, Dowding and, more lately, Lawrence governments of Western Australia. The fact that Brian Burke continues to hold his ambassadorial position can be described as nothing but a disgrace and absolutely pathetic.

SPEECH.PARA: I have identified three key factors in the measurement of the performance of an economy: how we are travelling against the Budget, the current account and unemployment. Of course, many other things could be used to measure such performance but those three are the key ones. This Government's performance, as measured against all of those factors, fails dismally.

I now look at a few figures in relation to the Bills before us. The additional appropriations for 1991 are about $963.8m net. That is an increase of 3.1 per cent over the projected figures. Appropriations for 1990-91 in net terms are approximately $30 billion. While all other members of the business community are having to tighten their belts and cut their expenditure in an endeavour to survive, we see the Government bringing before us an increase in its requirements. One must ask why there cannot be a little more fiscal management in order to bring this under control.

If we look at the sector that I have been involved in all my life-that is, the farm sector-we see that farmers have had to cut their budget expenditure by up to 50 per cent. They cannot ask the taxpayer for a bit more money. Why can we not apply some of those business principles to government management?

If we look at some aspects of what has occurred through this mismanagement, we find that net pay-as-you-earn estimates for the eight months to February this year are $1.65 billion behind Budget Estimates. If we go further, we find that for prescribed payments in the same period there is a shortfall of $247m. We see that company tax receipts are down $377m. One could argue that, because of that, the Government can legitimately say, `We have to recover or offset that loss'. That is a nonsense argument.

If this economy had been managed in any sort of a responsible manner, we would find that those figures would be up; productivity would be up. If we had addressed our industrial system and put a little emphasis on getting productivity up and running in this country, those figures would be up. There would be no need to come back here asking for more money. We could, in fact, produce a very large and real surplus. That is where the crux of the problem lies. This is what happens when those people who produce, who ultimately pay tax-and I include employees and employers in that-are screwed into the ground. We have seen today that there are some 844,000 people without jobs now. If we had a properly managed economy, those people could be out in the work force being productive and paying tax; but instead we have things back-to-front.

I will now make some comments about our current account deficit, which is currently running at approximately $13 billion. As I have already said, it will end up at somewhere between $17 and $18 billion a year. Last year at the debt summit, it was identified that to stabilise our debt in this country and to get on top of our current account deficit, we needed a net growth of about 4 per cent in export earnings for the next 10 years.

What has this Government done to facilitate that situation? The situation will not be improved by screwing people into the ground deeper and deeper, but it will be improved if incentives are provided for people to get out there and do things. In providing incentives, a number of areas in particular must be addressed. The first one has to be the taxation system. The taxation system in this country penalises anybody who has a go. It penalises exporters, the very people whom we need to bring about a net growth of 4 per cent each year for the next 10 years for Australia to get on top of its financial problems and return to being the country it was some 40 or 50 years ago. That should be a challenge that everybody in this place, the other place and throughout the Australian community should accept willingly.

But when we have a government with policies which create a situation whereby exactly the opposite happens, how can we criticise what is now quoted readily-that Australian quote, `She'll be right, mate.'? Of course `she'll be right' if there is nothing in it at the end of the day for the individual. We must give a little incentive, the opportunity to perform, and some reward at the end of the day. We only have to look at how our sports men and women perform. If we give them a bit of encouragement, they are as good as or better than anybody else in the world. Certainly, when it comes to determination and application, there are none anywhere who can match our sports people.

There needs to be a drastic and radical overhaul of our taxation system. We must put incentive and reward back into the taxation system, so that those people who do a little or a lot extra are encouraged and so that those people who invest are encouraged to do so. I have mentioned in this place before that our sales tax regime penalises our exporters who are in competition with other countries around the world-particularly America, Canada, Europe, Argentina and, shortly, I would imagine, South Africa-which do not penalise their exporters through their taxation systems, giving those exporters an enormous advantage over the Australian exporter in the marketplace. This will become more and more important as protection is reduced in this country.

We are now on a course of the reduction of protection, which I welcome. It is unstoppable. But, as that protection drops and we see our growing manufacturing industries hopefully moving towards becoming internationally competitive, they will not want any government imposed penalties to be placed on them through the taxation system when they are competing out in the real world. They will want the removal of much of the unnecessary regulation and duplication that occurs in this country.

I mention one budding industry, particularly in Western Australia, which is affected by that regulation and duplication-the flower industry. Those people moving into the export of flowers, particularly to Asia, have to get a certificate of inspection, which costs $35 for every half-hour spent inspecting the flowers, even though the certificate has no commercial value. If the inspection goes one minute over that half an hour, the price goes up to $70. When the flowers get to markets in Japan, Korea and other Asian countries, the certificate has no value at all. The inspection is done all over again by the country of entry. Yet, because of our export regulations, those flowers are not allowed to leave the country before being inspected. It is ludicrous-and that is just one example of the sorts of regulations we have in place.

I would just like to raise a couple of points which came out of the Estimates. Although I will be pursuing them in the committee stage, I want to identify them in this speech. Before I do that I shall make a few comments regarding the tax that is about to be imposed on the wool industry. I have been provoked to do this by that incredible answer given to us yesterday in this place by Senator Cook and that incredible interview given by Minister Kerin on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio yesterday. I shall read part of the answer. It states:
The imposition of a 15 per cent tax rate, rather than the 12 per cent recommended by the Vines committee, will result in a tax higher by hundreds of dollars-
I emphasise the word `hundreds'-

rather than thousands of dollars. At a time when growers will already be experiencing very tight incomes, our view would be that a few hundred dollars extra will not be the decider in terms of bankruptcies, as the honourable senator's question implies. The difference between a 12 per cent and a 15 per cent levy on growers' viability is also, in our view, insignificant . . .

What an incredible statement! When things are tight, the cents count. Here we have the Minister talking about hundreds of dollars not being significant. The sad part about this answer is that it is a damned lie, an absolute total lie. Let us look at the actual figures in the average situation for woolgrowers in this country. I state quite categorically here, to put it on the public record, that in net terms the difference between a 15 per cent tax rate and 12 per cent tax rate is $4,126.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Crane, on reflection of some remarks that I understood you to have just made, there is a possibility that one might infer that you were saying that the Minister has lied. If you have said that, you should withdraw it.

—I shall withdraw the remark; I did say it. The difference is $4,126. It is not the couple of hundred dollars that the Minister says; it is 41 hundreds. If we put this into gross terms, we have to add more than another $2,000, or another 20 hundreds. It has to be realised that, to produce a 15 per cent tax which the Corporation keeps, costs one half of one per cent. We are looking at a situation whereby that 15 per cent tax, in terms of the gross impact-I am glad that Senator Button has walked into the chamber-is 22 1/2 per cent. If we reduce that tax to 8 per cent, the gross impact is 12 per cent, and we are talking about many hundreds of dollars, in fact thousands, not the couple of hundred that Senator Cook talked about yesterday. If we look further at its impact on the pre-tax net returns of growers last year-I am talking about woolgrowers-that tax is 16.7 per cent this year. One can only estimate what the income of a woolgrower will be. The difference in that 3 per cent could well be 50 per cent of the total net income of woolgrowers. It is not insignificant.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to raise other points in the committee stage but I shall give notice of them now. One relates to the flock reduction scheme which for a variety of reasons caused a lot of heartburn for many people, including me. Yet I did support it and I am quite willing to say that. If we look at it, between 13 1/2 million and 15 million sheep would have been taken out by this scheme at an average cost of about $3.80 per head; certainly less than $4 per head. Until the scheme is completed we will not know the final price. Yet on questioning of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the Australian Wool Corporation, we find that no cost benefit analysis has been done on that particular scheme. I find that absolutely extraordinary.

My next point relates to the fact that at the Estimates Committee hearings last year I raised the issue of farm plans in terms of getting tax deductibility for conservation work on properties. We still do not have a satisfactory answer to that. One must question why, in what is a taxation provision, somebody has to come in to authorise the farm plan. Surely the taxation laws are sufficient in this country that, if the provision is abused, action can be taken within that arena.

I shall conclude my remarks by re-emphasising the three points I raised at the beginning of these comments. First we need to measure how we are going-whether it relates to a government, a business or a household-compared with the initial budget. Secondly, we must look at how the current account situation is going. Thirdly, we must look at how the unemployment situation is going. In each of these three measures, the Government has failed dismally. Unless there is a rethink about the direction that must be taken to resurrect this country, we will keep on sliding down the road which we are now on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91, which is in the package before us. I want to talk about the Department of Defence Supplementary Estimates, which include the expenditure of $68.882m in relation to the Gulf, principally for the Royal Australian Navy (RAN) contingent that served there. At the outset I pay tribute to the members of the Australian Defence Force who served in the Gulf. They were, in the main, the crews of the RAN ships, but they also involved RAN divers who did what I regard as one of the most unpleasant tasks that befell the lot of any servicemen or women who served in the Gulf. The waters in which they were operating and the conditions under which they were operating, with the booby traps, the mines, and the underwater defences in the harbours around Kuwait, were distinctly unpleasant and distinctly dangerous, to say the least.

SPEECH.PARA: We also had a number of exchange personnel, who had been posted to friendly countries, serving in units which were transferred to the Gulf, and we had a large medical contingent on the USS Comfort. All of the Australians who served in the theatre of operations acquitted themselves well and brought very favourable comment for their country.

Most of the medical personnel who served there were reservists. One of the problems that has emerged with the reserve medical component and the dental component-it is something for which the Government has proposed no solution at present-is the great loss of income that a great many of these people suffered by being called up for active service. They are all prepared to do this or they would not be members of the reserves, but it really does cause acute hardship. These people are mainly self-employed, sole traders, whose overheads are quite considerable. The overheads continue while they are on duty and the recompense they get in respect of their service in no way meets their outgoings. Call up for a period of continuous service costs them a great deal of money. This is the problem that the Americans have experienced also, because their medical services are largely dependent upon reservists.

The way the world is, with volunteer armies, we must rely very heavily on reserves. This problem has to be overcome, and it can be overcome only by the allocation of some financial recompense for those who are genuinely out of pocket as a consequence of service. However, I digress there.

I refer to the expenditure of $68.882m, which the Government had to make to get the Navy into the Gulf. That money should have been spent years and years ago. In other words, the ships were not equipped to operate in a hostile environment in a combat role. Money was spent on infra-red sensors for mine detection, on beefing up communications systems, for close-in weapons systems, and on other items of equipment which were essential.

Despite the expenditure of what is a relatively large amount of money-$68m-only four ships out of the whole of the Royal Australian Navy were equipped to operate in a hostile environment as a consequence of that expenditure. As I said before, that money should have been spent years ago, to maintain a threshold degree of preparedness in the Navy, and a similar argument applies in relation to both the Air Force and the Army.

When the Gulf war started we simply had no force in the Australian Defence Force that we could have sent there for immediate service. The Navy required a considerable expenditure of money to get a small number of ships ready. The Air Force similarly required tens of millions of dollars in expenditure on electronic welfare capability, the purchase of precision guided munitions and the training in the use of those munitions, before it could have gone to the Gulf on an active service basis.

The Army, despite being the largest of all three services in Australia, whatever the amount of money we have spent on it, simply could not have taken a place with a formation in a conventional modern land battle. Our personnel are trained for light infantry tasks. The operational deployment force in Townsville, for example, is a very highly trained unit, but there is very little place for it on the modern battlefield.

The Government has to address the problem of what it wants the Australian defence forces to do and to equip them with a central professional capability in all three combat arms-Army, Navy and Air Force-so that they have a degree of readiness. We cannot have the whole of the defence forces in a high state of readiness because it is economically impossible. No country does that. Neither the United States nor Israel, the two principal countries with a demand for defence forces being in a high state of readiness, does that. With our economic base, it is impossible for us to have more than a limited level of readiness. But at present we have a total inadequacy with respect to readiness and that must be addressed.

The primary reason for this is the fact that the defence budget is so low. We are now spending about 2.3 per cent of what is a very low gross domestic product (GDP), the lowest for more than 40 years. The mandarins in this town who seem to know everything are talking quite confidently of the percentage of GDP going to defence being reduced to 2 per cent. I have even heard figures of 1.5 per cent and even lower in five or six years time, if the policies presently followed by this Government are kept in place. If we reach that situation, we simply should not be spending anything at all on defence, because it would become just farcical and be a waste of money.

One of the disturbing things in relation to defence expenditure at present is the Force Structure Review Committee, the findings of which are due to be announced in this Parliament on 6 June. This is a major cost cutting exercise, which will have enormous consequences on the capability of the Australian defence forces. It will bring on for the Government the biggest fight since conscription for overseas service in Australia. It has never been debated in this Parliament because very little information is available on it, but there has been a series of selected leaks that have come from the offices of the two Ministers responsible, that of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) and that of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray). Whenever members of the press pick up the two Ministers on this and ask for further details, or start to question them on it, further debate is denied on the grounds that the matter has yet to go to Cabinet and they are told that it will be announced and made clear on 6 June.

I think the leaks do have a degree of veracity. The origins for this review are very obscure. There is certainly no protest out there in the Australian community about the amount of money we spend on defence. In fact, in the last three or four weeks a survey came out that showed that 61 per cent of Australians are not satisfied with the level of defence capability of this country. They do not think the Australian defence forces are able to defend the country to the extent that the general population expect. My assumption is that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said to Mr Bilney, who is a very charming eccentric, that something ought to be done. I say that with respect, Minister. I enjoy Mr Bilney's company enormously.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister would not be taking a point of order. To describe someone as a charming eccentric can, in fact, be quite flattering in this place.

—I enjoy Mr Bilney's company enormously, but not even Mr Bilney would pretend to understand the Australian defence forces in any way at all. I believe he went to Headquarters ADF and said, `We need to save some money because Mr Keating has told me to', and they have turned around and said, `Very well, your wish is our command' and have cut everyone's jobs but their own.

SPEECH.PARA: I am alarmed at the projected cuts in the combat capability of the Australian defence forces, particularly the proposal that they are going to create an emergency reserve, which is something that was tried in the 1960s. It does not work. It cannot work. There is not a pool of youths in the Australian community who are prepared to do 12 months of continuous training, followed by four years with a commitment of at least two months in the reserves.

What we want in the Reserve forces is the brightest and the best. One of the central lessons of the Gulf war was the importance of having highly trained, high quality personnel using high quality weapons systems. We cannot get that if we are recruiting our reservists, who are the first line of supplementation for the Defence Force, from the unemployed or the unemployable, which is what the emergency reserve proposed by the present crew at Russell will do. Australia will be very badly served if that happens.

If that goes ahead we will see a very marked reduction in the minuscule combat capability of the Army and the Air Force. We will also see the complete devastation of the reserves in the Army that have never had a fair go because of the budgetary constraints that have been placed upon them. But with a shrinking budget it is inevitable that a new emergency reserve will bite very, very deeply into the resources of both the Army and the Air Force.

I have no objection at all to the taxpayer getting value for money and, indeed, it is obligatory on all of us in this Parliament to ensure that they do. There are examples of waste and inefficiency in the defence forces. They ought to be cleaned up. But after seven years on the job we do not see any of that coming from this Government. We still see a vast degree of overmanning and overranking in the Australian defence forces.

Back in 1987 the defence committee of this Parliament produced its report Management of Australia's Defences and took to task the great degree of overranking that exists in the Australian defence forces. Nothing has been done about that. For example, the Australian Army has one officer to every six other ranks-that is, 16.6 per cent. The comparable figure for the United States is 13.3 per cent. Putting it another way, the Australian Defence Force has a proportion of officers of general rank-that is, one star and above-to all personnel of 1 : 456. In the United States it is 1 : 2,020.

It costs a great deal of money to keep a general by the time we pay his DFRDB-Defence Force retirement and death benefits-and all the other expenditures that are associated with having senior officers. As our report in 1987 showed, the number of senior officers in the Australian Defence Force has virtually doubled since the early 1960s and for no real purpose at all. Part of it, of course, has come about through inadequate salaries paid to Defence Force personnel. One of the ways of overcoming that is to promote them; but to do that is bad management practice and, of course, it generates greater costs in the longer term.

I turn now to the Gulf expenditure. There were many lessons in the Gulf operation of value to the Australian defence forces. Characteristically, the Government and the Department of Defence have pretended that the Gulf operation did not occur, and the only statement we have had has been the statement read by the Chief of the Defence Force, a ministerial statement at the air power conference some months ago, in which, inter alia, the Minister said that we really have to be very careful about looking at the Gulf because it is not Australia; different circumstances apply here.

It was a different geographical circumstance but it really was the first large-scale example of the exercise of armed forces in all three combat arms-Army, Navy and Air Force-that we had seen for nearly 45 years, since Korea. There were a lot of lessons that came out of that in relation to Australia's needs.

I would like to thank the Minister for Defence at this point. When the operations started in the Gulf, the Minister took to Cabinet the proposition that the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman of the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade make an official visit to the region. That was accepted by Cabinet and I think it was of great value to the Parliament. Mr Ted Lindsay from the House of Representatives and I went along, he as the Chairman and I as Deputy Chairman representing the Senate. I am grateful to the Government for affording us that opportunity.

We arrived in the theatre of operations four days after the cessation of hostilities. We were able to meet all the senior commanders in the headquarters groups. I would like to record my appreciation for the way in which those visits were arranged. I thank the people who did that. I would also like to thank our hosts, the various senior officers in the headquarters group. We were all enormously impressed with the professional capability of those men and women. The professionalism, the intelligence and the capability of the headquarters staff were really outstanding. We had every confidence in them.

They extended us as much time as we wanted for interviews. We were a small group-we were only three-and we were the first civilian group from outside the theatre to be there meeting with them. We met with senior commanders and we had at least three-quarters of an hour with them, just in a small group-the three of us and one or maybe two of them. Nothing was off limits. We could discuss whatever we liked. We gained a great insight into how the operations were conducted and how the war was won.

The first visit we made was to General Waller, the Deputy Commander-in-Chief. He was brought in by General Schwarzkopf from Centcom, the American headquarters that ran the whole operation. He had overall command of the operations under General Schwarzkopf. While we were with General Waller he talked about the overall perspectives of the campaign as he saw them: the great way in which all three combat arms combined; the joint operations between the Air Force, the Army and the Navy; and the very high degree of interoperability between the three services and between the coalition groups. Probably the great genius of General Schwarzkopf was shown in the time he expended in diplomacy, in bringing into unison a group of more than 30 nations who had armed forces in that theatre, all working together for the common aim and support of the United Nations resolution. That did not happen easily. There were a great number of cultural differences between the forces involved, between the Western and the Arab nations.

There was also a great disparity in experience between the forces. Countries such as Saudi Arabia had never operated with the force structure and the number of troops involved in the Gulf operation. That was all accomplished without any difficulty at all, and it is a tribute to not only General Schwarzkopf but also all the senior planners that agreement was reached through discussion and everyone was brought to agreement without anyone feeling that he was being badly treated or left out of planning or that his national interests were not being considered. Under the stress of a combat situation, that is no mean achievement.

General Waller told us of the deception plan: the way they built on the perception of the Iraqis that the main attack on Kuwait would be from the Gulf by way of an amphibious landing; how they maintained that through military means through the dispatch of more and more marine amphibious units to the area, the generation of signal traffic, helicopter lifts and all the rest of it. They were so successful that up to four days before the start of the land operations on 24 February the Iraqis dispatched another three divisions into the south-east corner of Kuwait. Right up to the cease-fire time the Iraqis still maintained that the principal attack would come from the coast. Of course, it never could have come that way. There were some very good technical reasons which prevented a mass landing being made of the dimensions needed to evict the Iraqis from Kuwait on the coast there.

From General Waller we went to Admiral Sharp, who did the overall planning for the operation. Admiral Sharp was accompanied by Colonel Purvis. Colonel Purvis, a graduate of Fort Levenworth Staff College and a very brilliant mind, came with three majors and they did the operational planning-that is, the defence of Saudi Arabia. It is interesting that the defence plans for Saudi Arabia took something like four months to put together because of the need to educate and bring along all the coalition partners in the nature of the operation that was being run. Yet all of the mass of detail for the offensive campaign was written in only four weeks.

Colonel Purvis took us through the deception plan again in much greater detail and the huge logistic problems that were involved. There was a precondition for the land operations that at least 60 days supplies were in the field before the land operation could begin. That involved something like 30 million gallons of fuel alone. All of this was held south of Kuwait because until the air war started on 16-17 January the Iraqis could observe what was going on south of the border and the planners wanted to maintain the deception that the primary attack would come from an amphibious landing plus a breaching of the border between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia.

Until 15 January the Soviets were selling the Iraqis satellite information of the area. After 15 January the satellite information stopped and then the logistic suppliers could move to the west of Wadi al Batin and into the area where 7 Corps and 18 Corps ultimately made the attack which defeated the Republican Guards, which was the principal objective of the land operation.

The logistic supplies and the logistic planning were enormous and the UN forces were aided there by the great degree of overdevelopment of the infrastructure within Saudi Arabia itself. One of the principal ports used in the Gulf was Al Jubayl, which has 17 miles of dockside. That enabled all the supply ships to come in and unload thousands of tonnes of supplies onto the dockside, onto the acres and acres of concrete there, and that all went up the single road from Al Jubayl to al Batin. There was something like 42 miles of convoys a day moving up there, with 400 heavy armoured vehicles. The degree of planning that went into the logistics was enormous, as was the degree of detailed planning that went into the operation itself. When the combat started with the air war on 16-17 January, it all rolled according to plan and everything worked out very well.

All the headquarters people to whom we talked put great emphasis on the success of the air war. The air war really was the dominant factor in the campaign. I said a few minutes ago that there were 60 days supplies as a precondition for the land battle. There were also preparations for 20,000 to 30,000 casualties for the land battle on the hospital and medical teams side. So there was a huge degree of preparation there.

Despite the best of analysis, the expectation was that the land operation would run for weeks and that there would be tens of thousands of casualties. In the event, such was the power and precision of the air war that the land operation was over in 100 hours. It is a matter of history that the UN forces lost fewer than 200 killed. With the numbers of personnel involved-over half a million on each side-the huge amount of weaponry that was involved, the open nature of the terrain and all the rest of it, it was one of the great feats in history that an army that was experienced and well equipped in the way the Iraqis were, was defeated in 100 hours in a land battle for the loss of probably 120 to 130-I do not have the precise figures-of the UN forces.

A large part of the credit for that goes to the way that air power, using high technology, and using it in the correct way in accordance with modern doctrine, had such a dominating effect. That is very important for us in Australia because we have tended to assume that we will always have air superiority in this country. We have fought under air superiority in the engagements we have been involved in, probably since 1943. But if we do not have the means of obtaining air superiority in this country and if we are opposed by an opponent who has the means of using modern technology in the air against us, the ability to conduct operations on the ground no longer exists. One cannot operate on the ground if one is opposed by someone using modern technology and controlling the air space. And, as that decimation of the convoy on the Al Mutla Ridge showed, one cannot even run away if one does not enjoy some degree of air superiority.

After we talked to planners in the Central Headquarters, the staff of General Waller and Admiral Sharp and Colonel Purvis, we then moved to the British Forces Middle East Headquarters. We had a session with the Chief of Staff of--

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop name-dropping, it is ridiculous here.

—This is important from an historical record point of view. I understand the Minister would like to be off with the socialist Left somewhere on a welfare program, but I am putting this down for the benefit of the Parliament; that is why I was sent to the Middle East. We met with the Chief of Staff of the British Forces Middle East, and next morning we met with General Sir Peter de la Billiere, the British Force Commander. He is a very intelligent and a very thoughtful man who gave us a very careful analysis of the whole operation as he saw it.

SPEECH.PARA: We then met with Prince Khalid, the Commander of the Arab Forces. Then we met with Brigadier-General Glosson, who ran the air war for General Horner. Glosson and Purvis were the two really outstanding minds in the whole campaign. I say that with full respect for the intelligence and the professionalism of all the other people we met. They were an exceptional group of people, but in my judgment General Glosson and Colonel Purvis stood out. It was one of the most absorbing of all the interviews we had. General Glosson would not have us at Air Force Headquarters. He said `No, I will come to you'. He came to the Australian Embassy in Riyadh and he gave us a couple of hours, in great detail, of how the whole air campaign was put together. That was of great value to us.

We then went down to Bahrain and we went on to the RAN ships, Sydney and Westralia, and met with the crews there and saw them at sea; they were still patrolling. We met with Admiral Arthur, who was the navy commander for all the forces in the area, on Blue Ridge at Bahrain, and met with his planning staff. We then went to Kuwait City itself and saw the effects of the occupation on that city. We also saw the oil fires.

While we have watched on television, on our screens at home, those plumes of smoke on the horizon, until one sees the extent of the atmospheric pollution that is coming from it one simply cannot credit it. It depends on the wind velocity, the wind strength and the atmospherics of the day, and it changes from time to time through the day. But in the middle of the day, in what is a tropical setting, it was almost as dark as night for about an hour. It was quite scary to be there in those conditions. The major priority, I believe, and of far higher importance than any of the politics in the area, apart from saving the lives of the Kurds, is cleaning up and putting out those fires before anything else is done.

We then went to Cairo and met with the director of military intelligence in the Egyptian Army. The Egyptians had the second largest land force in the area, with two divisions and about 18 artillery battalions there, a commando brigade and a big logistic component. Then we went to Israel and talked to the Israelis. We inspected a Patriot detachment and talked to their military intelligence, as well as meeting with Deputy Foreign Minister Netanyahu and the Defence Minister, Mr Arens.

There are a couple of points out of all this that have to be emphasised in relation to Australia. The first is the matter of intelligence. There is no such thing as warning time; that is one of the things that the Gulf showed very clearly. We, therefore, do need to have a degree of readiness. It cannot be extensive but we do have to have something that is ready to go in the defence forces. We do have to have highly trained people, and we have to have high quality equipment. It is the only way we can fight. We have to have a degree of interoperability, because we are going to be involved in operations with other nations under the aegis of the UN. I think it is unlikely we will be fighting alone in any future conflicts, so the matter of interoperability is important.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of the debate that essentially covers the full range of Government activity, I wish to focus upon the lamentable failure, over six months, of the Hawke Labor Government to protect the good name of Australia in regard to the continued tenure of Brian Burke as Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See. The fact that Mr Burke remains employed by the Commonwealth of Australia until 31 July is an indictment of the courage of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in refusing to dismiss him for now admitted impropriety and possible illegality and a reflection upon the whole ethos of the Hawke Labor Government in putting cronyism above diplomatic standing.
—I wouldn't go down that track, Senator. You are not too good yourself. The Australian, in the editorial - -

—It is such a shame that Senator Button has also bought into this. I would have thought he would have a higher position on this than his mates. Really, Mr Burke should have gone a long time ago. The honourable senator knows that, we know that and so do the people of Australia and the people of Ireland. It is very sad that he has condoned what his colleagues and the Prime Minister have done. Way back on 19 December last year I raised a number of issues about Mr Burke and the appropriateness of his remaining in the position; yet we were stonewalled then and we are stonewalled now. Over successive weeks of questions on the continued suitability of Mr Burke to remain as Ambassador, I summarised my concerns when speaking on the adjournment. The questions that I raised then--
—I missed that speech.

—It is a real shame that Senator Button missed that, because it was a burster. All of those questions remain unanswered today. The publication of the diaries of the convicted phone tapping investigator, Robert Smith, raised, even then, a serious question as to the high character as ambassador of a person who appeared to have ordered spying on political opponents. Such an action, according to the honourable member for Stirling, would have justified the resignation of a Premier, to say nothing of what should happen to an ambassador. What a pity the Prime Minister and the Foreign Affairs Minister did not share the honourable member's judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, I asked why the Minister for Foreign Affairs did not investigate just who did pay for the dirty tricks campaign and the spying by Mr Smith, if only to assure himself and the Parliament and the people of Australia that one of Australia's diplomats is above and beyond reproach. He has not done that, even today. I also asked why it had been necessary for the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) to be briefed six times in a matter of days by the Australian Federal Police in 1988 about issues concerning phone tapping and the possible connection with Mr Burke. We still have not got an answer to that.

Were the then Attorney-General and the Minister for Foreign Affairs briefed as to the contents of the now famous blue file marked `Government' which was seized from Mr Smith? Why did the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs refuse to obtain an answer as to why all documents taken from Smith on 6 December 1988 were not on the property seizure record? None of these things seems to be important to the Government. It has simply brushed them under the carpet and said, `It does not matter. This is cronyism at its best and we will protect Mr Burke come hell or high water'.

Those were the questions that I asked. No Minister and no member of the Hawke Labor Government has been prepared to answer them. I did not ask about a breach of law at that stage, but it was the business of the Senate to know whether Ministers were aware of possible impropriety by the Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See. The Minister has not made it his business to clarify whether or not there has been any impropriety or illegality. He continues to say that it is rumour and innuendo.

It is not rumour and innuendo. It is now based on the very evidence that Mr Burke himself has provided. But cronyism reigns supreme. Sadly, neither the Minister for Foreign Affairs nor the Prime Minister wished to clarify the position of their little mate, and their little mate rolls on at the taxpayers' expense and to the detriment of the international reputation of Australia. From his answers at the time we can only deduce that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade did not consider political surveillance to be improper. He obviously still does not consider that to be improper.

Therefore, one can only ask: what does he do and what does this Labor Government do about their political opponents? If they do not consider it improper in Western Australia, they probably do not consider it improper anywhere. The answer emerged in the media on 27 February 1991 that the now celebrated leader's account controlled by Mr Burke had been used to pay for the surveillance. While this may not be viewed as illegal, to most people it would surely be seen as highly improper. No answers have been forthcoming from this Government as to any questions. We may have to await further evidence in the Royal Commission.

The publication of the McCusker report on the collapse of Rothwells has raised five specific questions which I posed on 19 December as to the role of Mr Burke and his consequent fitness to serve as Ambassador. Was Mr Burke a de facto director of Rothwells in his last three months as Premier through the appointment of public servants Lloyd and Edwards to the board? Was Mr Burke aware of the memorandum of 13 November 1987 stating that Rothwells was again insolvent? Was Mr Burke instrumental in having another $50m injected into Rothwells on 16 November 1987 through the purchase of Broken Hill Propriety Co. Ltd shares by the State Government Insurance Corporation? Did Mr Burke supply a character reference to the late Bill Burgess as Chairman of Rothwells to allay suspicion by the National Companies and Securities Commission as to the $500m worth of non-performing loans in Rothwells? Did Mr Burke hold out the offer of a senior government position to Mr David Hurley in December 1987 to induce him not to resign as the one Rothwells director with banking credibility? I also asked what knowledge Mr Burke might reasonably have been expected to have of payment of bribes to the Stirling city councillors when his brother, Terry, taped a conversation and his long term adviser, the late Jack Walsh, was involved.

Not only was Mr Burke aware of all of these things, but also so was Senator Beahan. Senator Beahan has sat in here with his lips zipped for so long, knowing full well that he knows that tax was not paid and knowing full well that bribes were given to people to vote in a certain way in a local council decision; but he is not prepared to come out and put the facts straight.

All these questions, based upon substantial evidence, needed to be answered. Presumably, we will have to wait until answers are obtained through the Royal Commission because this Government has been derelict in attempting to have the situation clarified in order to avoid any further international embarrassment. They were questions that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade should have asked an ambassador so implicated, and that should have resulted in that ambassador being stood down until they were refuted. Of course, the Hawke Labor Government was going to protect its mate being warehoused in Ireland prior to resuming a political career.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the Senate will now proceed to matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A matter of public interestwhich I think should be of concern to the nation is that of the future direction of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO). That organisation has been changing direction over the last three or four years and the Opposition has been generally supportive of its new direction. Yesterday in the Senate the annual report of the DSTO Commercial Activities Trust Account was tabled, and I would like to take this brief opportunity to make some comments on the commercialisation of DSTO.

SPEECH.PARA: Although these are still the early days of the commercialisation and new direction of the organisation, valuable progress has already been made. The annual report does not yet give a profit and loss statement, although I understand that will be provided next year. I was particularly interested to study the analysis of the trade debtors as at 30 June last year and to notice that, compared with the previous year, the Government has become a much better payer of its debts. I say this because in 1988-89 debts owing by government to DSTO for 90 days or more totalled nearly $35,000, whereas in 1989-90 debts of 90 days or more were nil. This is certainly a move in the right direction and I hope it is one that will be maintained. In fact, outstanding government debtors had reduced from nearly $138,000 last year to just over $18,500 this year.

By comparison, however, private trade debtors reflected the problems which we are seeing in the wider community. Ninety-day debtors last year were nearly $17,000 and for this year they were up to $83,000. Where private debtors last year were nearly $87,000 in total, that had blown out this year to $244,000. I recognise that there has been greater work done with the private sector this year, but close attention will have to be given to control over debtors in the future.

It is pleasing to see the growth in commercial receipts over the 12 months. In fact, the total commercial receipts doubled over the previous year. Areas of especially good growth were consultancies, which had grown from $117,600 to $290,000, and also testing and analysis, which grew from $69,780 to $495,260. I presume that this will be the trend for the future.

The opportunities available to DSTO are many and varied. They range from some unique capabilities such as wind tunnels and testing facilities for engines, structure and materials, to information technology, special material techniques and testing. Some work being done in the Surveillance Research Laboratory will have a substantial overseas military market, and of particular value should be work being done in infra-red sensor materials. Other commercial opportunities include software applicable to air traffic control, in new computer architecture, and the application of optical fibre technology.

These are exciting areas, and Australia should be proud to have scientists and engineers of the calibre we have, working generally out of sight in DSTO. Unfortunately, over the years, much of their work has not been recognised and in some cases it has even been lost to Australia. That can no longer be allowed to occur. Therefore, it is extremely important that these highly trained and able people have their work translated effectively into benefits for this country. That is why I believe it is so important that we also make sure that we have equally skilled people available to develop and manage the commercial side of the organisation's work.

There are negotiations to be undertaken, joint ventures to be set up, contracts to be written, business plans to be established and intellectual property safeguards to be implemented. There are licences and licensees to be dealt with. Scientists are renowned for not usually being comfortable in these areas. It is absolutely critical that people of a high calibre are available to DSTO to harness the maximum commercial benefit for the organisation from its scientists' and engineers' achievements.

The limitations on the work that can be done are twofold. One is the lack of capital. The cap on funds from DSTO is one per cent of total DSTO funding. There is an urgent need for capital to be supplied by industry partners and, of course, increasingly from ploughing profits back into expansion of the work.

The second limitation is inevitable, and that is that the commercial activity needs to be consistent with defence objectives. There are obviously constraints on what information can go outside the Organisation. Defence work must take priority and our national security and procuring processes must not be jeopardised. Inevitably, we are restricted by the size of our domestic markets and by limitations on defence exports.

It would be a great help if Australian industry were to become more aware of the valuable resource to which it has access in DSTO. Australia could truly be brains driven with more input into industry from the research work done in DSTO. It is my understanding that DSTO is still lagging the field in terms of commercialisation in similar organisations such as the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, and the commercial arm of the AMC.
The achievements during the year are significant and exciting, but I believe they are just a taste, a forerunner, of what can be done by this organisation in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be a bureaucratic problem in part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, can Senator Button not handle the heat in this place?
—I am freezing to death.

—Maybe the honourable senator should start taking an interest in a thing or two. I should like to raise a few matters relating to what has become known as the Meatgate saga. I refer to the situation which has developed in the Harrison inquiry. This has now become a merry-go-round of deception and inconsistency. Unfortunately, I suspect it will end in failure. It is an absolute tragedy for the Australian meat industry and the chances of reform in that industry. Whatever measure we place on it, the cost of our slaughtering and processing is totally uncompetitive when compared with costs in other countries. What has occurred in the last two or three days is indeed unfortunate. We now see that the commitments made by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU) to play the game while the Harrison inquiry was on are once again being totally ignored. We have seen the situation two days ago, I believe, when the AMIEU and the ACTU, with three days of the inquiry left, walked out from the Government's own umpire.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth noting that the inquiry was set up principally at the request of the ACTU and the AMIEU-certainly with a degree of pressure from the ACTU. The inquiry was designed to address the long term structural problems in the meat industry.

I acknowledge the efforts of Minister Cook and congratulate him on trying. He endeavoured, through a very strongly worded letter, to get those parties back into the inquiry. But what have they done? They have just turned up their noses at the Minister and virtually have told him to mind his own business. That is well documented in articles in the Australian today. It is worth looking also at an article in the Australian today, under `Analysis' by Shane Green. I would commend this for reading to all in this place. It is headed `Slaughter of an industry'. It appropriately describes what is happening in the meat industry in this country-an industry that was worth $3 billion of export income to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Including live sheep?
—Yes. I am not arguing that point. It is an industry worth $3 billion. That industry has been totally undermined, as has the live sheep industry, and we need some forwarding thinking--
—Who undermined the live sheep industry?
—The AMIEU has undermined the live sheep industry. It has tried to prevent the export of sheep on a number of occasions, and you know that well, Senator.
—Come on! You dig back in history to suit your argument. You know perfectly well that that is not what has undermined the live sheep industry.

—Through you, Mr Deputy President, I will take that interjection. You were the one, Senator, who introduced that subject of live sheep. You think it is fine for you to introduce it and I am not supposed to respond. It would seem to me that the Minister is treating this subject rather lightly when it is a very serious and important matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Continuing with another undermining that has occurred: we see through the documents that I have here that the deception in Meatgate, through the Victorian Government, has continued. David White, Minister for Manufacturing and Industry Development, has joined that. He has misled the Victorian Parliament in terms of the input of his Department. We see changing stances between the position of the Minister for Labour in Victoria, Mr Pope, and the whole sorry mess of the Harrison meat inquiry continuing to get worse.

We have now seen that extend, once again, into the State of Western Australia, where people at Robbs Jetty, in support of their colleagues in Victoria, took action just last week over structural reforms which occurred over there some five months ago-an absolute nonsense. Of course, when there is some sign of a little bit of recovery in Western Australia-and I emphasise the words `little bit of recovery'-we see that being disrupted through nonsense action.

The real question is: What is the course that is now open? The AMIEU and the ACTU were the ones who requested this inquiry and fought for it. It is an inquiry that has cost, I would suggest, very many millions of dollars. Yet when I asked for the costs of the inquiry at Estimates last week, and what the costs were of the additional hearings because of the abuse to that inquiry, I was told they were not available; you could not get them; they were not recorded. That in itself is a matter of concern. The question we have to ask now is what are the options to overcome the impasse and the wastage occurring in our meat industry.

The only course that is now left open in terms of this latest walk-out, after those millions of dollars have been spent and with just three days to go, is to immediately proceed with the deregistration of the AMIEU and to open up the meat industry and give those people who wish to work the opportunity to do so.

Look at the contempt that has been shown to Commissioner Harrison in this inquiry. His endeavours to get on top of this subject are genuine. He has been undermined firstly by the AMIEU, despite the commitments that were made, and secondly by the performance of the Victorian Government in terms of leaving out crucial statistical data. In response to a question that I asked here some time ago, I acknowledge that in the latest submission that was put by the Commonwealth, which I also have with me, that statistical data was put in there. Now we see that the ACTU, which also made a commitment to that particular inquiry that there would be no disruption during the time of the inquiry, is leading the walk-out.

The only option left is the deregistration of the AMIEU and, as I said, opening up the industry in Australia so that people who wish to work can work. That will enable those who have made a significant investment in the meat industry, in terms of abattoirs and infrastructure to get the product offshore, to get on with the job. The time has come for this Government to join with those employer organisations that are now seeking to have the AMIEU deregistered, as it did with the Builders Labourers Federation in the building industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise the situation of the Australian Capital Territory electricity supply from the Snowy Mountains scheme. It is a matter in which I know the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, has an interest, and I am glad that he is here for this discussion. The ACT has received electricity from the scheme from its beginning and has a very direct interest in a review, currently under way, of the finances and operation of the Snowy Mountains scheme being conducted by representatives of the Commonwealth Government and the New South Wales and Victorian governments. The review was initiated by the Prime Minister in 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this year, I think in February, Senator McMullan, Mr Langmore and I visited the scheme and saw over it so that we had a greater comprehension of what it provides and its importance to this Territory. We get 30 per cent of our electricity from the Snowy Mountains scheme. New South Wales gets 6.3 per cent of its electricity from it and Victoria 3.8 per cent. Those figures indicate the extent to which the ACT has a very legitimate interest in the review which is being undertaken.

The ACT Government should be there too because the power which was provided to the Commonwealth is now provided to the ACT Government. The Chief Minister of the ACT has written to the New South Wales and Victorian governments and to the Prime Minister. He has sent copies of an ACT submission to the inquiry to the New South Wales and Victorian premiers. As I understand it, as of now, there has been no agreement that the ACT has a legitimate place in this inquiry.

What I find most remarkable is that the Prime Minister, having initiated this inquiry in 1989, did not insist at the time that the ACT should be a party to it. The Commonwealth ought to cancel the inquiry and withdraw from it until such time as New South Wales and Victoria agree that we do have a legitimate place at the table of this inquiry. I am at a loss to understand why we have been excluded.

The consequences to the ACT could be an increase of up to 20 per cent in overall electricity costs and it is, of course, for that reason that the representatives elected by this community have expressed an interest in what is going on. The ACT had legally enforceable rights in relation to the Snowy Mountains scheme. The 1973 agreement provided for the Snowy to supply 670 gigawatt hours of electricity, currently at the rate of 3.5c a kilowatt. The New South Wales Electricity Commission charges 6.9c a kilowatt for power delivered to the ACT Electricity and Water Authority. As a result of this review, the ACT may have to relinquish its entitlement to the cheaper electricity and purchase from New South Wales at a greater cost.

How can anybody deny that the ACT has a legitimate interest in the review? I am inclined to wonder why the Prime Minister set it up and how it is that he was advised to do so without the ACT Government being present. There are a number of aspects to the way the Commonwealth has treated the ACT in financial matters since the ACT obtained self-government that are worthy of comment, but in the interests of the bipartisan way that this matter has been treated to date by Senator McMullan, Mr Langmore and myself, I shall not reiterate them today. I have dealt with them previously.

We three, having returned from a visit to the scheme, wrote to the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) on 4 March. I should say that Senator McMullan wrote the letter and Mr Langmore and I signed it. We told him that we had enjoyed the inspection of the scheme and had benefited from the understanding of it which we obtained. We said:

We are most concerned to learn that the Australian Capital Territory has been excluded from participation in the panel (the Commonwealth and the states of Victoria and New South Wales) reviewing the financial and institutional arrangements of the Scheme.

The letter went on to point out the amount of electricity we received from the scheme and how much greater the impact of a change would be on the ACT than on the other two States involved. We said to the Minister:

Now that the ACT is a self-governing territory, we find it inconceivable that it is not represented, in its own right, at negotiations that have the potential to force ACT total electricity costs up by as much as 20 per cent.

We pointed out to him the effect that this would have on our constituents and on the commercial and industrial development within the Territory. To my knowledge, the Minister has not provided us with a reply to that letter. That is surprising seeing that it is dated 4 March, and I am very disappointed that that is the case. I raise this matter in the bipartisan way that we have proceeded with it so far because our constituents and the commercial viability of Canberra depend on getting electricity and the sort of increase which may flow from this would be quite disastrous to our local economy.

The Chief Minister has not been able to get a response. I do not know that the Prime Minister has given any explanation as to why he initiated an inquiry which excluded us and I think the time has come for us to speak up and ask the Government to make a statement as to why the matter is being dealt with in the manner that it is and why it is that we are not getting answers to the correspondence which has been written about a very legitimate matter of concern to constituents and business in the ACT.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The subject I want to speak on in this matters of public interest discussion is a bit of a smelly one, I guess. It relates to the export, or potential export, of seaweed from Australia to South East Asian markets. One of my constituents, an entrepreneurial Western Australian, has to help overcome what has been in recent years a terrible fall in the reputation of that class of people from Western Australia. Of course, Western Australia has been renowned for producing innovative and entrepreneurial types. The tyranny of distance ensures that Western Australians, both in politics and in business, are innovators and entrepreneurs and often do things in that remote environment which produce great benefits for the whole of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important at this time in Australia's economy, when we are in this very deep recession and also when there has been so much focus on problems in Western Australia and on the businessmen of Western Australia, that we focus on some positives. There are people like Ralph Sarich who continues with thedevelopment of his engine and his fuel injection system, which in the long term will produce income for Australia.

The person I want to talk about today has a proposal before the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service to export seaweed to established markets-markets he has firm orders from-in Japan and other South East Asian countries. The story I want to relate is, in a micro-sense, very comparable to the continuing debate over the mining of Coronation Hill. The gentleman I refer to, my constituent Mr John Horobin, has been seeking for a number of years to work his way through the mire of red tape and government bureaucracy with his proposal to harvest seaweed from the Swan River particularly, and the Peel and Harvey estuaries, broadly speaking, have it dried and then exported to South East Asia.

One could imagine that a proposal such as that would be fraught with all sorts of dangers, when we think of the myriad environmental concerns such a proposal would cause. Basically, the proposal simply seeks to extract seaweed, particularly from the Swan River, which has already broken away from the ground and more often than not floats up onto the beaches of the Swan River. I guess SenatorMcMullan would be familiar with these beaches from his younger days. The seaweed would then be dried on racks in a fairly prehistoric way, put into plastic bags and sold to the Japanese.

Australia had an export market in seaweed in years past-there are documented figures on the tonnages and so forth-but export has waned over the years. There is a very clear demand for it and for the product known as gracilaria, which is used to make a product called algar which can be used in a number of downstream processes, such as pharmaceutical uses and food uses. It can also be used in the plastic industries. It is a product which has relevance to the manufacture of microchips and other high-tech substances. It makes the mind boggle to think of sea weed coming out of the Swan River and ending up in a microchip in a complicated computer, but so be it.

The problem that Mr Horobin and his company have is that they had to fight over the years to get the relevant approvals from State and local authorities, but that has now been achieved after their battle. He has an approval from the Waterways Commission in Western Australia which basically allows him, almost on a pilot basis, to take the broken away seaweed from the shallows by hand. This is a fairly low-tech way of harvesting the seaweed. In the long term, Mr Horobin would envisage having some sort of mechanical harvesting. He recognises the potential environmental impacts and wants to start off on a small scale and then allow the various authorities-local, State and Federal-to monitor the effects on the environment.

This proposal is now before the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. Mr Horobin is seeking an export licence under the relevant Act, the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982. It was referred to that Service many months ago. He has had correspondence with the Service and has sought further information. That information has been supplied; indeed, the latest submission that Mr Horobin has made to the Service has been sitting in the intray of that bureaucracy for a number of months without even a recognition or any sort of response whatsoever. Mr Horobin has made repeated calls to the Service, seeking to have some sort of answer. Like so many struggling small business people, he has become frustrated with the red tape he has to go through to get what would seem to be a very positive industry which will employ many young Western Australians and produce export income for Australia-from a product which is at the moment taken out of the Swan River as a form of pollution, at great cost to the relevant authorities, and dumped in tip sites around Perth.

In other words, we have a product here which is a form of pollution, which is extracted at great expense, which Mr Horobin, through his process and through employing young Western Australians, can extract, process and export and thus earn export income. He already has letters of intent, in fact firm contracts, with some companies in South East Asia to export it. The problem that he is now faced with is in dealing with the Federal bureaucracy, which is thousands of kilometres away from where he is trying to get this activity off the ground.

The bureaucracy's recognition of the urgency of the matter is obviously a low priority. A bureaucrat sitting in Canberra does not have to feed that man's wife and family. A bureaucrat sitting in Canberra does not really have to worry about whether he deals with the submission from Mr Horobin today, tomorrow, next month, or next year. But to young Western Australians, of whom nearly one in three, and one in four in some areas, are out of work, it does matter. I think a new sunrise industry such as seaweed export would be a very positive occurrence for those young people. It would give them some hope for the future.

The point I wish to make is that clearly, as is the case with Coronation Hill and so many other resource projects, we have here a micro-example of the problems that always face Australian business people who want to exploit Australia's natural resources. We have an approval process which discourages people from even getting to first base. This gentleman has been waiting for years to get this industry off the ground. After finally getting approval in principle from the relevant authorities in Western Australia, he is now faced with telephoning the National Parks and Wildlife Service in Canberra to try to move his application up the in-tray of the particular bureaucrat who is handling it. I certainly hope that the department responsible will consider this proposal expeditiously.

Recently there has been some focus on the problems of the Swan River. It has a nutrient problem which the State Minister, Ernie Bridge, believes comes from all the septic tanks around Perth but clearly it also comes from the non-point of source pollution from fertilisers in the Avon Valley. Part of the effect of that nutrient problem is, of course, that seaweed and kelp in the Swan River are growing at rates much higher than would normally occur without those nutrients. Mr Horobin's proposal has the side benefit of enabling us to remove some of that seaweed and, I guess, allowing new seaweed to propagate and soak up some of thosenutrients in the Swan River. I think the proposal has merit.

The question I ask in this matter of public interest is this: how far does someone like Mr Horobin have to go to get what seems to be a very sensible, small business idea off the ground? Most Australians would have given up months or years ago and would not have been so tenacious in moving their proposals forward. I commend his proposal to the Senate. I encourage the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service to expedite the consideration and approval of Mr Horobin's proposal.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That the sitting of the Senate be suspended till 2 p.m.
Sitting suspended from 1.19 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. How much worse does he expect unemployment to get in Australia following today's appalling unemployment figures which reveal a 322,100 or 60 per cent increase in the number of Australians out of work-the biggest ever 12 months increase in unemployment-lifting the adult unemployment rate to 10.2 per cent and the youth unemployment rate to the worst ever April level of 25.8 per cent, worse than one in four? Does the Minister now accept that the Government has made serious mistakes in its economic policy?
