ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two parts to that question, apart from the rhetorical recitation of figures. The first asks me to make a forecast about unemployment, and I have continually declined to do that. The unemployment figures in terms of the recession are always lagged figures, and Ministers, including myself, have said for some time that we anticipate unemployment figures remaining and continuing high even though some other signs of the recession bottoming out might become apparent.

ANSWER.PARA: The other part of the question relates to whether the Government admits, or I admit, that it has made serious economic mistakes. I think the question was couched in those terms. I have said on previous occasions that the Government recognises and very much regrets the disadvantages that have been caused to so many people as a result of high levels of unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bit late to be apologetic now.

—I am trying to answer a serious question, not indulge in point scoring. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer on several occasions have made statements about the misjudgment in the fundamental indicators of the Australian economy in terms of the recession. On the advice that was given at the time to the Government, which was being tendered by a great variety of people, the Government's actions were correct and not dissented from by the Opposition.
—Our policy was totally different.

—Is that right? The Opposition's policy is totally different. I remember: the Opposition was going to lower interest rates with a magic wand at the time of the last election. That was when the Opposition was trying Mr Peacock for the second time and was going to lower interest rates with a magic wand. I remember all of that; I have not forgotten.

ANSWER.PARA: There are a number of factors which are contributing, apart from any blame which may attach to the Government in terms of the domestic recession, to labour market conditions. Not only is there the question of the health of the Australian economy, to which I have referred, but also there is a major slowdown in the growth of other world economies. There are also very depressed market conditions affecting many rural industries. A combination of factors is contributing to the present situation. In answer to the second part of the honourable senator's question, that is all I am prepared to say. In answer to the first part of the question, I will not indulge in forecasting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for that answer and I note that he said `apart from any blame which may attach to the Government'. I now invite him to tell the Senate what blame the Government should attract. Secondly, I ask: will he stand by Mr Hawke's unaltered forecast that unemployment would not reach 10 per cent, or does he recommend a change to that?

—I have already answered the first part of the question and I do not intend to indulge Senator Baume with a further answer. In respect of the second part of the question, I do not know when that forecast was made. I would not say with any confidence that unemployment in this country could not reach 10 per cent, based on today's figure.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has his attention been drawn to a statement by the Australian Democrats spokesperson on industrial relations concerning the right to strike in Australia? Does this statement propose that the Government legislate for the right to strike and suggest that, if the Government does not appear serious about it, the Democrats will do the job instead? Can the Minister advise honourable senators what the Government's reaction is to this Democrat proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a copy of a media release under the title of Senator Paul McLean, the Australian Democrats spokesperson on industrial relations, dated yesterday and headed, `Democrats challenge Government to legislate ``right to strike'' now'. According to this press release, the Democrats are proposing that, if the Government does not move on this fundamental issue, they will introduce legislation in the autumn session of Parliament and that that legislation will deal with issues such as sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act.

ANSWER.PARA: I am asked by Senator Sherry what my attitude to this statement is. I am pleased to see that the Democrats have given, as I understand it, quite a deal of detailed consideration and analysis to this issue. As I have said, it is a fundamental issue in industrial relations in Australia.

As for what the Government will do, I have in recent days often stated the position of the Government. The Government's position is that we resumed our review of the Industrial Relations Act in January this year. Last year in the Senate we enacted some amendments to the Industrial Relations Act on union amalgamations. In January this year we resumed our review of the balance of the Act. That review was being conducted by the industrial legislation subcommittee of the National Labour Consultative Council (NLCC). I remind honourable senators that the NLCC is a tripartite body of employers, unions and the Government. That subcommittee is examining all of the other proposed amendments to the Industrial Relations Act. Some of those amendments go to the issue that the Democrats press release has referred to and to other issues, such as legal framework.

I welcome the entry into this debate of the Australian Democrats and the way in which they have done so. The Government is committed to tripartite decision-making, and we will see through the discussion in the NLCC without making any pre-emptive undertakings. We would like the social partners-the employers and the unions-to examine and come to a consensus, if at all possible, on this matter. We will see that process through, and when it has culminated I will be in a position to say what the Government is likely to do.

Earlier this year the United Nations industrial relations agency, the International Labour Organisation (ILO), under the freedom of association laws, had the matter of the air pilots dispute in Australia in 1989 referred to it. While its finding exonerated the Government from any breach of freedom of association legislation-and that was endorsed by the United Nations body-it did say that there was a significant question of the state of labour law in Australia regarding the right to strike. It referred that question to its standing committee of experts for consideration.

When that report has been finally approved by the ILO, we will have an expression from that United Nations agency on its views of the state of labour law in Australia. Along with the Democrats intervention in this matter, that will be a significant contribution to forming what I hope will be a generally consensual view in the community about what we should do on these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is it the case that he has asked his Department to examine the need for a new code of conduct for ambassadors? Just because one of the Government's political appointments has behaved in an improper way, why is it necessary to tarnish all former and current professional officers with his misbehaviour and the Minister's failure to remove him from office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one is tarnished by a code of conduct relating to his behaviour any more than public servants in the whole Public Service system are tarnished by the existence of Public Service guidelines and their liability to observe the standards of behaviour that are applicable under the Bowen Committee's code of conduct. The point simply was that it became apparent, as we were looking at some of these things for the first time in the context of a certain matter, that these other provisions-the Bowen Committee code of conduct with its pecuniary interest declaration and so on, and the Public Service guidelines applicable to such things as political activity-were not formally applicable to ambassadors, simply because of the nature of ambassadorial appointments, terms and conditions, arrangements that govern those appointments and their distancing from the rest of the Public Service system. In the first instance, it was simply a matter of formalising and making appropriate adjustments for all those other provisions as they relate to ambassadors.

ANSWER.PARA: Furthermore, since the question of political appointments will no doubt continue to arise from time to time because that has been quite common throughout the whole history of diplomacy in this country on both sides of the Parliament, it did seem appropriate to pay some attention to particular issues that might arise in the context of political appointments in the future; just to ensure that the ground rules were perfectly clear perhaps to a greater extent than was the case on this occasion. There is no hint or suggestion in any of this that anyone is particularly in need of closer instruction in this respect. It is just a natural thing to attend to in the aftermath of issues coming to light in the way they have.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister not then realise that to start talking about codes of conduct for ambassadors at a time like this indicates appallingly clumsy timing? If his explanation is in fact genuine, he should do it at an appropriately neutral time and not at a time which heaps insult on all former and current officers.
—The only insult involved in any of this is to the intelligence of the Senate with a piece of nonsense of that kind coming from Senator Reid.

—Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen recent newspaper reports of comments made by the Director of the South Australian Department of Industry, Trade and Technology, Dr Peter Crawford? Dr Crawford is saying that manufacturing companies must band together to compete in international markets. In light of the importance of improving Australia's competitive position internationally, can the Minister inform the Senate of initiatives taken by the Government to promote networking by companies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see Dr Crawford's comments, which are not a revelation to me. In an economy of this size the more that companies cooperate in seeking international markets the better. But in terms of Senator Schacht's question as to how the Government views this, I point out that Dr Crawford was in fact speaking in a seminar organised by the Australian Manufacturing Council; a seminar which is also supported by my Department.

ANSWER.PARA: This was one of a number of seminars held around the country in the past two weeks on networking or the process of building relationships between firms to improve competitive capabilities in both the domestic and export markets. The reason is that in world terms many Australian companies are too small to compete. Companies which get together and network will often be better able to take advantage of the opportunities in the international marketplace. Enterprises which form strategic networks and joint ventures with other complementary companies can collectively break into key markets. To assist this the National Industry Extension Service (NIES) has been piloting a range of enterprise network approaches. These pilot projects are identifying successful models and looking at what makes them work.

The Australian Manufacturing Council, supported by NIES, organised seminars on networking in Adelaide, Sydney, Queensland, Melbourne and Perth in response to growing interest from manufacturers and State governments. There will be another seminar in Hobart next month. More than 120 people were involved in the Melbourne seminar and about 80 people were at some of the others. The President of the United States Garment Industry Development Corporation came to Australia to speak at the seminars and a number of highly qualified people participated in them. I think that these seminars have proved such a success that they will probably be an ongoing activity. It is a pity that it is necessary for governments to sponsor them, but we will continue to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the Minister to a report in the Adelaide Advertiser of Tuesday, 7 May. In that report, which was headlined `Bannon Snubs Farmers', the South Australian Finance Minister is quoted as saying that two-thirds of South Australian steelworkers had been forced to leave their industry and the State's farmers had to be prepared to do the same. I ask the Minister: is this the secret of Labor's economic employment and rural policies? In other words, because this Government has destroyed the job prospects of two-thirds of South Australian steelworkers, does it intend to visit similar destruction upon Australia's farmers, as is evidenced by today's unemployment figures?

—I did not listen to the question because I thought that it was directed to Senator Button. In the circumstances, since it was a question to me and I did not hear it, I wonder whether Senator Bell would be good enough to give it to me and I will obtain a reply for him at the end of Question Time.

—I did direct the question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The Minister acknowledged me by looking at me and listening to the question. Is he trying to evade the question?

—Order! The question was clearly asked of the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. That is what I heard and I called Senator Cook and he said that he will obtain a reply at a later time.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. In the Minister's statement to the House on 12 March this year reference was made to the need for Australia to lift its exports of high value added goods and services and to participate in the fastest growing sectors of world trade. In light of this, can the Minister outline to the Senate the prospects for Australia's participation in the information technology software and services areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall that I did say something like that on 12 March; it seems a long time ago. This country is well placed to take advantage of growth in this market segment. In 1989-90, we exported $260m worth of software and another $260m in information technology (IT) services, which is helping to turn around the balance of trade in the information technology figures. I believe that we will see much improvement in this export trade in the next few years.

ANSWER.PARA: High quality innovative Australian companies, such as Computer Power Pty Ltd, Aspect Computing Pty Ltd, the Co-Cam Computer Group, Ferntree Computer Corporation Ltd, Moldflow Pty Ltd and the Paxus Corporation, are all out in the international marketplace marketing skills in this area. I do not want to mention particular companies at length, but, for example, Computer Power is now a world leading software products and services company with a turnover of over $250m a year and has more than 100 offices around the world.

IBM Australia Ltd has been a considerable contributor to this export activity. Its programming centre last year exported some $57m worth of software. In that centre it employs 155 IBM staff and engages 320 contractors.

Growth of IT, however, depends on the ability of firms to meet the quality control and design standards demanded by the international marketplace. That is where our transnational partners in Australia are playing a valuable role. It is an area in which the Government recognises there needs to be further collaborative work between governments and companies of that kind. That is why the vendor qualification scheme is being extended for a further three years and now covers software companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the emphasis placed on departmental advice by the Minister and the Prime Minister in justifying the Government's stand on ex-Ambassador Burke continuing in his role as Australia's representative to Ireland and the Holy See and the Minister's assurance yesterday that he `would be prepared to table all sorts of things', will he table all the departmental advice received on the subject?
—Not without a much more specific request than that.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Yesterday Senator Evans said that he would table anything that we wanted to ask for. We are now asking for all the advice on this subject.

—If I was asked intelligently in a way that would do justice to the seriousness of the case and not in a flippant, insubstantial, general all-purpose trawling expedition of that kind, of course I would be responsive.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MARRIAGE COUNSELLING, EDUCATION AND FAMILY MEDIATION SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs detail new services established with the $15m promised by the Prime Minister last year for extending marriage counselling, education and family mediation services? How will these services be fully decentralised to maximise their benefit around Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Reynolds for her question, which obviously comes from her association with the provision of services to the rural and provincial areas of Australia, particularly in north Queensland. It is a fact that the Prime Minister, in his statement on 8 March last year, announced an increase of around $15m over three years to assist marriages and promote family stability. I believe that the provision of family counselling, marriage education and mediation services to those underserviced areas of rural and provincial Australia will be a fulfilment of that undertaking.

ANSWER.PARA: In particular, we are trying to ensure that disadvantaged families in those non-metropolitan areas of Australia do obtain access to these services in a way which those in the suburban and metropolitan areas take for granted. We will certainly ensure that that occurs. In particular, I have asked for submissions from the peak organisations of the family counselling and other like organisations Australia-wide with regard to the provision of these services. I believe that the encouragement and fostering of good relationships between the Department and these peak organisations has been very fruitful in bringing forward submissions which I am sure will help to fulfil our objectives. Indeed, the relationships between the peak organisations themselves-which have been fostered in the past year or so-will, I am sure, lead to the provision of services in those rural and provincial areas of Australia which will well serve the people in those areas.

In relation to marriage counselling, that is well understood. But the major effort at the moment is to provide mediation services for separating couples because, quite clearly, if a traumatic dispute over custody of children or property can be resolved without a court-imposed solution-where the people in dispute are brought together by a neutral mediator in a way which allows them to devise their own solution to the property or custody disputes-then that is likely to be a more enduring solution. It will certainly reduce the trauma associated with the break-up of a marriage. Of course, it will also reduce the legal costs, which can be very burdensome for those people involved in this process.

Senator Reynolds will be pleased to know that, not only in north Queensland but also in other areas of Australia which are outside the major metropolitan areas, these services will be provided in a way which I believe fulfils the undertaking of the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask whether the Government intends to stand by its intention to pay $28,000 to Mr Burke as a so-called termination payment. If so, in light of the Minister's argument of yesterday that the payment was lawful by reason of, firstly, the authority conferred upon the Minister by the Governor-General to determine the terms and conditions of Mr Burke's employment and, secondly, clause N of Mr Burke's written contract of employment dated 20 July 1988, and noting in passing that the preamble to Mr Burke's contract of employment states that the terms and conditions contained therein are made pursuant to an approval by the Governor-General of Mr Burke's appointment-such approval being dated 9 March 1988-will the Minister now advise the Senate whether the authority conferred upon him by the Governor-General is an authority to determine the terms and conditions of Mr Burke's employment at the time of his appointment, or does the authority confer a power to vary, alter or add to those terms at any subsequent time? Is the authority contained within a written instrument? If so, can the Minister table the written instrument? Having regard to clause N of the contract, what specific provision of the Public Service rules, or what reserved power of the Department of Industrial Relations, is relied upon to support the payment? Finally, will the Minister table the advice from the Attorney-General's Department to which he referred in his answer yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I have all of those things written down. It is certainly my understanding that the authority of the Governor-General of 9 March 1988 to Mr Hayden, whose successor I am as Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, is such as to confer a right upon me-the Foreign Minister-not only to determine terms and conditions at the outset of a period of office, but also to vary or add to those conditions as appropriate at any time while Mr Burke continues to hold the position in question. I think that is a fair reading of the language of the instrument, which I will table if it has not been already-I do not think it has been tabled in the Parliament-and it is also a straightforward application of first principles that govern these things, which I am sure a court would have no difficulty in construing that way.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked for the advice from the Attorney-General's Department. That is in the form of a short question briefing note to the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, and I table that as requested.

As to the basis in the terms and conditions document itself-it is not a contract; it is a determination of terms and conditions that govern these things-I do not rely on anything in paragraph N that is vested in the rules applicable in respect of officers of the Public Service which are subject to administration by the Department of Industrial Relations. I rely, rather, on the general residual power that exists in that particular clause to make determinations leaving aside the context of matters which are within the scope of the normal Public Service guidelines-in which case I am exercising the authority that would normally be exercised by the Minister for Industrial Relations. Those situations apart, there is a residual capacity to otherwise determine matters. So that is the particular phrase I am relying upon there. That is, in effect, as was set out in the advice from my Department and that is, again, perfectly straightforward.

As to the termination payment-its status now in the context of the resignation being brought forward-that termination payment will continue to be made and it will be varied slightly in accordance with exactly the same formula being applicable. It will now be equivalent to 18 weeks and five days salary; that is to say, on the same pro rata basis as was originally determined on 31 July, but going through to the period ending 5 June 1992.

I point out that the extra four weeks salary Mr Burke would get under this is just one-third of the payment he would have received had he stayed in office until 31 July. I point that out in case Opposition senators are unable to follow the arithmetic of these things-I thought I would do it for them. And it is exactly what Mr Burke would have got if he had been dismissed today.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the large number of Australians of Yugoslav origin and recent press reports of possible army intervention in that country, what is the Australian Government's reaction and response to the continuing tension in Yugoslavia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like everybody else, the Australian Government is becoming increasingly concerned about the deteriorating situation in Yugoslavia. The incidents of violence, which before this month were of a sporadic and isolated nature, are now becoming more frequent and widespread. A very serious incident occurred in the Croatian town of Borovo Selo where at least 15 people, including 12 Croatian policemen, were killed in a gun battle.

ANSWER.PARA: The Yugoslav National Army, as most honourable senators would have seen from the press, is now moving to take up positions in the areas of greatest tension. But it is not clear that this is going to have a calming effect. Indeed, some fear that the Army's presence may provoke further violence. Yugoslavia is, of course, a federation comprising six republics, some of which are calling for the establishment of a looser confederal structure and are threatening to secede if no new arrangement can be negotiated. Members of the Federal Presidency are continuing to meet in emergency sessions to try to resolve Yugoslavia's problems, so far without conspicuous success.

On behalf of the Australian Government, while recognising that it is, of course, up to the Yugoslav people to decide their own future political organisation, I nonetheless call upon them in the strongest possible terms for the solution to Yugoslavia's problems to be achieved through peaceful and democratic means. We say this not only as a fellow member of the international community but also as the adopted home of hundreds of thousands of Australians of Yugoslav origin who are watching developments in Yugoslavia with mounting anxiety.

In view of the recent deterioration in the situation in Yugoslavia, I should say that my Department is now advising people to defer non-essential travel to Yugoslavia. This travel advisory will be kept under daily review.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EVALUATION OF TENDERS FOR COMPUTER CONSUMABLES

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to his interview with Paul Lyneham on Monday, 6 May in regard to his improper intervention in a contract for computer consumables in which Mr Lyneham said:

QUESTION.PARA: You have had; or they (Department) have had, an independent internal inquiry that says basically you were right and they were wrong--

That is a statement, I must say, which the Minister supported. Is it a fact that the independent review team, as indicated in the documents tabled yesterday, rejected the Minister's directive to reinstate an unsuccessful tenderer on the contract and recommended that `the arrangement should stand as is' because overturning a contract on the protest of a losing bidder `would tend to bring the purchasing process into disrepute and invite protest on every occasion'? Why did the Minister deliberately mislead the Australian public through the 7.30 Report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that there is a degree of sour grapes in that question. If I could give Senator Parer some advice--
—Just answer the question.

—Senator Parer is flogging a dead horse here. The reality is-I will give Senator Parer a full and comprehensive answer if he will wait-that I was motivated in this matter, unlike Senator Parer's colleagues in Queensland, to ensure that we got three objectives: one, a fair tendering process; two, value for money for the taxpayer; and, three, that Australian suppliers not be disadvantaged. They have been the three motivations, which at the end of this process have been vindicated. They have been my guiding motivations at all times, and at the end of the day we have been vindicated.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Parer has put to me part of an interview with Paul Lyneham. He quotes from the review team's report, claiming that the Australian public have been mislead. He knows full well-it was explained to him quite well, but I have been noting his actions consistently; I can see why he is no longer in the private sector and is now sitting there with his colleagues-that the reality is that that review team was reporting to my departmental officers. Those departmental officers met with me. I will quote to Senator Parer in full their advice to me. When I talk about departmental officers, I mean the Secretary to the Department, the Executive General Manager, Government and Corporate Services Program and the Executive General Manager, Supply Services. They said:

Maintaining the status quo is not appropriate. Our review has pointed to some major deficiencies in the process. Whilst there is no suggestion of bias in the process, by not deciding and notifying in advance the criterion to be used and the relative weights that might be applied in the evaluation, potential bidders did not know clearly and consistently how the evaluation process was to be conducted. This could have affected their price offering. Furthermore, the application of the basket approach which was applied in this case does not give best `value for money' in every case.
They then went through a number of options. I repeat: they said, `Maintaining the status quo is not appropriate'.

Senator Parer makes some point about the Paul Lyneham report. I answered a question the other day from Senator Parer, a question to which I was keen to give a full and adequate answer. Senator Parer may not remember that answer. It was two days ago, so I will make a concession for him. But, in the context of that answer, I said:

. . . importantly, the review team reported to the Secretary that, although these problems had occurred, it did not believe that the value of correcting the deficiencies warranted cancelling the contract.

I made that very clear at the start two days ago when Senator Parer asked his first question on this matter. He should not accuse me of misleading the public; he is the one who is doing that. I also went on to say:
The Secretary and other senior officers considered this advice and, on their own assessment, advised me that leaving the matter as it was, taking the `do nothing' option, was inappropriate.

If Senator Parer wants to come in here and ask a question or make some points, he should get his facts right. He should not accuse me of misleading the public when he is the one who has this inherent incapacity to get it straight.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. How can the Minister reconcile the fact that in briefing Mr Lyneham, he told him that the Department had held an independent internal inquiry which found, basically, that he was right and it was wrong? I refer the Minister to what the internal independent inquiry said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the arrangement should stand as it is ``because overturning a contract-
and, I might say, simply because of representations made to the Minister-
. . . on the protest of a losing bidder would bring the . . . process into disrepute . . .

I repeat the question: why did the Minister deliberately mislead Mr Lyneham and the Australian public through the 7.30 Report? Is this why he now wishes to ban political advertising-so that the public can rely on this sort of misleading information gained through public affairs programs?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I really think that was the same question as was originally asked. The Minister can answer if he wishes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that the best way to respond to Senator Parer is not to say anything further, but let me make a couple of points with respect to the supplementary question. First of all, it was Senator Parer and Senator Hill who came in here yesterday and accused me of giving the interim report of the review team to Mr Lyneham. Had that been right, then I presume that Mr Lyneham would not have made such a mistake.

ANSWER.PARA: Those senators have come in here today and taken completely the opposite point of view. They have said that I completely misled him by maybe not giving him the report. Firstly, they should get it right. Secondly, the relevant section of Paul Lyneham's interview states:

And now you've had--or they've had an independent internal inquiry that says basically you were right and they were wrong. How independent was this? I mean, any ministerial fingerprints on it anywhere?
I then say:

Well, let me say the matter was brought to the attention of the Secretary, and Deputy Secretaries involved. They went through it with me very exhaustively and I think they felt very strongly that, in fact I'm sure they felt very strongly, independently of any view that I might have had, that the process really had to be looked at. That led to the review team, was set up by the departmental Secretary and I think it's fair to say that . . .

In response to Mr Lyneham I said that it was a departmental secretary and senior officers who discussed it with me. They are the ones who put a view to me. There is nothing inconsistent with what I said to Mr Lyneham and what is shown up in the document received yesterday. Senator Parer should get it right for once and stop wasting the time of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I ask: at what stage is the draft of Australia's national report on environment and development issues which is to be submitted to the 1992 United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (UNCED)? I further ask whether the Minister is aware that the international organisation of Parliamentarians for Global Action, in recognition of the importance of the national report and the fact that it constitutes a political statement as well as background information for the UNCED secretariat, has urged all governments to submit their national environment reports to their parliaments for full parliamentary debate and discussion prior to submission to UNCED? Finally, I ask the Minister whether the report will be tabled in both Houses of Parliament to allow honourable senators and honourable members the opportunity to review and debate its content before a final report is prepared.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian national report for the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development is currently in preparation. I understand that a first draft of that report, based on the initial contribution of government departments and agencies and non-government organisations, will be distributed to interested agencies, State governments and NGOs for comment and further contributions later this month. The report will provide basic background information on Australian environmental and development policies. All participating countries in this conference are preparing national reports and together these will be used to assess areas of need and priority in global environment and development programs. National reports are to be lodged with the conference secretariat by the end of July this year and would form part of the background material for further preparations for the earth summit in Rio de Janeiro in June 1992.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister is aware that Parliamentarians for Global Action has urged all governments to submit their national reports to parliament prior to submission to the conference. The Minister has yet to decide whether such a course is possible, given the tight deadline for submission and the parliamentary program over the next few months. Nonetheless, both the draft and final reports will be public documents and comments on the draft will be sought from all sectors of the community.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EVALUATION OF TENDERS FOR COMPUTER CONSUMABLES

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Administrative Services. I, too, refer the Minister to the documents that he tabled yesterday in regard to the circumstances surrounding the interference to the tender for computer consumables. On 8 April the Minister made a notation on the departmental minute of 14 March 1991 instructing, `The initial decision stands and I want it urgently acted upon'. I presume we can take that as being correct. How does the Minister reconcile that with his statement to Senator Parer in the Estimates Committee hearing 10 days later, on 18 April, when he refused to answer further questions by claiming, `This matter is still under consideration by myself and officers of the Department'?
—That is a tricky one.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very easy. Let me tackle the first point, which is interference. Let us get the matter straight. I am the Minister for Administrative Services. I have responsibility over the Department. I have a responsibility to ensure that the Department acts properly and gets it right. To this extent, I got involved in this matter. I shall again tell honourable senators that, if the same circumstances arose, I would get involved again. There would be absolutely no doubt about that.

ANSWER.PARA: The two outcomes that have been achieved by my intervention in this matter are these: first of all, an Australian supplier, entitled to get the Australian Made logo and to use it, has not been disadvantaged; and, secondly, the Australian taxpayer will receive the benefit of an expanded list of cheaper tenders because of my intervention. Get that straight. On that minute I did in fact say, `Act on the direction'. That direction was for the Department to reconsider. My view was quite clearly that the reconsideration was inadequate.
Opposition members-Not so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not so, they say. They act on the basis of one part of one selectively leaked document, and that is what they have been motivated by all along. We have had a continual number of contacts between my officers and the Department, verbal and otherwise. Very soon after that minute went over we organised for a meeting to take place. That meeting finally took place a few days after we had initially intended, but it had been planned. As the honourable senator said, the minute was sent back on 8 April. A couple of days later the Department spoke to one of my staff. A meeting was then organised and it took place thereafter. The meeting was organised before the Estimates Committee on 18 April and it took place on either 19 April or 23 April. That is why I can say quite clearly and easily that the matter was still under discussion.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister has failed to cover the point that, 10 days after he gave the instruction that he wanted this acted upon, he was still advising in the Estimates Committee that the matter was still under consideration. One or other of his statements is patently incorrect. Was the Minister telling the truth at the Estimates Committee or was this document fictitiously put together prior to that?
—We seem to have the poor man's Perry Mason over there. I have already answered the question pretty well, thank you.

—I refer the Minister for Social Security to the recent statement of Bishop Michael Challen of the Brotherhood of St Laurence that the reason many of the 4,809 people assisted by the Brotherhood in the first three months of this year sought help was that they were `waiting to qualify for a social security payment or because the payment they receive is insufficient to pay the rent and buy food and clothing'. I ask the Minister: firstly, does he acknowledge the immense hardship being caused by this Government's extension of waiting and deferment periods for social security benefits? Secondly, in view of today's horrific unemployment figures, will the Government take immediate steps to reduce the waiting and deferment periods, to ensure that those people who are the innocent victims of the Government's engineered recession will receive their payments as soon as they need help and do not have to resort to reliance on welfare agencies? Finally, if not, what does the Minister suggest these people do to survive during the waiting periods?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that there are hardships involved for many people in Australia at the moment. Obviously, when one is unemployed, life is not a bed of roses. In relation to waiting periods, it must be remembered that the Department has hardship provisions, which are often used. I shall seek some figures for Senator Lees on how many people take advantage of those hardship provisions, which can, of course, mean a shortening of those waiting periods. These hardship provisions are not used sparingly by the Department. When people demonstrate genuine need, the Department acts quickly.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the honourable member's question about how people survive during the waiting periods, I point out that the waiting periods, such as those established for people with cash in the bank, for instance, are there because the Government believes that if people have sufficient resources they can for a limited period look after themselves. At the moment I am looking at the question of waiting periods in general for the preparation of a Budget submission. Over the next few months the Government will, no doubt, have some discussions about them.

I caution Senator Lees and, indeed, the Brotherhood of St Laurence on that point. It is the operation of hardship provisions that eases hardship for many people who are having problems with waiting periods. It is not simply a matter of looking at the length of the waiting period and assuming that every person is affected by it. That is not the way it works in practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I draw the Minister's attention in particular to the wait of 13 weeks or three months that young people have to go through when leaving education. Are they always advised that there is a hardship provision and told how they can apply?

—It is not true to say that everyone is always advised, but those who express to Social Security officers that they have a problem are advised that they can apply under hardship provisions. It depends upon the attitude of the person coming in. Many of them do not object and do not claim and, of course, would find it very difficult to claim that there was a hardship for them, but those who do say that there is hardship are told how to exercise their rights.

—I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the recent recommendation of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission that the Government should convene a national conference on superannuation and retirement incomes. Will the Government convene such a conference; if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The recommendation referred to by Senator Alston was contained in the national wage case decision brought down by the Commission towards the end of April. The Senate will be aware that the Government submission to the national wage case sought the Bench of the Commission to adopt as an outcome the accord mark VI prescription. I do not need to run through the submission but, inter alia, it contained a claim for an extra 3 per cent superannuation provision to be made by increasing existing superannuation entitlements by one per cent from 1 July this year, one per cent from 1 July next year and another one per cent on the same date in 1993.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to the case presented by us and all the other parties, the Commission recommended to the Government that the Government hold a conference for those parties and obviously seek some result on the matter. At the present time, the Government regards this as a substantial matter, which relates not only to what are reasonable prescriptions for wage and salary earners in this country but also to our whole strategy on retirement incomes, given that with the continual greying of Australia there will be an increasing number of beneficiaries as pensioners in later years. We recognise as an essential element in meeting the demand they will place on the Budget for pensions on a narrowing tax base that there is now a need to make provision for a superannuation outcome which will enable Australians to retire with dignity. In view of the weighty matters contained therein, the Government is considering its options in this matter and in due course will make an announcement on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Do I take it from that answer that the Minister has not ruled out the convening of a national conference and that, despite the fact that the Government has ignored correspondence on the question from the Business Council of Australia for the last seven months, the Government is still prepared to consider a national conference which would be held in public and available and open to all interested parties?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston refers to ignoring correspondence from the Business Council. On Monday of last week I held meetings with the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, the Metal Trades Industry Association and the Business Council of Australia in separate sessions in order to discuss with them their reaction to the whole of the national wage case decision and, in that context, to the superannuation recommendations in the national wage case decision. So the Government is not ignoring the employer groups on this matter. We have had direct personal discussions on these issues as recently as Monday of last week.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Alston asked me whether this means that the Government is not ruling out something. It means that the Government is studying its options, as I have said, and until it makes a decision all of the options that are available are being studied.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It refers to the unemployment statistics released today, which showed that the increase in the number of unemployed persons was the largest monthly rise recorded by the survey. I particularly address the Minister to the record levels of youth unemployment. When did the Government become aware of and concerned about this aspect of the unemployment situation? What measures did the Government implement at that time to overcome the problem, and why have those measures not been successful?

—I cannot answer that question precisely. Since unemployment began to climb last year there has been some variation in the relative rates of unemployment among young people and adults, and the increase in youth unemployment has been more dramatic than the increase in unemployment for adults. Just the same as when unemployment was going down very rapidly, the lagged effects of youth unemployment followed adult employment downwards. I do not know of any particular programs that have been directed to the question of youth unemployment, apart from the normal programs administered by the Commonwealth Employment Service, but I will make some inquiries about that and give Senator Harradine an answer when I can.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When the Minister makes his inquiries, will he consider providing to the Senate a detailed analysis of the current unemployment situation, including the question of work force participation, and discuss the appropriate solutions?

—As Senator Harradine was the only senator on the other side of the chamber interested in a detailed analysis they are the only words that I heard, but I will read the Hansard to see what he specifically asked and see whether I can provide an answer to that.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I note that Senator Richardson was at the time the Minister responsible for this matter. At the time of the assistance agreement with the Ravenshoe Mill, who within the Department was authorised to make payments in excess of $1m? On what dates and in what amounts were payments made under the assistance agreement, and to which companies was each of the payments under the assistance agreement made? If the Minister is unable to answer the questions at the moment, can he give the Senate an answer as soon as possible?

—I cannot answer those questions now. Senator Boswell did lodge this question at about 1.20 p.m. in my office, but we did not have time to get through to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to get answers. While I was the Minister at the time, I am sure that Senator Boswell will appreciate that I did not necessarily know precisely which person was going to make payments to the Department; I cannot recall that. I will check that and I am sure I can get the details for Senator Boswell tomorrow.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to media reports of allegations that the diplomatic bag was used to deliver large sums of cash to Ambassador Burke in Dublin? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the allegations are valid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of an anonymous note addressed to the Western Australian royal commissioners which alleges that $153,000 was sent to Ambassador Burke from the office of the Secretary to my Department. I note that the officers named in the allegations about money laundering, namely, Mr Woolcott, the Secretary to my Department, and Mr Forrester, the head of the Corporate Management Division, categorically deny the claims made in the note.

ANSWER.PARA: My Department has conducted an investigation of a diplomatic bag sent to Dublin and carried by Mr Shane Carroll in the period just before the alleged report to Mr Forrester of September 1989. My Department found that Mr Carroll did indeed transit New York in August 1989 with a consignment of diplomatic bags, including one for the Australian Embassy in Dublin. The bag for Dublin weighed six kilos and contained the following items: a box containing three Chubb locks with packing which together weighed 3.2 to 3.5 kilos; two batches of classified cables-the exact weight of those two batches is not available but the weight of such batches ranges up to two kilos each; and a letter to Ambassador Burke from the acting head of a branch in the Americas and Europe division of my Department. That letter, which has been identified as classified, contains nine sheets of paper. The Department's records, which are in very good order, are able to account for the contents of the bag in question and manifestly give no credence whatsoever to the allegation.

If one goes beyond the details of the rather bizarre claims made in this anonymous note, there are important points of principle and procedure involved here. There is a well-established mechanism in my Department for handling allegations of fraud or misconduct; mechanisms which do protect the position of those who are genuinely concerned about unmasking such activity. The procedures include referral of concerns in confidence to the Department's fraud prevention and discipline section and, in cases where officers feel their concerns are not being properly dealt with by the Department, the procedures also provide for referral in confidence to the relevant outside authority.

Neither I, nor my Department, will support officers who bypass those procedures and make spurious allegations in the public arena or personal attacks on colleagues. To do so anonymously, as in this latest incident, only compounds the transgression. But to further place these latest allegations in their proper context, I should point out that they are based on claims made by an officer of my Department, Mr Shane Carroll, whose name features prominently in the document in question. It should be said that Mr Carroll had been charged, quite a time before this, with eight charges of improper conduct. These charges included attempts by Mr Carroll to gain personal advantage through threats that, if he did not get the preferment he sought, he would continue to make allegations about corruption and maladministration in my Department.

An inquiry officer from outside my Department was appointed to investigate those charges. She completed her inquiry on 16 April 1991 and directed dismissal of Mr Carroll in respect of each such charge. The inquiry officer's report referred to `a web of misconduct on the part of this gentleman'. In fairness, I should add that he has lodged an appeal with the Merit Protection and Review Agency against the inquiry officer's direction.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

Is this the secret of Labor's economic employment and rural policies?
The answer to that question is no. The second question is:

In other words, because this Government has destroyed the job prospects of two-thirds of South Australian steelworkers, does it intend to visit similar destruction upon Australian farmers, as is evidenced by today's unemployment figures?
The answer to that, without accepting the premise in the question, is no.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Michael Baume proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The continuing human tragedy and misery of the appallingly high level of unemployment brought about by the recession Mr Keating said `we had to have'.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is something awfully self-evident about the continuing human tragedy and misery of the appallingly high level of unemployment brought about by the recession that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said we had to have. The dreadful thing about it was perhaps outlined best by the response to Senator Harradine's question a few minutes ago, when the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) acknowledged the fact that last year it had become evident that there were increases of a substantial nature in youth unemployment and that, nonetheless, the Government had, in effect, done nothing-I underline that-to correct what was happening. It had not changed its basic policy stance. On the contrary, in terms of labour relations it seems to have adopted much more of the tactic of doing exactly what the Australian Council of Trade Unions wants, which bears a greater relationship to the role of people in jobs than the needs of people who are out of jobs and therefore apparently no longer contributing members of the unions.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the extent of the disaster is something that the people of Australia have been slow to comprehend, largely because of the volume of deliberately misleading propaganda coming from the Government benches. The full horror of the unemployment figures is now beginning to sink in. The figures themselves can no longer be discounted, discarded, or ignored by this Government. The figures are too horrendous to be ignored and dismissed. We do not know-we have no idea-what level of unemployment the Government now expects will occur under these policies which have so disastrously failed Australia. Some time ago the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that it would not exceed 10 per cent. Senator Button today, when asked, would not venture a view. He certainly did not defend Mr Hawke's forecast, but replaced it with nothing else.

What will happen next is a question that can be fairly asked in view of the fact that what is happening now was denied by the Government. It said that it would not happen. It was like the recession that we were not going to have, which magically turned into the recession we had to have. That is what is happening in unemployment. These are the unemployment figures, to extend Mr Keating's expression, that Mr Keating says we had to have, because that is what this recession means. These unemployment figures can be pinned directly to the Government's failed economic policies, to its failure to respond, as was established by the response to Senator Harradine's question, to the problems when they first emerged.

I remind the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), who I note is to follow me in this debate, that last year when I raised this matter with him, particularly youth unemployment, he indicated that his advice was that youth unemployment appeared to have bottomed and was trending the other way, I think was the expression. That has turned out not to be true. One wonders whether it reflects on the merit of the advice or the determination of the Government to pretend that things that are nasty do not exist. I do not mind if the Government and the Ministers want to fool themselves, but what bothers me is when they see what is happening and refuse to take action to fix it.

There is no doubt that we are in an economic recession, the depth of which is unnecessarily severe because of the Government's failure to take the sort of fiscal measures that we have been advocating for years and because of its enormous reliance on monetary policy which the Reserve Bank of Australia was telling it for years was the wrong thing to do. The blame must be laid exactly where it belongs.

We even had high commodity prices and a longstanding world boom at a time when Australia was frankly doing badly economically and going further and further into debt. The Government tried to buy its way out of the high unemployment figures of 1983 and 1984-I stress that the 1984 figures for unemployment, well after the Fraser Government had gone, were appallingly high; they were higher than under the Fraser Government-by encouraging huge foreign debt through its economic policies. Our foreign debt is now five times what it was when this Government came to power.

We cannot keep living on borrowed money. The time of reckoning eventually comes, and it looks like the time is now. The people who are carrying the burden of that time are not the members of this Government-they will carry it at the next election-but the people of Australia who have lost their jobs. That is why I want to dramatise just how severe this problem is by looking at the number of people who actually have lost their jobs.

Today's horrific unemployment figures, before seasonal adjustment, reveal that in April 856,000 Australians were looking for work. At the same time last year, 534,200 Australians were looking for work. In other words, in the latest 12 months, 322,000 additional Australians were looking for jobs that they did not have. To the best of my knowledge, having looked through the figures, that is the highest ever increase in one year. It is a 60.3 per cent increase on the previous year. To my knowledge, these are unprecedented figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does this go back to the Great Depression?

—Unfortunately, we cannot get exactly comparable figures for the Great Depression. I do not have them readily available. These figures certainly far exceed the sorts of increases in unemployment which the present Government said were disgraceful when they happened under the Fraser Government. We heard that the Fraser Government should never be forgiven for allowing that to happen. Yet the problems of the Fraser Government basically emerged from the worst drought we had had for 50 years.
—And a world recession.

—And a world recession. I thank the honourable senator for the interjection. What has this Government got to excuse itself in this situation? I guess that one excuse stands out: it had the worlds's greatest Treasurer. This recession is the price that the 856,000 unemployed people of Australia have to pay for having the world's greatest Treasurer.
—The Victorians certainly have no chance of getting jobs.

—I will go to the Victorian situation shortly. We have this huge increase in total unemployment and an enormous increase in youth unemployment. In fact, the unadjusted 25.8 per cent youth unemployment rate for April is the highest April unemployment rate for young people on record-at least on the figures that I can find.

SPEECH.PARA: I am stating all these figures-and I know that it might sound boring-because people have not recognised or understood how horrific and awful they are. For example, there has been a 57 per cent increase in the number of 15- to 19-year-olds who cannot find their first job and who are still looking. This time last year only 29,500 were looking for their first job, but now there are 46,400.

These figures go on in an awful and an horrific way. This latest month has seen, I understand, the biggest monthly rise in unemployment, seasonally adjusted, on record. The total unemployment figure for one month, seasonally adjusted, is 66,900 people. Of course, the 27 per cent unemployment rate among people aged 15 to 19 years, seasonally adjusted, is the highest ever April figure for young unemployed people. As one goes through this dismal booklet put out by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, one sees horror mounted upon horror.

I would now like to turn to the youth unemployment situation in Australia because there we see, for example, that, seasonally adjusted, the number of unemployed young people-that is, people aged between 15 and 19 years-has risen in the last 12 months by 29,600. In just the last 12 months, that is a 35 per cent rise in the number of young people who are out of work. The worsening in the number of unemployed persons, and this includes adults, of 322,100 which I mentioned earlier is-and this has now been confirmed by statistics I have received from the Parliamentary Library-the biggest rise in unemployment ever recorded for a 12-month period.

Returning to the plight of young people aged 15 to 19 years, in the last 12 months the number of young Australians in jobs has fallen by 11,600. That is the biggest ever fall in the number of young Australians in jobs since these statistics began to be collected.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a disgrace!

—Absolutely, I could not agree more. It is interesting to note that there are now 196,000 fewer young people at work in Australia than there were in the same month under the Fraser Government. To an extent, that is because there are much greater secondary school retention levels and I think that should be acknowledged. Even though there is no doubt that the extension of Austudy to secondary students is of great benefit to some of them who will now have the opportunity of being paid to get qualifications that will improve their productivity and their chances of getting jobs, for many young Australians this is no more than a teenager-sitting exercise which gets them out of the dole queues and the unemployment figures so that this Government can dress up the figures to try to make them not look as bad as they really are.

SPEECH.PARA: There are extraordinary gimmicks-for example, the statistical trick of now no longer recording as being unemployed someone who works for one hour per week for no pay. Those people are no longer listed as being unemployed; they are now included as being employed part time. So if someone who is unemployed takes on a work experience job for no pay that person disappears from this Government's unemployment statistics. Of course, if people work on the family farm-and this might explain why the rural figures are not as bad as I thought they would be-for one hour per week for nothing they are no longer listed as being unemployed.
Despite those gimmicks and stunts under this Government, we still have these worst ever youth unemployment figures. I sincerely hope that things will catch up with this Government.

The total number of young people who are unemployed, full time and part time, is also the worst April figure ever, at 178,700. It just seems to go on and on. I have already pointed out that the unemployment rate for April, at 25.8 per cent unadjusted, is the worst April figure ever.

Let us look at what is happening in the States. There is no doubt that different experiences are being felt in different States. In other words, where a State has the double whammy of a Federal Labor government and a State Labor government we have the inevitability of total disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at Tasmania.

—I will be looking at Tasmania, Western Australia, Victoria and other disaster areas. Is it not remarkable that the State with the best record is New South Wales-the only State with a Liberal government?
—Coincidence, do you think?

—I submit that it is not coincidence. I believe that there is a direct correlation between incompetent mismanagement at State and Federal levels and high unemployment. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table which shows the rise in unemployment in each State.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This shows, for example, that the unemployment rate in April 1991 in New South Wales was the lowest of all the States at 8.6 per cent. In Victoria it was 10.5 per cent; Tasmania, 10.8 per cent; Queensland, 10.7 per cent; South Australia, 10.3 per cent; and Western Australia-where the politicians on the Labor side are generally regarded as `Burkes'-11.1 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: We can see what has been happening in these Labor States. In Victoria the rise in unemployment in the last 12 months has been over 100 per cent-117.7 per cent; in South Australia, 52 per cent; in Queensland, 44 per cent; in Western Australia, 57 per cent; and in Tasmania it went up by only 29 per cent this year because it had gone up by so much the previous year. Here is a clear indication of the sorts of disasters and the difference in the levels of disasters in the Australian States. As I said, where one has the double whammy of State and Federal Labor governments there is the double disaster of huge unemployment rates.

I will leave it to some of my other colleagues to outline the specific problems in their States. I want to concentrate now on what the Government has to do and what it refuses to do. It is surely clear that, with the great bulk of job losses in Australia coming from young people, the Government has to recognise more than it did in answer to Senator Harradine's statement that it is not just a question of youth employment going up faster when things are good and going down faster when things are bad. Are we going to have youth in the firing line of economic change all the time? Are the young people under this Government going to be the cannon fodder of economic mismanagement? That is what has happened so far-youth are in the front line.

The latest figures show that adult unemployment is catching them up nonetheless. Adult unemployment in most States is still only about one-third of the youth unemployment rate. It is clear that if the market is telling the Government, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Industrial Relations Commission and others-the people who appear to be running the show-that young people are the most likely to get the chop in a recession, that employers cannot afford to employ them, there is no point in thinking we are solving the problem for all time by shuffling them out of the statistics, by finding holes where we can shove them. There is no doubt that a whole new approach has to be adopted to youth unemployment in particular. For example, a training wage is obviously the way to try to resolve this gross imbalance.

Basically, this nation needs a massive redirection of its economic policies. The present ones have failed. Senator Button skirted around this today at Question Time, but by his whole approach there was a clear concession that Senator Button's and the Government's policies have caused this disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —That human tragedy and misery exist in times of high levels of unemployment cannot be denied by anyone in the chamber, least of all by anyone speaking for the Government. Only a fool would deny that today's unemployment figures mean more tragedy for more people. I certainly would not deny that. Although I think the question for all Australians to face, irrespective of their political allegiances, is why we are where we are and how we might best get out of, not just this recession, but a period where for decades we have gone up and down in economic cycles. We must try to make sure that we have an economic base for our future.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that there is not much point in Senator Baume saying, as he has done for quite some time now, that his recession is better than our recession. I do not think that either one was too hot but I would not claim, even for a second, that Australia's fundamental economic problems lie with decisions taken by the Fraser Government. Sure, when we got into office, times were pretty tough in Australia, not just with the recession, but also with that huge deficit with which we had been left. But they are not the reasons why Australia today faces serious structural problems. Those reasons go back much further.

They go back to the period after the Second World War, through the 1950s and the 1960s, when successive governments in Australia-and, I might say, quite often with the complicity of oppositions-were able to believe that the good times would last forever: that if you could grow it, dig it up or chop it down, it would be good enough; that the sheep's back, the quarry and the forest would get Australia through its future; and for decades it worked.

The problem was that other countries did not waste those decades in the 1950s and the 1960s. Japan, all the countries of Europe including Germany, and the United States, actually used that period to plan, to get ready for a future. They did not think a good future would just fall into their laps. They knew that they had to earn it. Unfortunately, that is a lesson that the generations that ran Australia in the late 1940s, the 1950s and the 1960s never understood.

Now, when we have hit the 1980s and the 1990s, the problem is that those commodities face uncertain times. Senator Baume raised debt as a problem. Looking at the figures, even from the other day, one finds that it is extraordinary that even in recession Australia manages to spend at the moment a billion dollars more each month than the value of its production. That is a worry for all of us. It ought to be a special worry for our kids. They may well be left with a problem unless Australia can face it now.

The interesting thing about the figures is that export volumes are up, but once again Australia, just as it did six years ago, has faced another downturn in its terms of trade. Because we relied on commodities entirely, because the basis of the economy, as a result of decisions taken 30 and 40 years ago, is almost all in that primary sector, almost all in commodities, we do not have any other weapons. So, when the world turns off the high price commodity tap, there is no water in the well for us. Australia needs different patterns of investment and a real manufacturing base to complement the natural advantages that we have with our ores and our primary produce.

Those are the real reasons why Australia has a problem. We can score points forever against each other about who has the best recession. The truth is that Australia will be vulnerable to those recessions until those investment patterns change and until we, as a nation, understand that you cannot spend a billion dollars more each month than the value of the goods which we produce. Those are lessons that I hope all Australians can learn. Over the course of the next few years when making decisions at elections-elections which Senator Michael Baume wants to lead us to-Australians will not simply believe the snake oil salesman who tells them that all can be cured tomorrow afternoon. No-one can do that.

Coming to the crux of today's debate, it disappoints me to hear Senator Baume disparaging the very successful efforts that the Government has made with Austudy and with student payments in the past few years. It is not a matter of hiding unemployment figures. It has to be remembered that when we came to office retention rates for secondary schooling were under 40 per cent; they are up to 60 per cent now. I hope that, as a result of the active employment strategy that will go through this place in the next few weeks, not only more of our young kids but also more of our work force who are unemployed will undergo training to improve their skills. That must have some effect on Australia's future. The skills of the work force will mean everything to us. If they remain low, Australia's future prospects will remain low.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have got to have jobs, though.

—I note that Senator Patterson interjects that they must have job prospects. Surely in a recession when the numbers of unemployed are very high, as Senator Michael Baume has pointed out, our job is to make sure that, when the recession is over, those people who have been disadvantaged have at least used the time of that disadvantage to improve their skills so that they can take advantage of the upturn more quickly, can benefit and can get jobs better than those they have had before. That has to be the aim of everyone in this place, not just the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It disappoints me to hear Senator Michael Baume refer to this strategy as dressing these people up. It is not a matter of dressing anyone up, if I can use his words; it is really a matter of getting those people to a position where they will not be vulnerable in future recessions because they will be so valuable to their employers. That is what Australia must be about. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) talked about the clever country. It is not clever to have a work force that is unskilled. It cannot be. Our efforts to try to improve the skills of the work force during the past few years have been very successful. They will be more successful still after the active employment strategy is introduced.

By the way, it should not be assumed that tough economic times are only occurring here. Even with a manufacturing base, the United States is in a recession. One wonders whether George Bush's head will be called for because of that. If one looks at Great Britain, one will find millions of people on the dole. I doubt very much whether Senator Baume will be calling for John Major's head for that. In the United States there is not even a national social security net underneath anyone who is displaced. Most of the support is either insurance based for individuals or run by individual states. In fact, states are cutting back on social welfare support because people from states with lower benefits are moving to those with better benefits. Rather than some states increasing the benefits, all states are reducing them to make sure that no flood of unemployed comes across the borders.

Australia does not have that sort of system. Here we have one of the most ordered and effective social security systems in the world. In fact, officials from our Department of Social Security have been invited to go to Canada and the United States in, I think, October this year to give some lectures on how their systems might be improved. Around the world it is recognised that the system here to meet the needs for those who are unemployed is far better than it is in other places. I note that the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson-I hope that everyone notes that I have finally said `doctor'; I have been trying to remember to do so for months-was in New Zealand recently.

TALK.START.PARA: —So was Senator Cooney. What was he trying to learn?

—I do not think this has much to do with Senator Cooney. Dr Hewson was in New Zealand looking at what is being done by that country about social security payments. As most honourable senators would be aware, things have been very grim in New Zealand with massive cuts across a whole range of benefits. In a press conference in New Zealand on 26 April, Dr Hewson said that his aims were to ensure that the money goes to those in need and that those who should not get it or who in some way are sponging on the system get excluded. The problem is that if Senator Baume-I understand that Senator Baume has a particular liking for Gilbert and Sullivan and I understand he occasionally treads the boards in pursuit of that--
—And very well, too.

—I am not in a position to say whether he does it well or not. But one would imagine, if he is to support Dr Hewson in the kinds of statements that he made in New Zealand-and which, of course, he has made many times here-the only Gilbert and Sullivan role in which he would excel would be as Lord High Executioner to those who are unemployed. What happens after nine months? I cannot say exactly what will happen under Liberal Party policy because it does not actually have a policy in this area yet. It does not have a policy in respect of health, tax or social welfare-mind you, we are waiting. But according to these statements that have been made by Dr Hewson and others, at nine months the execution will occur. At nine months a person will be considered to be a sponger on the system, and out that person will go.
—That's not true.

—It is true. Not only is it true, but honourable senators opposite are now not even maintaining any more the pretence that was maintained for a few months that these people would go on to special benefits.
—That is not true.
—It is true. Dr Reith-that is not correct; he is certainly not a doctor--
—Professor Hewson.

—No, I am talking about Reith on this occasion. He is not a professor, not a doctor-he is a Mr; an ordinary old Mr. Even Senator Teague does not have to go back to ordinary old Mr-he has a more exalted title. But Mr Reith has made it perfectly clear that that safeguard of special benefit will go. After nine months, to use Dr Hewson's words of some time ago, people would just have to look after themselves. That is what the Liberal philosophy is. After nine months people will be executed if they are on the dole. The Liberals would say, `We don't want to care about you any more; you are on the streets'. One wonders what kind of society Australia would be to live in if that happened. If it does happen, the fair play ethic which has been a part of Australian thinking over the past 100 years will go out the window.

SPEECH.PARA: Today Senator Baume made much of youth unemployment. He also raised this matter in a press release that was put out some little time ago.
