He did not tell all the story, of course, in the press release. He certainly did not talk about the level of youth unemployment in March 1983 when this Government came to power. The level then was 28 per cent. The figure today is 25.8 per cent. I do not pretend for a second that I am proud of a 25.8 per cent figure; it is awful. But it is, of course, much better than that which was left to us. One wonders why Senator Baume could be so selective in his press release as to leave out what I would have thought was an incredibly important fact.

With respect to arguments over how the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) figures are calculated and who is included and who is not included, one has to look at this a little more deeply. The first point is that the Government does not determine what the statistician does with those figures. We do not instruct the statistician what is to go into them and how they are to be compiled. He is independent and he makes up his own mind. So, it cannot be a case of any sort of Government fiddle. That is a nonsense and, of course, a gross insult to the Australian Bureau of Statistics which is collecting those statistics. It has never been the case that the Government has directed it in the way that those figures ought to be prepared.

When talking about figures concerning youth, we have to look at the number attending school or who are in tertiary institutions. We also have to bear in mind the decline in the proportion of people aged 15 to 19 in our population, which is a reflection of the slowdown in the birth rate that has been occurring for some time. I would have thought that the increasing numbers in schools and tertiary institutions and that decline in the proportion in the 15 to 19 age group would account for all of Senator Baume's alleged hiding of unemployed youth.

The Government has continued to attempt to assist teenagers in their efforts to get jobs. The announcements that we have made, even as recently as earlier this year, further that. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) was able to have included in the March statement a whole range of measures which will involve more and more training programs.

An extra 55,000 or 56,000 training places will be made available as a result of those programs. That is on top of all those programs that are in place at the moment. So a whole host of people get new opportunities to improve their skills. They will not be dressed up but will be made into more effective, more skilled workers to benefit Australia both now and in the future.

The number of young people receiving apprenticeship training and Austudy educational allowances has jumped significantly since 1983. Many things have jumped since 1983. When one looks at that 1982 recession, the situation we inherited when we came to office, it has to be remembered that the real value of unemployment benefits then for a single adult as compared to now was 26 per cent less. The real value of those benefits has increased by 26 per cent during the eight years of this Government. Although I might not be proud of the unemployment figures, I am certainly proud of what the Government has been able to do for those people who are unemployed. Their lot has been very significantly improved every year by this Labor Government.

Hardly anybody got rental assistance in 1983. Rental assistance has been a creation of the last eight years. Brian Howe, during his stewardship of the portfolio I inherited from him, was able particularly to bring about massive increases in rental assistance-increases hitherto unthought of. For some, there have been increases of up to 79 per cent in real terms, which is an enormous jump. Of course, rental assistance during Brian Howe's time was extended to unemployment beneficiaries who rent private accommodation. That had not been the case before.

I do not think it is all that fair, and one would imagine a tad rich, to be preached to by Senator Baume, who as Mr Baume was a member of the Fraser Government, when one looks at the miserable rates that that Government was paying for unemployment benefits at the time of a recession and at a time when rental assistance was not paid to unemployed people. At least some compassion has been shown by this Government. At least we have acknowledged where the suffering is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rents are much higher now.

—I talked about the real value, and Senator Baume was listening, so do not tell me about higher rents; that makes no difference. It is not a question of the matter of public importance that Senator Baume has submitted. Talking about the continuing human tragedy and misery is a bit rich when one considers that all the Opposition wants to do is recognise the increased numbers. The Opposition does not want to do anything at all about the financial situation of the unemployed. There is no proposal on the other side of the chamber to increase by a cent any welfare payment. All the Opposition wants to do is cut them out. The Opposition should not lecture us on how appalled it is about misery and tragedy when all it wants to do is add to it: make it more miserable for more people. All the Opposition has in mind is to cut off after nine months people who will be in desperate strife and put them on the streets. That is not something that we could ever agree with, let alone even consider.
—That is absolute rubbish, and you know it.

—Senator Patterson wishes it was rubbish, but I actually think that Senator Patterson might have some sort of conscience and believe in it. The accountants that run Senator Patterson's Party only think about the bottom line; they have no concern or compassion for people at all-never have had and never will. The Opposition should not denigrate the achievements of Austudy and those kids who are now able to stay at school because of that and other student allowances.

SPEECH.PARA: We have made sure that Australia's work force in the future will be far more skilled than it was in the past. The Opposition should not acknowledge tragedy and then prescribe for it even more tragedy. That is all that a Hewson-Reith administration could ever do.

In a press release of 7 April Senator Alston spoke of an employment strategy for the unemployed based on supplying them with `the right incentives'. The right incentives will come down to the stiff medicine that Prime Minister Bolger called it in December of last year in New Zealand. As Senator Baume and others cast admiring eyes over the cuts that the New Zealanders have made, I hope that all those in Australia presently unemployed understand what that will mean for them. It will mean a throwback to the uncaring attitudes of colonial Australia, a throwback to the worst of the bad old days.

The unemployed deserve an awful lot better than that. They deserve at least governments with some care, some compassion and an intention to make sure that payments to them are not just maintained but increased. We have demonstrated that commitment over a long period of time, and we shall to continue to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is today once again discussing, on a matter of public importance brought by the Opposition, the damage done not only to our economy but to the people who are thrown out of work by the Government's engineered depression. Once we have reached that point, we should look at the victims. Before the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) leaves the chamber, I express some appreciation of the comments that he addressed to the Opposition's more draconian proposals on the active employment strategy. It gives me some hope that the Minister might be more receptive to the amendments of the Australian Democrats which we will move to make that so-called active employment strategy of the Government more humane and constructive.

SPEECH.PARA: It is somewhat ironic that we are discussing these matters on a matter of public importance brought by the Opposition. There is no doubt that the Government's economic policies are causing great hardship, but for the Opposition to continue to take up the time of this chamber and to cry crocodile tears is really nothing more than an exercise in political point scoring and grandstanding. Behind the Opposition's sudden, great concern for poor and disadvantaged Australians stands a reef of economic policies which this Government is implementing. Once again, we need to consider that these are the very policies that the Liberal and National parties in opposition in this chamber have supported and which, as I have said, the Government has in fact been implementing.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a load of rubbish.
—If Senator Campbell would like to tell me just one policy of the Government, one economic policy of the dog-eat-dog variety, that he does not agree with, I would be very pleased to hear it.
—What is wrong with industrial relations reform?

—Order! Senator Spindler, it might be a good idea if you addressed your remarks through the Chair. You are anticipating interjections and you are getting them. If you want protection, address your remarks through the chair.
—I will be happy to do so.
—What about industrial relations reform?
—Senator Baume, I spoke then and indicated that I did not want any more interjections.

—I will be pleased to address my remarks through the Chair. It is obvious that the Government, in its failure of its economic policies, has had to rely on the support of the coalition parties, who have refused to assist the Australian Democrats in opposing some of the measures which would have reduced the suffering of those Australians who are now bearing the brunt of the recession.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of Australians suffering as a consequence of the recession, one could ask: where has the Opposition been on the issue of income support for young, unemployed and homeless people; on the removal of the assets test for farmers seeking family allowance supplement and Austudy; on increasing the waiting period for unemployment benefits? The Australian Democrats have moved amendments to shorten it, but where have the coalition parties been on this issue?

The high interest policy instituted by the Government was supported by Dr Hewson, who believed that that was indeed the only economic policy that could be applied to remove the imbalance in our trade figures. The Government, aided and abetted by the Opposition, is committed to dismantling all protective barriers to Australian industry while our competitors, in many cases, are increasing the assistance provided to their industries, especially their primary industries.

Where is the benefit to low income families and rural Australian families in policies that call for the total deregulation and privatisation of our transport, health, financial and communications systems? Where is the benefit to them in having unemployment benefit cut off after nine months-the stated policy of the Opposition? Where is the benefit to them in a consumption tax which will reduce the sales tax on Rolls Royces and place it on bread and milk? Where is the benefit to them in massive cuts in public expenditure?

I am not saying this to let the Government off the hook: the Government should be deeply ashamed of the effects of its economic policies on those people who have always given the Australian Labor Party their support on the understanding-obviously false-that it would protect the interests of ordinary Australian workers. Those who are disillusioned with the Government should not expect the Opposition parties to rally to their cause.

I now turn to the damning figures released today on the current state of employment in Australia. In this respect we are talking about people who want to work and who cannot find work. A record number of 844,000 people are now unemployed, which represents a record increase of 66,900 since last month. One year ago the figure was 524,700, which means that there has been a 60 per cent increase in the last 12 months. Currently 9.9 per cent of the population is officially unemployed, the highest figure since April 1984. I believe that we can add at least another 50 per cent to this figure, as Senator Baume demonstrated earlier this week, because of the hidden unemployed. There are 616,000 people on unemployment benefits. So the Government's Budget figure of 475,000 people receiving unemployment benefit has been well and truly exceeded. The record is the 1984 figure of 619,000, which will probably be exceeded next month.

Among the States, Western Australia had the highest unemployment rate at a seasonally adjusted 11.1 per cent; followed by Tasmania with 10.8 per cent; Queensland, 10.7 per cent; my own State of Victoria with 10.5 per cent; South Australia, 10.3 per cent; and New South Wales, 8.6 per cent. As usual, the Australian Capital Territory has the lowest rate of 6.6 per cent. Public servants and politicians do not easily become unemployed or affected by either the Government's or the Opposition's economic policies.

Perhaps the most worrying figure is for the seasonally adjusted teenage unemployment rate, which rose from 25.8 per cent to another record high of 27 per cent. One year ago, the figure was 17 per cent. Once again our young people are bearing the brunt of the economic policies of the Government and the Opposition. Since the cut-backs to income support for young people-again, I might add, supported by the Opposition last year-we can safely assume that the vast majority of the young people who cannot find work are now living in poverty. What an indictment of this Government. What an indictment of both old parties. So much for caring for young people as one of our most precious assets and so much for our future, which I believe is severely endangered by these policies.

We have seen the lessons to be learnt in Europe, where in Germany record high unemployment figures have seen the rise of fascism and Nazism. We should learn from those experiences and ensure that social dislocation of that nature and the human misery that goes with it does not occur in this country. The figures shatter once and for all the myth that people on unemployment benefit are dole bludgers. It is now very clear that there are simply not enough jobs to go around, yet the Opposition proposes to terminate the payment of unemployment benefit after nine months.

I turn to the active employment strategy. What does the Government do in the midst of this rising unemployment, hardship and despair? It introduces this so-called employment strategy which will compel unemployed people to enter into an agreement with the Government in order to receive unemployment payments. The strategy provides for the abolition of unemployment benefit from 1 July 1991 and its replacement with a two-tier payment system which is dependent on people abiding by directions given to them by public servants standing behind a counter.

Yet the Government is trying to sell this strategy as a positive and active program. We should remember that these people are not given the choice to work or to seek training; they are being forced to do so. Training for what? Is the evidence not on the table today that jobs are simply not there? Yet we are going to force people to undertake training or to lose unemployment benefit for jobs that are not in existence.

This strategy is fraught with problems, of both a philosophical and practical nature. It has already attracted widespread criticism-correctly-from a variety of quarters, including the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Australian Council of Social Service and many other community and welfare organisations. Whilst I do not have time to go into the numerous technical and practical problems with this package, I foreshadow once again the amendments that the Australian Democrats will move to make this strategy more humane and more constructive.

We believe that the Government should demonstrate that those people who are out of work are given a genuine chance through an economic strategy which will create jobs. I refer to an article published in the Sydney Morning Herald on 4 May 1991 headed `Forum calls for Federal initiatives'. The article refers to a report entitled An Australia that Works: A Vision for the Future by the Committee for the Economic Development of Australia (CEDA). In quoting from that report, the article states:

``Picking winners is not always an undesirable project, as the success of Singapore, Korea and Japan suggests; intervention by government is not always `shooting ourselves in the foot' as the successful interventions that occur in all those countries demonstrate,'' the communique says.
``The overall scale of markets in an economy like Australia can be stimulated by government use of market access, purchasing and offsets to secure competitive advantages.''
The CEDA conference called upon the Government to focus its policies on a number of key areas:
* improvements to the education and training system to create a more productive work force;
* bringing about a rise in the proportion of Australia's commodity exports shipped abroad in a higher value-added form;
* renewed commitment to the manufacturing sector; and
* reform of the institutional and constitutional framework to remove counter-productive Federal/State divisions.

It found that the key areas of value-added growth in 21st century would include areas such as telecommunications, education, health, development and research, and tourism-all heavily dependent upon government programs.

It is time that the Government and the Opposition accepted that it is no longer acceptable to pursue economic policies which are based on a dog eat dog, totally deregulated free market. We must look to the Government to take interventive action to ensure that those industry sectors which can provide employment do so.

It is urgent that the Government look at some of these measures that are now necessary to achieve the aim to provide work for all those who want to work. I cite a few points from the policy of the Australian Democrats: a reduced payroll tax; a 5 per cent bounty on new exports-and I emphasise new exports; a further lowering of the home loan interest rate; faster depreciation for new investment in productivity enhancing equipment, in contrast to the token adjustment in the Government's industry statement; a slowing down of tariff reductions while other countries are increasing the barriers against our products; and increasing expenditure on public transport and public housing. Immediately everybody will say, `But where is the money coming from?'. These costs could easily be covered by a 2c per litre additional petrol and diesel excise, which would yield $460m; a 40 per cent increase in the excise on tobacco and alcohol, which would yield $1.1 billion; and increased withholding taxes on foreign loan interest which has recently been the subject of the Martin report, which would yield $600m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: -I cannot let pass the comments made by both the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, and Senator Spindler because they implied that they have a monopoly on compassion; that they are the only ones who care about the unemployed. I find it offensive and I will not accept it. One of my greatest fears is that in my lifetime-God forbid it-the Australian Democrats will obtain power. If that happened, every business person would desert this country at the rate of knots and we would have unemployment beyond any record that we have ever seen today. I am not going to deal with any more of Senator Spindler's remarks because, as Senator Walsh said, it really is `fairies at the bottom of the garden' stuff. If Senator Spindler thinks he has the answers, then God help Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish that Senator Richardson were here in the chamber so that I could take him back to 1983 and compare the figures. Almost eight years ago to the day-on 25 May 1983-Senator Richardson, who was not then Minister for Social Security, said:
The last election was won by the Australian Labor Party on the issue of unemployment. This Government will sink or swim on its performance in providing jobs.

I repeat: this Government will sink or swim on its performance in providing jobs. Let me just say that the word `providing' is the key to the difference between Labor and Liberal. The Labor Government is trying to provide jobs but the coalition is about creating the environment in which the private sector can create the jobs. This is preferable to going out and falsely boosting jobs. As a result of the Government's trying to provide jobs, we have seen an increase in the public sector and now we are seeing the real unemployment, the true unemployment.

We are debating today the continuing human tragedy and misery of the appallingly high level of unemployment brought about by the recession that the Treasurer, Mr Keating, said `we had to have'. Often the suffering and human tragedy being experienced by Australians as a result of the recession `we had to have' is reduced to headlines and statistics. I just give some examples of these headlines: `Record job plunge a test of Government's resolve'; `Jobless hits 9.2 per cent and worse to come'; `Unemployment tops one million'; `Victorian apprenticeship vacancies down by 43 per cent'; and `Minister predicts more jobless'-that was Senator Richardson on 2 February; he was right for once. I suppose he was getting us all prepared. The final example is: `State's dole numbers soar'.

It is all very well as we sit back and look at those headlines. I suppose that one of the headlines tomorrow will be `Record unemployment rates for two months in a row'. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer and the Minister for Social Security have all recognised the seriousness of Australia's unemployment problem but they have no choice.

Today at half past 11 we had unemployment statistics which were unambiguously bad. In April, a new record was created-844,000 people unemployed. This followed an old record-it has taken only a month to break it-of 770,100 unemployed in March. In April, the unemployment rate rose from 9.2 per cent to 9.9 per cent with 66,900 more Australians joining the dole queues. As Senator Baume has said, this is the largest monthly rise recorded by the survey. When we think about that and divide it by 30, that is some 2,500 people a day, seven days a week over the last month, who had no jobs. These were people who fronted up to their work to be told, `You're finishing up on Friday'. These are people who work in manufacturing or in the local shop in High Street, Malvern or wherever else. In Victoria, the unemployment rate rose from 9.7 per cent in March to 10.7 per cent in April, with 28,700 Victorians joining the dole queues.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is over the magic 10 per cent.

—Yes, Victoria has gone over the magical 10 per cent. Between April 1990 and April 1991 the unemployment rate in Victoria rose from 4.8 per cent to 10.5 per cent; more than double. The number of unemployed people rose from 106,000 to 230,000 in one 12-month period. That is what has happened in my State since the last election; double the number of people unemployed because of the folly of the Victorian State Government and the folly of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: In March, there were 1.05 million Australians registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service looking for work; a million people out there searching for jobs-and they are the registered ones. The number of people working dropped by 82,400 in March, which represented the biggest ever monthly employment decrease-Senator Baume mentioned that. Youth unemployment rose from 14.6 per cent in April 1990 to 27.4 per cent in April 1991. In March 1991, 35.6 per cent of Australians under 20 were looking for full time work. In Melbourne, a massive 45 per cent of young people under 20 were looking for work. That is nearly half of the kids under 20 looking for jobs. Over the last 12 months, approximately 190,000 jobs have disappeared from the labour market; 150,000 of these in the past three months.

It is not difficult to become complacent and blase when one is inundated with one set of bad economic statistics after another. From the relative comfort of employment-which those of us here in the Senate, our staff and the staff of the Parliament enjoy-it is easy to insulate oneself from the despair, the helplessness, the frustration, the bitterness, and the financial and emotional suffering which characterise the tragic human face of the unemployment figures; that is, the people behind the figures.

We are talking about 844,000 Australian families whose goals and aspirations have been shot down by a recession which the Treasurer claims `we had to have'. These are 844,000 Australians whose confidence and self-esteem is gradually being withered away as they apply, but are rejected, for jobs which they are more than capable of performing. These are the 844,000 Australians with mouths to feed, families to clothe, mortgages or rent to pay and no foreseeable means of meeting these responsibilities.

I will try to provide the Senate with an insight into the human face because we have talked about statistics. Senator Richardson talked about statistics and he talked about what the Government was doing. But he did not talk about the people. Let me just tell the Senate about James from Kings Cross in Sydney. We can read about him in the Burdekin report:

James is a 19-year-old youth who presented to us on 2 September, homeless and unemployed. He was not streetwise and needed a bed until he could find a job and get a place to live. He was exceptionally motivated and made every attempt to find work . . . However, we could not find accommodation for James outside Kings Cross because generally refuges do not accept people over the age of 18. As disillusionment with his failure to get work grew, James became more acquainted with the Cross, more acquainted with the street life and he began using drugs . . . On the 26th of the ninth, this is three and a half weeks after arriving on our doorstep, James left us to go to a squat. In three and a half weeks that highly motivated person was on the street using drugs . . .

That is how long it takes-3 1/2 weeks. Senator Richardson stood there telling us that when the recession was over there would be training programs and people would get employment. Well, in 3 1/2 weeks the damage can be done; we do not have the time.

Gavin is another example. Gavin is 17 years old and has left school. He refuses to accept unemployment benefits because he does not believe that he should get something for nothing. He wants to be an ambulance driver. What can he do in the interim? He has gone off to get his driver's licence, to improve his first-aid skills and to continue his voluntary work with the State Emergency Service until he is 19. He has found a way of coping, but it is not really satisfactory for him.

Let me tell honourable senators about Nadia who, last weekend, stood in a queue of 5,000 people. I remember looking at photographs in old newspapers of people in long dole queues during the depression. On this occasion there were 5,000 people seeking a job in a Japanese-owned department store which is to open in Melbourne in five months time. Nadia, with an honours degree in art history and a graduate diploma in museum studies, has spent the last five months looking for a job and has said she would take anything. She believes that what is happening is disheartening and demoralising. That was Nadia last weekend looking for a job.

I refer to another letter which covers two States. It is a letter I pulled out of a newspaper and gave to a couple of my colleagues because it demonstrates two things. First, it deals with the human face of unemployment and, secondly, it deals with the other people involved-the parents. The parents of these young people who are unemployed had aspirations for their children and indeed have worked their insides out to give them the very opportunities that they as parents did not have. They are now watching those kids being consigned to the scrapheap of life. Mr Taylor of Toowoomba says:

My son, Andrew has just been retrenched-yesterday. He is 23 and has an agricultural science degree from Queensland University. It took Andrew six months to find a job after graduating at the end of last year.
He put a huge effort into job-hunting. He did not at any stage go on the dole as he thought that was a bit defeatist and his mother and I were perfectly happy to sustain him.

There were only eight students in his year who majored in Animal Production-eight. From a highly regarded faculty in one of the country's premier universities, eight graduates B.Ag.Sc. looking for jobs . . .
But Andrew found his job-in the dairying industry in northern Victoria. A small, lean, competent cooperative involved in herd improvement and increased efficiency in dairying.
All about productivity and being clever, in fact.
He loved it . . .
The letter goes on to talk about Andrew and his job there. It continues:
But the export-orientated farmers in northern Victoria have been squeezed dry . . .
The father then talks about the business declining. He continues in the letter:

When he had to be retrenched, his boss, the chairman, and the past chairman were all there-the hardest thing his boss has had to do in 30 years in the industry. The toughened chairman had tears in his eyes. When it was over, his boss suggested to Andrew that he ring home- `Stay on the phone for half an hour if you need to, Andrew'.
That is what the boss said to this Queensland boy who had got a job in Victoria. The letter continues:
Andrew is devastated. `I didn't regard this as just a 9 to 5 job, Dad, and I'm leaving when I know there is a lot more I can do here.'
Then the father makes the comment:

So while the thugs in the trade union movement continue to run Australia on the basis of the maximum wages and rorts for the minimum of effort, this country burns. While the social security industry blossoms and is deliberately nurtured by Government policy, industries haemorrhage. While other countries dump their produce in Australia, ours rots. What a clever country!

That is the human face of unemployment. I have told only a handful of 844,000 real life stories which illustrate the pain and frustration borne by those who have felt the brunt of the Treasurer's engineered recession, but they are real stories involving real people.

The time for fiddling with levers has passed. That is what Treasurer Keating has been doing. What is needed is tax reform, labour market reform, and transport and waterfront reform. Confidence needs to be restored so that businesses are prepared to invest in Australia, with jobs being created by that investment. That is what we need. I want to remind my colleagues on the other side of the chamber what Senator Richardson said in October 1983:

I might say that the Labor Government was elected primarily on the issue of unemployment. It recognises its responsibilities in this area and if it fails over the years to meet the problem of unemployment it will not be elected again . . .
I repeat that he said in those circumstances this Government `will not be elected again'. He then added, `and it will not deserve to be'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some considerable regret, in the two meanings of that word, that I rise to speak in this debate today: first, because it is a debate that has been run on a number of occasions in this place, and I do not think the Opposition is persuading me in any way that if and when it ever got to be in government it would understand what a human face was about; and, secondly, because it is quite clearly a matter of regret for me and for government, as has already been said by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), that there are that number of people unemployed. It is a matter of great regret and requires us to have taken more heed of what the Minister said about the best way to tackle this. Brawls about which recession is best probably are not very constructive, nor are people who want to claim that they have a monopoly on compassion.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know how Senator Patterson defines compassion, or whether it is that she has 800 letters. I suspect that Senator Patterson is worthy of more regard than that. It is to me a matter of real concern to wonder how one describes compassion if one is in government. If one is in government compassion has to be assessed, judged and described by the programs one implements to address the problems of unemployed people, not by articles of faith. A faith-led recovery I do not believe would be persuasive. I am not quite sure what Senator Patterson believes because it is very difficult to find out what Opposition members believe. It is very clear that they have some claims. Perhaps a declamatory-led recovery may be another way of putting it.

Then there was the suggestion that we should attract investment, which would create jobs. Senator Patterson, in making that claim, I believe, is suggesting that this Government has not provided jobs. That is a gross misrepresentation of the facts and indicates that Senator Patterson does not have a very good understanding of the 1.6 million jobs that have been created. Unfortunately, in the past 12 months, some of those have gone. But they were not provided by government. They were created by the Government at the time, setting the parameters that allowed for that growth to happen. We know the benefits. We have argued so often in this place the benefit of people finding their income security in the preferred way, that is, through employment.

It was said in the last debate on this issue by Opposition senators, and it is said from time to time by them, that they object to women in the work force, to women exercising their option to take up jobs and to seek their income security in this way. I believe, Madam Acting Deputy President, that that is not your view, because I understand that you have said so in certain places, including this chamber. It is curious that Opposition senators would want to say in this chamber that what we need to do is to give everyone jobs but on other occasions take the view `Yes, but we do not really mean women'.

I do not know their view on employment or the role of women in employment. I believe that they are not clear about it. Senator Patterson may frown, but the record shows what she and some of her colleagues think about women in employment. The challenge for anybody listening to this debate is to try to find out what the Opposition would do to address the challenge of such high unemployment. It is quite clear what the Government has done and is doing. That is the difference, and that is what this debate comes down to.

Senator Michael Baume has asked us today to debate the continuing human tragedy and misery of the appallingly high level of unemployment, but he finishes with dot, dot, dot, with no suggestion at all about what he or the Opposition will do. When Senator Richardson suggested that Dr Hewson had views about what the Opposition would do, Senator Michael Baume wanted to object to those things. I can quote Dr Hewson following, I think, a visit to New Zealand, but I cannot be absolutely sure about that. This is a transcript of an interview with Mr Matt Abraham on 6 May 1991. Certainly Dr Hewson was giving the interview on that day. I cannot say where he was, but I suspect he was back in this country.

When asked what he thought about the dramatic cuts of up to 10 per cent or more in pensions, medical subsidies and so on and the rise in prescription charges in New Zealand under the Bolger Government, and whether he was persuaded or attracted to follow in kind, Dr Hewson said:

Well, we are not necessarily picking up any of their welfare cuts, although in principle personal financial responsibility originating with the family and the targeting of welfare are key elements of our approach. We have already identified some of the decisions we would take in that regard, although we do not mirror in a sense the New Zealand approach. Sure, we need to keep a tough line on that, on welfare spending, to make sure it hits the target . . . We need to keep a tough line on welfare spending to make sure that it hits the target, to make sure that those who shouldn't get it don't get it or shouldn't get it to the extent that they get it, well, we will have to cut that back.

Senator Michael Baume seems to be objecting that Dr Hewson will not be cutting back on welfare. On the next page Dr Hewson says, yes, that he anticipates that cuts in welfare would be about $1 billion. That is a pretty exciting achievement! That is what the Opposition is telling people who are unemployed. We will look forward to a Hewson government: it will cut welfare by $1 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —People who need welfare, get it; that is what targeting means. Do you understand English?

—Does Senator Michael Baume understand the achievements of this Government, which has actually cut expenditure in welfare and at the same time increased every payment because of targeting? Why would he not want to endorse that achievement? If our approach is not his, how does he intend to do it differently? Why does Senator Michael Baume object to the Government's achievements in this area and suggest that he can do better if targeting means that after nine months unemployment people will lose any further assistance under the Hewson proposals? Is that called targeting or is that called marginalising?

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that we can take any comfort from what the Opposition is proposing to do. Dr Hewson says, `We will stay tough on welfare, we will find $1 billion worth of cuts in welfare and we will make sure that people look after themselves after those nine months'.

I understand that the Opposition is proposing some amendments to the Job Search and Newstart legislation that actually modify that position just slightly. But the principle remains the same: the Opposition will not support people on the unemployment benefit after nine and possibly 11 months. That is in such contrast to what this Government is doing. As I have said in this place on previous occasions, this Government is concerned about unemployed people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your greatest record is massive unemployment. You have created so many, no wonder.

—Order! Senator Michael Baume, you have had an opportunity to contribute to this debate. Senator Crowley is entitled to make her contribution as adequately or inadequately as she chooses without your assistance.

—I think I thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. The point I want to make-as I have said, I have made it in previous speeches-is that it has not only been in times of recession or high unemployment that the Government has actually designed and delivered programs that assist people who find themselves unemployed or, for that matter, dependent upon social security for their income maintenance, whether it be through pensions or benefits other than the unemployment benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government is concerned to see that people on benefits or pensions in this country are not forgotten. That has been the practice in the past. The Government has focused on counselling skills, training and projects to encourage those people to feel part of a system, to undertake training, to develop their skills and to gain the confidence that is certainly likely to slip if they are unemployed. That is all recognised and understood. That is why these government programs are in place.

I would like the Opposition to tell me-I can never get this information-whether it will cut out these programs and abandon the training schemes. Will it say, `It is not a matter of training; all you have to do is create employment and people will know how to get the jobs'? Does the Opposition recognise that the nature of jobs and employment in this country is changing and must continue to change in the direction of a more skilled work force? I do not understand how Opposition senators can argue against those government proposals and at the same time say that they have a compassion for people who are unemployed.

Minister Richardson took issue with Senator Michael Baume about his claims that the Government is fiddling the unemployment figures. That is something that I, too, would like to pick up. Senator Michael Baume's speech in this place on 11 April 1991 conveys to me that he does not understand what the figures are about and that, if he does, he is not prepared to let the facts interfere with his preferred fiction. He talked about how governments fiddle statistics and seemed to quite ignore the fact that these statistics are collected by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). If he means that there is a fiddle on, he should take it up with the ABS instead of making vague smears and indulging in innuendo. Senator Michael Baume went on to say:

This is apart from the enormous fiddle involved in the statistics by the extension of Austudy to secondary schools which, as the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) said, in many instances may prove enormously beneficial in the long run to some people who would be given opportunities to get better education and training.

What is Senator Michael Baume saying? Is he saying that the statistics are being fiddled? Is he saying that the country is being deluded about the state of unemployment because people are exercising their choice to take up Austudy? Is he saying that people who exercise their option to take up Austudy and not receive the unemployment benefit are daft? Is he saying that he does not believe that people should have the right to take up Austudy? Is he saying that these figures are really just a deliberate attempt by government to hide unemployment?

This Government and I are proud that there is no longer an incentive for people to receive the unemployment benefit instead of Austudy. This Government has taken away the incentive for young untrained and unskilled people to go directly to jobs instead of staying on at school where they can study and train. Is Senator Michael Baume saying that he believes we should do away with Austudy and that people should not have that training? If he is not saying that, he should stop suggesting that the ABS is fiddling statistics. The fact is that Australians prefer to take up the option of Austudy rather than receive the unemployment benefit. It is the direct policy and aim of this Government that this should happen.

This Government does not want to see what happened under Mr Fraser. Mick Young has written about the tremendous loss in terms of skilled personnel that results from a time lag of at least five years that is needed for training. It is a comfort, albeit minimal, that this Government is saying to people, `If you are forced to be unemployed for a short time, do not waste your time. Make use of that time to train, to maintain your skills, to be retrained or to upgrade those skills so that when the opportunities for employment re-emerge, as they certainly will, you will be well placed to take up those positions'.

I noticed that, during Minister Richardson's speech, Senator Michael Baume and Senator Patterson wanted to interject, `What is the point of going to school or getting training when there were no jobs?'. I hope that they do not really believe the implication in that kind of question. If the virtue of education, training and skills is not clear to Senator Michael Baume and Senator Patterson, I wonder about the seriousness of their claims of compassion and concern for the unemployed. They cannot tell me that they would continue the Government's programs that have been set in place. It is all very well to speak in the Senate or out in the community about their concern and compassion. But that concern and compassion must be reinforced by setting in place programs that will actually put them into existence.
We fall back on, and we are prepared to argue for, compassionate programs and policies for the unemployed that will help and assist this country to get through this very difficult and hard period.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The trouble with what Senator Crowley has just said is that what Senator Patterson and Senator Baume have said about education training and skills is exactly how young Australians in schools and young unemployed Australians feel today. All around Australia-in Cairns, Townsville and Mackay when I was there last week and also in Western Australia-young people have said to me, `What's the use of having skills and what's the use of going to school if there are no jobs?'. That is exactly how young Australians feel. There is no hope for the future under this Government. Young Australians are depressed and this lack of morale is evident. This Government has to face this fact, as much as it hurts.

SPEECH.PARA: In her contribution Senator Crowley referred to what the Opposition would do when in government. She asked us a series of questions. She said, `The Opposition never tells us what its policies are' and she spent the last 15 minutes of her speech discussing that with the Senate. But the real question is: what is this Government going to do about it? After listening to Senator Richardson and Senator Crowley today the Senate is no better informed. We look forward to hearing Senator Giles's contribution as to how this Government hopes to solve this crisis of its own making. The matter of public importance says--

TALK.START.PARA: —No more palliatives, a real solution.

—That is right. We want to know how the Government will solve this crisis. The matter of public importance says that this is a recession that `we had to have'. Senator Crowley also dealt with the Opposition's views on women in the work force. Our position is quite clear: women should choose their position in the work force. We do not believe in the Australian Labor Party's policy of pushing women forward. We believe that the people who are best qualified for the jobs should get the jobs. We do not believe in that sort of discrimination.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson, in his comments, asked the Senate to ignore the question of whose recession was the worst. Of late, the Government has been comparing the current recession with the recession which occurred in 1982-83. I do not wish to do that, but as the comparisons and the figures get worse, month by month, Senator Richardson has invented a new strategy-to go back and blame Robert Menzies. He cannot blame Malcolm Fraser any more so he is blaming Robert Menzies for our current state of affairs. I guess that shows how far Senator Richardson has got to go.

We should perhaps look at the state Australia was in during the years of Robert Menzies. Of course, taxes were a hell of a lot lower than they are now and it was a lot easier to start a new business in those days when we had far less government intervention and far less Federal intervention in the affairs of state. Indeed, if we had an economic environment today which is similar to the economic environment of the Robert Menzies years-as many older Australians will remember, but I cannot-perhaps we would not be in the mess we are in. Later in my remarks I will refer to the human tragedy and how it affects older people. I am sure that many of those older Australians think back to the Menzies days and compare them with the days of the Hawke Government-the second longest serving Prime Minister. What a terrible comparison that is.

Senator Richardson also referred to Australia's reliance on our resources industries. He has been known to advocate that Australia should not be reliant on its resources and he, more than any other Australian, has done much to ensure that Australia can no longer rely on its resources. During his term as the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories he had the dubious distinction of stopping many resource projects which could now be contributing to our national income. This is the problem that this Government's strange policies have inflicted upon Australia-policies which change from month to month and week to week--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens have put us in the red.

—That is a good comment. Indeed, Senator Richardson and his mate the Treasurer, Paul Keating, have put this country into the red to the tune of about $132 billion-a debt that my children and my children's children will be paying off long after I am pushing up the daisies.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point Senator Richardson made-which was repeated by Senator Crowley-concerns the question of work force skills and skills training. He talked about the Government's great record in trying to train the work force. I put it to the Senate and to the Australian people that when Federal and State governments-particularly Labor Federal and State governments-start trying to come up with training schemes and skills schemes in order to fit Australia's youth and unemployed people for employment, one should really start to wonder about the `picking winners' approach. If I had to leave it to someone to train my children, or any children, in order to increase their skills so that they could participate in the work force, the last people I would leave it to would be those in the Federal Government.

One of the problems which the next Hewson Liberal Government will solve is that private enterprise is given a greater incentive to become involved in that training-not through forcing compulsory levies upon it or forcing the Government's own ideas about training and skills upon it and trying to pick the direction of the economy, but by allowing the private sector to really get involved. If government got off the back of business and allowed business to do its own training to increase the skills of the work force through the private sector, the work force would become skilled far more quickly.

The comments made by Dr Hewson whilst he was in New Zealand were referred to. I heard them repeated by Senator Crowley and Senator Richardson. Quite frankly, the comments Dr Hewson made were quite sensible. He is talking about cutting out benefits which are going to people who do not need them. If one were to walk down the main streets of our capital cities, stop Australians and ask them about the problems that need to be solved in the Australian economy-as I do quite regularly and as I have done through a recent survey of young people in Australia-one would find that they always comment that we have to stop wasteful government expenditure and stop paying the dole to people who do not need it.

I guess that is cheap political rhetoric these days, but we do need to cut out wasteful government benefits. That is all that Dr Hewson has been saying. If Senator Giles or anyone else wants to dispute what Dr Hewson is saying, let them do it. They should not repeat only the quotes that suit them; let them come up with solutions.

The other furphy put forward by Senator Richardson was the nine-month idea; that is, that the Liberal Party of Australia would leave people who have been unemployed for nine months out in the cold on the scrap heap. That is absolute rubbish and Senator Richardson knows it. It is a disgrace that he would come into the Senate and continue to mislead the Senate and the Australian public about this matter. Policies are always under review after an election, but the policy as it stands at the moment is that a special benefit would apply after the nine-month period. Eligibility criteria would be tightened up and these criteria would relate to outside assistance and an activity test, as to what sorts of activities people were undertaking when looking for a job. I do not think any Australian would deny that that is an appropriate response. People who have been unemployed for nine months should, clearly, have to face other eligibility tests. That is all we are saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was mischievous in what he said.

—As Senator Patterson has said, the comments of Senator Richardson and Senator Crowley were mischievous and designed to mislead the public. At the end of Senator Richardson's contribution-if one could call it that-he resorted to the class struggle. He resorted to the fact that the Liberals do not care about unemployed people; that we would put them onto the scrap heap. He said that the Government cares more about the unemployed than we do. Of course, that is an absolute load of rubbish. It debases the political debate if we have to resort to saying, `We care more than you do'. Senator Spindler went down that same track also.

SPEECH.PARA: Young Australians and unemployed Australians do not want money thrown at them; they do not want to become dependent on the Government. They want a healthy economy, some hope for the future and some hope that they will be able get a job. If they cannot get a job they want to know that they have a government which is prepared to put in place a safety net which will encourage them to go out and look for work. The Liberal Party will never resile from that commitment. Our commitment to helping the less fortunate is well documented and well understood and it is on the record. It does not need to be questioned by Senator Graham Richardson or anyone else.

I now want to refer to my home State, where the rate of unemployment leads Australia. We lead Australia in many areas, but this is one area where no Western Australian would be proud to claim leadership. In the last 12 months the level of unemployment in Western Australia has risen from 60,200 to 94,200 people who want work but cannot get it.

As to regional areas, in the northern metropolitan division, which takes in the electorates of Stirling and Cowan in particular, the increase in unemployment has gone from 8,500 individuals to 19,200. It is a 125 per cent increase. I guess many people in those electorates who voted for the Labor Party or the Australian Democrats at the last election would feel a bit stupid now, and what a shame. The situation in the southern suburbs is no better.

Senator Patterson referred to some remarks by Senator Richardson when the Labor Party came into power in 1983, where he said that this Government would sink or swim on job creation. The only job creation that this Government can claim real credit for is the job creation for its mates. On the latest count, Labor Party mates have been given 872 jobs by the Hawke Administration. Clearly, the most obvious one at the moment is the job given to Ambassador Burke. Of course, that has gone by the wayside today but former Labor members of parliament, such as Barry Cunningham; John Brumby; the former New South Wales Labor Minister for Roads, George Paciullo; Jim Spiegelman; Pamela O'Neil; and Peter Cleeland, among 872 mates of the Labor Party-are in cosy government jobs. They do not feel threatened by this unemployment crisis. They do not feel threatened by not being able to buy their children shoes to wear to school tomorrow. They are safe, they are sound, they are the mates of this Government and theirs are the only jobs that this Government can claim are permanent jobs-it has jobs which are safe from the cool winds of this economic recession.

I did not want to concentrate all of my time on the negative aspects of this. I want to finalise my contribution today by looking at some of the things that Australia needs to do to for young Australians, young families, middle aged Australians who are out of work, the farmers, the pastoralists who have had their chequebooks taken away from them and the elderly people who sit in their homes, who have been through the Great Depression, been through the war and watched politics in Australia unfold during the 1980s with a sinking heart. If I were a 70- or 80-year old looking at what has happened to Australia under this Hawke Government, with all the great hope that it came to power with in 1983 and seeing what has actually happened, I would think back on my life and think what a great waste of all of Australia's great resources and natural talent have been frittered away. When those old people see what is left for their grandchildren and their great grandchildren, one would really have to be concerned for how they will leave Australia.

Australians need some hope and what needs to be done is to change the policies of this Government. We need to ensure that mining and exploration for minerals does carry on, that Australia's great natural resources are not wasted and that our secondary and tertiary industries are able to succeed but that in the meantime we do not make it so hard to get a new mine off the ground, such as is happening in the Kakadu National Park at the moment, that our national income deteriorates.

There are so many other industries, such as tourism, where we are constrained by the regulation on international flights, by the moribund decision-making process about the third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport; by development approvals for tourism developments; by stupid Foreign Investment Review Board guidelines which make it very hard to make a tourism development viable these days; and, of course, by the airports' holiday leave loadings and penalty rates, which make the tourism industries non-viable at the moment. There are many areas of reform required. This Government has had eight years to put things right. It has not put them right and the Australian people are looking forward to hope for the future. That hope is Dr John Hewson's next Liberal Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the penultimate speaker in this matter of public importance this afternoon I find that we are going over ground that has been quite thoroughly worked in various similar debates over the last two or three months. There is not very much enlightenment from the Opposition as a result of its initiative in raising the issue again, although I am not denying for a moment that it is an extremely important issue. I should have thought, though, given the opportunity for these frequent debates, that we might have some indication of some really splendid policy development. Unfortunately, once again we are disappointed.

SPEECH.PARA: I have emphasised every time I have spoken on this issue that we are a very different society from the one that the Hawke Government inherited in 1983. There were inferior income supports; an inequitable tax system in which many of the wealthiest barely and rarely paid tax; a low school retention rate; failure to index benefits; household incomes which had grown by only 5 1/2 per cent in eight years; and a poorly administered and taken up family income supplement scheme. There was no national scheme to ensure that non-custodial parents complied with court orders for maintenance. There had been repeated attacks on what had been a universal health scheme-Medibank-and many people lacked medical coverage.

In the intervening years there have been substantial income improvements at the household level across the community generally. Real household disposable incomes per capita grew by 12.4 per cent between March 1983 and September 1990, comparing with a growth of only 5 1/2 per cent for the previous seven years. Child poverty has been at the forefront of many of our initiatives. At present more than half a million families, including 1.2 million children, are being helped with family allowance supplement payments or the equivalent in extra pensions and benefits. As I have noted before, the average payment to families who are entitled to this payment is something like $50 a week tax free. That payment is indexed, as are all our social security benefits.

Pensions and benefits have increased in real terms, and the tax burden on pensioners has been reduced. The pension is now worth slightly over 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. The value of the single pension has increased by very nearly 10 per cent in real terms since March 1983, and the majority of age and service pensioners were freed from tax liability from July 1990. This is very easy to forget unless one happens to be in that particular group.

Taxation has been made a great deal more equitable. Pensioners and families on low incomes have benefited from the increase since 1983 of the tax-free threshold and the reduction in the lowest marginal rate from 32 to 20 per cent. A great may more people are actually paying their tax and we are seeing a degree of redistribution from the wealthy to the most poverty stricken-the lowest income groups in this country-that many of us would not have thought possible a few years ago.

Health care has changed considerably, Medicare being the cornerstone of our health policy with nearly two million people who previously had no health cover now being protected by Medicare. School retention has already been mentioned this afternoon. If there is one policy which is going to make a long term difference to the opportunities of Australians of every age, it is that there are far more people staying within the school system and improving their employability. Over 60 per cent of children now stay on to year 12, and in 1982 only 36 per cent of students were in that category.

We have introduced considerable reforms into the housing sector: a new Commonwealth-State housing agreement; rental rebates are going to public housing tenants in quite substantial numbers-they have been increased from 52 per cent in 1981-82 to 72 per cent in 1987-88; and dwelling commencements have averaged 142,000 a year since the Australian Labor Party came into office, considerably more than the average during the previous Government.

People with disabilities are the beneficiaries of an improved set of policies introduced by Government and considerably increased education, training and employment opportunities-a matter which is of great importance for that particular and quite substantial sector of the community. Our child support scheme has also made an enormous difference to the living standards of those very many families where the non-custodial parents managed to avoid their responsibilities until quite recently.

This afternoon in this debate reference has been made to participation rates. I would like again to emphasise the fact that, amongst the coalition and also the Australian Democrats, there seems to be a fair amount of confusion about, first of all, who collects the data that is used and distributed monthly in the unemployment statistics; secondly, what the statistics mean; and, thirdly, what their significance is in the longer term.

For a start it is not the Government which collects these statistics; it is not the Commonwealth Employment Service which collects them; nor is it the Department of Social Security. The Australian Bureau of Statistics collects the figures. Therefore, these figures result from household surveys and other such methods of collecting from sample groups. Those people who do not seem to understand still apparently assume that we finish up with a big question mark about the statistics, which are said to fail to represent the hidden unemployed. The figures that we have these days are much more accurate and reliable than they have been in the past.

Although we are once again seeing an increase in unemployment, we are also seeing a slight increase in employment participation rates-that is, rates representing those individuals over 15-years of age who are in the work force, regardless of whether they are employed or unemployed. Again in seasonally adjusted terms, the figure, in total, is 75.4 per cent. For females, there has been a continuing increase from 51.8 per cent in April last year to 52.3 per cent in April this year. The total increase for persons has been from 63.5 per cent in April 1990 to 63.7 per cent in 1991, which indicates that there has been a substantial increase in those who identify with the work force. There also has been, in real terms, an increase in the number of people in the work force. The Government is particularly pleased with its success in achieving and maintaining high labour force participation rates, even though the unemployment rates do not look good at all.

High job growth since 1983 has encouraged people to enter the work force; to identify with the work force; and, in many cases, to enhance their employment opportunities. As I said before, the labour force participation rate now stands at 63.7 per cent-3.3 per cent higher than when this Government came to office and 0.2 per cent higher than it was in April 1990.

The other point that keeps confusing the Opposition is that of unemployment among young people. Just because people between the ages of 15 and 19 are not in the work force, it does not necessarily mean that they are unemployed. Some of them certainly are, but, as we have pointed out time and time again, the number of young people who are staying within the education system has been greatly enhanced. Over the 12 months to March 1991, 39,000 more 15-to 19-year-olds attended school or a tertiary educational institution full time-an increase of about 5 per cent. Along with the decrease of 30,000 in the 15-to 19-year-old population, reflecting the slowdown in Australia's birth rate in the early 1970s, this accounts for all of Senator Michael Baume's `hidden unemployed'. They are not hidden at all. They are there in the statistics in relation to those in full time or part time education.

A decline in full time employment of teenagers over the last year does not represent a rise in unemployment among teenagers. The calculations that have been used by Senator Baume and others in the Opposition do not consider the number who may have returned to school, who may be employed part time, or who are otherwise outside those technically employed. It is very foolish of Senator Baume and others to simply rely on the figures and not to look at the definitions at the beginning of every document that comes from the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

As have others, I have recently been in New Zealand. I was very interested to hear the reference that has been made this afternoon to the Opposition's plan to end entitlement to unemployment benefit after nine months. This is exactly the phenomenon that is apparent in New Zealand where, unlike the Australian Labor Party or the New Zealand Labour Party, the National Party Government's response to recession has been to reduce benefits generally by 10 per cent. That usually represents up to $30 a week. In some circumstances, a waiting period of 26 weeks has been imposed. I was interested to see in the Wellington newspaper, the Dominion, on 2 May 1990, the headline `More get special benefits after cuts'. The article read:
More beneficiaries have been receiving special benefits to top up their income since basic benefits were cut on April 1.

This is exactly what we are saying in response to the coalition's plan to cut out unemployment benefits and to make people rely on special benefits. They say that people are not going to starve; they are not going to be without income. But let me tell you why special benefit is a totally inappropriate form of income support for the unemployed. It is not linked to labour market assistance, it is not work tested, and it is not subject to an income test. Therefore, it completely discourages part time and casual employment. As I have commented before, the Opposition has also offered nothing concrete in the way of labour market training for the unemployed, although, during the last election campaign, it stated that it would reduce labour market program expenditure.

I wonder whether the coalition also has in mind some of the other recent measures that have been taken by the conservatives in New Zealand. Along with cutting back on social security benefits, the New Zealand `economeritricians', as I like to call them, have simultaneously introduced a new employment law-the Employment Contracts Act. This has meant that low income earners-from the less skilled, poorly organised sectors of the work force-particularly those employed by small business, are now expected to bargain on equal terms with their employers. All the tired cliches are being invoked-the ones that we hear from the Opposition in Australia: `a level playing field', `freedom of association', `the rights of the individual'-but very few are impressed by such obfuscation.

In a widely distributed document, a group of New Zealand Catholic priests expressed deep reservations about the new legislation. Freedom of association, they said, really meant freedom to dissociate. According to the bishops, the emphasis on freedom of choice failed to balance this concept with concern for the common good-that is, the public good. They could not accept the legislation:
. . . secondly because it emphasises the rights of the individual without their accompanying duty to act in solidarity and without giving any corresponding rights to the groups.

The bishops are in no doubt that this industrial measure is extremely harsh, extremely inequitable and, in their words, extremely unchristian. The only protection for the least well qualified is a set of poor minimum standards. For those under the age of 20, there is not even a minimum wage.

Is that what the Australian conservatives are planning-a system without a proper safety net? We have heard nothing about their safety net; nothing about their plans to stimulate the labour market; and nothing about their plans to train, to retrain or to educate. We deplore this recession and its effects on individuals and families as much as the Opposition does. Our system of income maintenance supports and education and training are the best responses in the long term to the needs and aspirations of Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The world's greatest Treasurer, Mr Keating, once spoke about `a beautiful set of figures'. They were not these figures, because the figures that we have in front of us are a particularly ugly set of figures. I have spoken about them in that way in another context earlier today. They are ugly because they reveal this Government's comprehensive inability to deliver a bright future for the young people of Australia. The young people of Australia have spent their lives listening to excuses, to explanations of why last year's plan has created this year's lost opportunities. I tell this Senate now that the patience of those young people has run out.

SPEECH.PARA: During the past few months I have spoken to thousands of these young people. They are angry; they are angry across the whole country; they are angry because they have a common fear that they are being forced into study or training programs with little prospect of employment after years of subsistence living as a student.

Some of the matters raised by Senator Baume are true and are worthy of our great concern. Of particular concern to me is a problem with the definition of what is employed and, therefore, what is unemployed. If, as Senator Baume says, a person engaging in voluntary work or work experience for as little as one hour a week is regarded as being ineligible for the unemployment benefits that should be paid to such a person, the policy or definition that establishes that idea is stupid. It defies common sense and defies the capacity of a young person to increase his or her employability.

I also agree that many students are what could be considered as hidden unemployed. On the basis of the accuracy of the statistics issued by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, which I think were compiled by the ABS in household surveys, Senator Giles challenged that. We did not hear a proper exposition of the definition of employed or unemployed. I mean, and common sense dictates, that the hidden unemployed are those who are unwillingly classified as students or as being in the voluntary work force but are really unemployed but not counted as such. They are hidden because they are falsely described as students or voluntary workers. That is what I mean by hidden unemployed and commonsense would agree with that definition.

The young people who are so affected are not stupid enough to put themselves in that classification and not stupid enough to accept what I previously described as a stupid definition. They are people who know that the process work, the assembly jobs, and the packaging jobs are being exported while we in Australia sit on our hands and watch the ridiculous dismantling of our tariff structures. We are exporting jobs overseas. These young people have quickly understood that this Government has failed in its responsibility to use wisely this country's physical and human resources to guarantee a prosperous future for its youth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —At a time when the figures show the greatest increase in monthly unemployment since the series began, the Senate has had to witness today a response from the Government which, I say, has been disgusting. As Senator Campbell said, Senator Richardson blamed the situation on Bob Menzies and the Opposition of the time, presumably Arthur Calwell, Gough Whitlam, and so on. Then two other backbenchers-Senator Crowley and Senator Giles-came in and attempted to defend the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I was surprised to hear Senator Giles say that employment had increased. She is half right. Part time employment has increased but full time jobs have been slashed. That is the disheartening factor about all of this. We are getting under-employment impoverishment. The fact of the matter is that the policies pursued by Senator Giles and persons like her push mothers into the paid work force, and create a situation where families have to rely on two incomes, and perhaps three, to make ends meet. Those are their policies. That is the problem. She and the Government are as guilty of discrimination against women employed not in the paid work force but in the home, and those who, having been forced into the paid work force, are now forced out of it and left for dead by the Government.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO ABORIGINAL DEATHS IN CUSTODY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the final 11 volumes of the Report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody as per the list circulated in the chamber. I seek leave to have a ministerial statement made by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) relating to the Royal Commission incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The report I have just tabled is an historic document.
It is a report which must command the attention not only of the Governments and the Parliaments of Australia but of the nation itself.

The Royal Commission evolved into an unprecedented national inquiry into the conditions of Australia's indigenous people operating under Letters Patent issued by the Governor-General, Governors in all States, and the Administrator of the Northern Territory.
The 11 volumes of the Report, ranging over 5,000 pages and containing 339 recommendations, provide an agenda for the nation over the coming decade.

As Honourable Senators are aware, one of the priority objectives of this Government has been to build a movement of cross-party and community support for initiatives in Aboriginal Affairs. This objective will take on greater significance as Governments across Australia respond to the Royal Commission Report.

The Royal Commission was established on 16 October 1987 and inquired into the deaths of 99 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the custody of police, in prison or in youth detention institutions. It also investigated action taken by authorities subsequent to these deaths.

The inquiry was established with the support of the Federal Opposition and, as the direct result of the perception of both Aboriginal and nonAboriginal people, that Aboriginal deaths in custody were both far too common and the public explanations too sketchy to discount the possibility of foul play.
Commissioner James Muirhead QC was requested to report by 31 December 1988.
The huge scale of this task became evident only too soon.

Commonwealth and State Letters Patent were subsequently amended to increase the number of Commissioners to 5, to extend reporting deadlines and to extend the Royal Commission's jurisdiction to the important social, cultural and legal factors contributing to the deaths. Mr Elliott Johnston QC became National Commissioner in April 1989.
At the outset I would place on record this Government's appreciation of the work of Commissioners Johnston, Muirhead, Wyvill, O'Dea, Dodson, Wootton and their staff.

The Royal Commission has examined in close detail both the lives and the deaths of the individuals concerned, and the huge range of social and historical factors operating to produce the situations these people faced. Public hearings were held, families were represented by legal counsel, relevant people were interviewed wherever possible, and all aspects of custodial care and legal processes were examined. The views of Aboriginal people were sought, particularly through the work of the Aboriginal Issues Units. Reports on the circumstances of individual deaths have been presented in the relevant jurisdictions and tabled as they became available.
I know I can speak for the Parliament in expressing on this occasion the deepest sympathy to the relatives of the deceased.

Although some individual reports recommend consideration of further action against individuals, the Royal Commission's Final Report does not accord with initial expectations of foul play. The Commissioners have not found that any deaths were the result of deliberate unlawful violence or brutality by police or prison officers. To that extent, families and friends in their continuing grief and anger have found the findings of individual reports difficult to accept. But, they cannot, I think, doubt the sincerity, dedication and compassion with which the Commissioners have carried out their task.

Nevertheless, the Report stands as an indictment of the operation of the legal and corrective services system in respect of the most disadvantaged group in Australian society, and of our society itself in allowing that situation to develop and to persist. The Royal Commission finds that there has been a failure to live up to the standard of care owed to those in custody; it has found many system defects and many individual failures to exercise proper care and basic human compassion.

Particularly prior to the establishment of the Royal Commission, in very few cases were initial investigations into deaths other than perfunctory and limited in focus, leading inevitably to deteriorating relationships between Aboriginal people and the broader community; to increased anguish and cynicism on the part of families and friends; and to neglect of opportunities to avoid future deaths.

The Report contains an extensive charter of law reform relating to the criminal justice system, police and prison authorities which falls primarily within the responsibility of State and Territory Governments.
