The recommendations range through the full extent of the criminal justice system to include: diversion from police custody; imprisonment as a last resort; reform of police and prison practices; and reform of custodial health and safety practices including a formal recognition of the States' duty of care to those held in custody. The Report also makes wide-ranging recommendations about future post-death investigations and the independent monitoring of deaths in custody.

On all these issues, I must stress that this Royal Commission Report must not be seen as some prison officer or police bashing exercise. It is not. The Report puts forward constructive and practical proposals for law reform. Significantly, it acknowledges that improvements have already been made in Aboriginal-police relations and puts forward proposals to further advance this process.
It is vital that Aboriginal communities and Aboriginal organisations such as Aboriginal legal services play a key role in developing these reforms.

I turn now to Commissioner Johnston's consideration of the issues underlying Aboriginal deaths in custody. In response to this aspect of its work, the Royal Commission has proposed a transformation of Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal community relations in this country.

Put simply, too many Aboriginal people are in custody too often. They are over-represented in custody at a rate-calculated nationally-of 29 times that of the general community. In some States this rate is considerably higher.
As a result Aboriginal people die in custody at rates that have been the focus of international attention. The circumstances of these deaths are set out in Chapter 3 of Volume 1 of the Report.

Thirty of the 99 deaths resulted from hanging. In those 30 cases, the following objects were among those used for suspension: strips of sheeting, strips of blanket, football socks, a length of electric flex, a belt, the sleeve of a jacket, a shirt, a mattress cover, a shoelace, the sleeve of a cardigan, a bandage, and a pair of jeans.
Other deaths occurred as the result of shocking self-mutilation such as a razor to the throat and the driving of a paint brush into the eye.
I give these examples not to sensationalise or shock but to bring to the Senate a sense of the human tragedy which underlies a death in custody.
The finding that foul play on the part of authorities was not a factor in the deaths in no way diminishes the standing of the Royal Commission or undermines the reasons for its establishment.
History will record that the Royal Commission has played a vital role in laying open before us the harshness and oppression experienced by so many contemporary Aboriginal Australians.
Consider this damning picture of the lives and deaths of these 99 predominantly young Aboriginal Australians.
- The average age at death was only 32 years.
- Of the 99 Aboriginal people who died, 43 had experienced childhood separation from their natural families through intervention by State authorities, missions or other institutions.
- 83 of the 99 were unemployed at the date of their last detention.
- 43 of the 99 had been charged with an offence at or before the age of 15.
- Only 2 of the 99 had completed secondary schooling.

- 43 of the 99 were taken into custody in the period immediately before their deaths on matters directly related to the over-use of alcohol and, in the remaining cases, the Royal Commission concluded that alcohol was a contributing factor in their being taken into custody for the last time.
- The Royal Commission concluded that the standard of health of the 99-whose average age was 32-varied from poor to very bad.
The average age of those dying from natural causes was a little over 30 years.

There are many reasons why I am proud to be Australian but these statistics can be no source of pride for any of us in this Parliament, to any elected representative at any level of Government in the country or to any non-Aboriginal Australian.
Fundamentally, the disproportionate number of Aboriginal people in custody stems from the underlying factors which bring Aboriginal people into contact with the law in the first place.

The Report finds that the single most significant contributing factor to incarceration is the disadvantaged and unequal position of Aboriginal people in Australian society in every way, whether socially, economically or culturally.

Much of the National Report, and the associated regional reports, is devoted to demonstrating the existence of that inequality and disadvantage. The Report documents, in a way never before achieved, the impact of European settlement upon Australia's indigenous peoples, their dispossession and subordination within a dominant and often hostile society frequently motivated by self-interest, the development of racist attitudes both overt and hidden and the way in which these attitudes became institutionalised in the very practices of legal, educational, welfare and Aboriginal assistance authorities.

That these attitudes were themselves the product of a particular time and society, and often well intentioned, does not excuse our society from attempting the task of reconciliation and redressing disadvantage.

The Report documents the impact of these things upon the lives of individual people, and the way that impact continues to be felt and demonstrated today, especially where Aboriginal people have lost their way and where despair and hopelessness have been bred of the destruction of Aboriginal culture and the stifling of independence and initiative. The Report demonstrates the close link between this continuing inequality and disadvantage and the refuge sought in alcohol over-use, and high custody rates for Aboriginal people.
It refutes at every level the myth sometimes put forward that the special assistance available for Aboriginal people has put them in a position above that enjoyed by other Australians.
It is evident that there are no quick and easy answers to these continuing problems.
There is, however, one principle which looms large as central to change for Aboriginal people. The Royal Commission describes as fundamental the issues of empowerment and self-determination.

As a senior and experienced lawyer with considerable knowledge of Aboriginal issues, Commissioner Johnston acknowledges that he had no real idea of the degree of ``pin pricking domination, abuse of personal power, utter paternalism, open contempt and total indifference'' which confronted Aboriginal people in their everyday lives, with no personal control over one's own children, one's employment, personal savings and decisions as to whether to buy a car or other personal belongings. He points out that communities today are still faced with a multiplicity of grants which effectively mean that agendas are being set elsewhere, that assumptions as to what is best for Aboriginal people are made elsewhere.

Commissioner Johnston highlights what he describes as the first prerequisite of the empowerment of Aboriginal society-the will for renewal and for self-determination. He also stresses the important role played by Aboriginal community-based organisations. The role of these organisations is continually emphasised in the recommendations of the Report.
At every level, control of lives and communities must be in Aboriginal hands, in the same way that non-Aboriginal Australians expect to control their lives and communities.

For this to happen, the Report makes clear, Aboriginal Australians must themselves have the will and capacity to put an end to their disadvantaged situation, and to take charge of their lives. Commissioner Johnston quotes impressive evidence of the efforts being made all over Australia by Aboriginal organisations and communities, at the local and wider levels, to demonstrate that this can be done, indeed is already being done. Aboriginal people do have the determination and capacity to succeed.
A prerequisite for Aboriginal self-determination is the creation of conditions which will eliminate the systematic and entrenched disadvantage which permeates every aspect of Aboriginal life.
The Royal Commission's Report contains detailed and comprehensive recommendations to address that disadvantage which are directed to Governments at all levels.

Within the time available to me it is obviously not possible to refer to the hundreds of recommendations to Governments directed towards overcoming the continuing and critical disadvantage suffered by Aboriginal Australians.
However, to convey some understanding of the breadth of those recommendations I note that they include, in no order of priority:
- A national survey of Aboriginal population and infrastructure.
- Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments to develop a system of single block grant funding for Aboriginal communities with a model accounting system.
- Triennial funding of Aboriginal communities.
- The Commonwealth to negotiate with the States and Territories to achieve the equitable distribution of local government funds to Aboriginal residents, as a condition of funding.
- The development of codes of practice by media industry and media unions.
- A progress report on the Australian Law Reform Commission's Customary Law report.

- The urgent provision of funds to enable implementation of the National Aboriginal Health Strategy (and I note that the Commonwealth has already made a significant additional allocation for this purpose).
- Review of liquor licensing legislation, notably in the Northern Territory, with a view to reducing the availability of alcohol and meeting the needs of Aboriginal communities.

- Support for the Aboriginal Employment Development Policy, including specific inter-government agreements on objectives and outcomes, and the establishment of a peak industry body and local industry, community and local government groups to promote employment equity in the private sector.
- A review and extension of the Community Development Employment Program, including to rural towns with large Aboriginal populations.
- The Commonwealth to act to provide a right of individual appeal on human rights violations to international committees.
- Funding be provided to organisations such as Link-Up for the purpose of allowing Aboriginal people to re-establish links with families separated by past Government policies.
- The establishment of a national task force on alcohol abuse.

- An urgent requirement for Governments and Aboriginal organisations to negotiate to devise strategies for Aboriginal youth to reduce the rate at which Aboriginal juveniles are involved in the welfare and criminal justice systems.
- Aboriginal communities to be given equitable access to ongoing expenditure by the Commonwealth, State, Territory and local authorities on roads.

- The Department of Employment, Education and Training be responsible for the development of a comprehensive national strategy designed to improve opportunities for the education and training of those in custody.
- High priority be accorded to the development of social, economic and cultural development plans by Aboriginal communities on a local and a regional basis.
- Recognition that the success of the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Education Policy will depend on the success of pre-schooling initiatives.
- The establishment of a small unit of Aboriginal people from Northern Australia to study the means of achieving greater self-sufficiency in remote northern communities.
- The implementation of a strategy for the training of Aboriginal people to build and maintain essential community infrastructure.
- All jurisdictions, where this has not already occurred, to provide a comprehensive means of addressing the land needs of Aboriginal people.
I turn now to the critical issue of the process to be adopted by Governments in responding to the Royal Commission Report.
Australia has a commendable international human rights record and acknowledges that human rights issues are of international concern.

The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs acknowledged at the United Nations Working Group on Indigenous Populations in Geneva last August that the Government is aware that the Working Group, Amnesty International and other international non-government organisations will be monitoring the implementation of the Royal Commission's recommendations.
In a very real sense the world is watching.
However, our motivation in ensuring a co-ordinated and comprehensive national response to the Royal Commission's Report will not be, and should not be, international scrutiny.

It is the historic and comprehensive nature of the Royal Commission Report, and our commitment as Australians to a fair go for all, which should drive us to ensure such a response. As a nation we must not squander the opportunity presented by the Royal Commission's Report to act on an agenda of reform in Aboriginal Affairs for the coming decade.

Prior to receiving the Royal Commission's Report the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs had already indicated his predisposition to support an open and publicly accountable process to monitor the response of all Governments to the Report.

He was, therefore, gratified that the very first recommendation of the Report proposes a public and comprehensive reporting process by the Commonwealth, States and Territories in consultation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.
Commissioner Johnston also stresses the need for extensive consultation with and involvement of Aboriginal people in the implementation of the Royal Commission's recommendations.

It is a matter of the utmost importance for me to emphasise that the Royal Commission Report does not impact solely on the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio at any level of Government. The Recommendations are addressed to the whole range of Government departments at Commonwealth, State, and Territory levels.
It will be necessary, therefore, for there to be a response from the whole of Government in each Commonwealth, State and Territory jurisdiction.

I report to the Senate that the Prime Minister has asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to assume responsibility for co-ordinating the Commonwealth Government response across all portfolios, supported by the Aboriginal Reconciliation Unit within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

Honourable Senators, this Report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody demands careful consideration by all Governments. Its recommendations have implications for a range of government activities, from Australia's international obligations down to the everyday contacts of individual police, prison, hospital or welfare officers with Aboriginal people and for every Australian. I do not pretend that all the changes proposed can happen quickly, even though a number of recommendations may be capable of relatively rapidly implementation. The recommendations reflect the linkages between many areas of policy affecting Aboriginal people, and point to the need for co-ordinated action between and within Governments.

The Government has already set in train a process for consideration of the Report which acknowledges the status of the Royal Commission as a joint Commonwealth-State investigation, and the overlapping nature of responsibilities in many areas. The Prime Minister has written to Premiers and Chief Ministers of every State and Territory seeking their co-operation in a joint strategy of response.

The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs will be meeting with Ministers from those portfolios most immediately concerned in the near future to discuss the implications of the Report and to agree on a timetable for implementation. The need for empowerment is at the heart of many Recommendations, and Governments will need to allow adequate time for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people themselves to consider the Report and formulate a response.

I turn now to what is the final and perhaps the most important Recommendation of the Report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I appeal to all Senators and to the wider community to give this section of the Report deep consideration.

As Honourable Senators would be aware, last December the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs issued a Discussion Paper as the basis of future legislation to enable our nation to embark on a process of reconciliation between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians.

As I said earlier, it has been a fundamental objective of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to create a climate of cross-party co-operation in and community support for significant progress in Aboriginal Affairs.
He was, for this reason, delighted by the final Recommendation of the Royal Commission Report which states:

``that all political leaders and parties recognise that reconciliation between the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal communities in Australia must be achieved if community division, discord and injustice to Aboriginal people are to be avoided. To this end the Commission recommends that political leaders use their best endeavours to ensure bi-partisan public support for the process of reconciliation and that the urgency and necessity of the process be acknowledged.''

In discussing the framework of the Report and the other Recommendations in the Report, the Royal Commission describes the reconciliation process as ``the fundamental backdrop to reform and change.'' The Royal Commission further states that reconciliation of the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal communities must be an essential commitment of all sides if change is to be genuine and long term.

As the Royal Commission observes, the process of reconciliation proposed by the Government will have as a principal focus the need to educate nonAboriginal Australians about the cultures of Australia's indigenous peoples and the treatment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people by European settlers and their descendants. This sad history-which includes the dispossession and dispersal of Aboriginal people, confinement in reserves, removal of children from their families and the destruction of much Aboriginal culture-needs to be recognised as a primary cause of the current disadvantaged position of Australia's indigenous peoples. All Australians need to understand this country's past and the place of Aboriginal people in it. This would have the objective not of creating guilt, but of building compassion and empathy for Aboriginal people and their disadvantaged position in society, as well as appreciation of Aboriginal cultures and achievements, and the unique position of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as the indigenous peoples of this continent.
The Royal Commission recognises, as does the Government, four key issues essential to the process of reconciliation:
- the taking of concrete measures to tackle disadvantage and establish self-determination as being essential building blocks of the process of reconciliation;
- the reconciliation process must have cross-party support and support from Aboriginal people;
- the focus should concentrate on the process of reconciliation and not on a document or instrument which might be one of the outcomes; and
- the process should not be impeded by either Aboriginal or non-Aboriginal people setting pre-conditions in advance.

The Report suggests that, if we are to remove the cause of distrust and enmity between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people and build good community relations, we must not only eliminate existing disadvantage but also recognise Aboriginal rights, cultures and traditions. This process of reconciliation must carry with it a complete rejection of the concepts of superiority and inferiority which have informed Australian society over the past 200 years.
Importantly, the Royal Commission's Report emphasises the extent of past cross-party co-operation in Aboriginal Affairs.

The Report traces the history of Aboriginal Affairs policy and recognises that the first step in the reconciliation process-and the one which received the clearest endorsement from the Australian people-was the 1967 referendum.

In the words of Commissioner Johnston, ``since 1967 there has been an evolution of thought on the part of non-Aboriginal Australians which has been reflected in the actions of successive Commonwealth Governments irrespective of party composition.''
In the final chapter of the Report, the Royal Commission chronicles in some detail the changes which have occurred.
The Report also recognises the widespread community support which, at the time of writing, had already been forthcoming for the process of reconciliation.

I can report to the Senate that the groundswell of support for the reconciliation process has continued with endorsement coming from a wide range of Aboriginal organisations and individuals as well as from diverse sections of the non-Aboriginal community.

I have a responsibility on the occasion of the tabling of this Report to invite the Opposition to join with the rest of the Australian Parliament and give unanimous backing to the proposal for the Process of Reconciliation endorsed by the Royal Commission.

I embrace wholeheartedly the concluding aspiration of the Royal Commission, that ``in the end, perhaps together, Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal, the situation can be reached where this ancient, subtly creative Aboriginal culture exists in friendship alongside the non-Aboriginal culture. Such an achievement would be a matter of pride not only for all Australians but for all humankind.''

If Australia, as a nation, had been able to achieve this recognition and reconciliation before this date, these tragic deaths may have been prevented. We might have been able to spare families the suffering they have experienced.
It is not too late, however, for other deaths to be prevented. The Royal Commissioners have given us their insights, their advice and a clear direction for change.

The families of those who have died, and indeed all Australians, have a right to expect that governments at all levels and of all political persuasions will act together to ensure that change takes place.
I commend the Report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement and documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody and the ministerial statement that have been presented to the Senate today are indeed historic documents. They are also very disturbing documents and they contain issues and matters that should preoccupy the attention of this Senate, this Parliament, State parliaments, the Parliament of the Northern Territory, and the Parliament of the Australian Capital Territory for some time and in some considerable depth. They demand close attention by anyone who is involved in public administration and in ensuring that community relations continue to operate in a satisfactory and impartial manner throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: When we talk about deaths in custody it is very easy to put the problem aside because the preoccupation in the media on this issue in the past number of years has dealt almost exclusively with deaths in custody of Aboriginal people. It would be very concerning if, because of the depth of this particular inquiry, the attention it has received and the information that is in the document presented here today, which all relate to the deaths of Aboriginal people, that was the entire focus of policy changes and revisions in the next few years. We must be aware that there are deaths in custody of other members of the community as well as those of Aboriginal people. We need to state from the outset that this issue, whilst it is terribly important to the Aboriginal community in Australia, is a much wider problem and should not be dealt with exclusively as an Aboriginal problem.

I hope that the particular report and document that have been presented today will not just get filed away in parliamentary libraries or become documents that are suitable for academic research in future or for public service departments and bureaucracies to quote back at us from time to time when they want justification for a line of expenditure in a Government department. It is very easy to hide issues such as this and to ease our conscience by knowing that there is a significant report and, knowing that the report is there, to put it aside knowing that someone else will deal with it.

The cost of preparing this report for this Parliament is $31m. That is an extremely high cost for the value. Unfortunately, I believe, like many other senators and many other people that, when the report was instigated a number of years ago, a number of us stood back and said that there would be a certain predictability about the recommendations that would arise, that nothing new would be learnt and that, essentially, the problem for the Aboriginal community was alcohol related.

Unfortunately, all those things are true. The predictability of what has emerged in the recommendations was well stated before the inquiry got under way. I have been unable to glean anything new from an initial reading of the ministerial statement or from a cursory glance at the 11 volumes of the report. Certainly, the relationship between alcohol and the problem has been acknowledged in the ministerial statement. We are told on page 4:

Forty-three of the 99 were taken into custody in the period immediately before their deaths on matters directly related to the overuse of alcohol and, in the remaining cases, the Royal Commission concluded that alcohol was a contributing factor in their being taken into custody for the last time.

What a damning statement of the problem in our community. There is a recognition that, for every one of the 99 cases that were investigated by this inquiry, alcohol was found to be either a primary cause or an associated cause of the death of the person.

Of course, the report has always looked at the issue from the perspective of the Aboriginal victim. I hope that when we have the time to look through the 11 volumes, we will try to assess their contents from the basis of looking at the wider issues in the community generally. Certainly, there are issues concerning the past treatment of members of the Aboriginal society in Australia over the past 200 years. These issues have been recognised and picked up by the various Commissioners who have looked at this report.
I also want to highlight the fact that, after spending $31m of taxpayers' money on a major inquiry of this nature, it is very interesting to note that the reports have concluded:
Although some individual reports recommend consideration of further action against individuals, the Royal Commission's Final Report does not accord with initial expectations of foul play.

The fact that the Commissioners were able to identify the finding that no deaths were the result of deliberate, unlawful violence or brutality by police or by prison officers is something that we need to recognise. We must recognise that through the course and conduct of this inquiry the police or apprehending authorities were often taken to be the guilty parties. The media concentration on the role of the police was in fact far too extensive and far too problematic in proposing what the issues really were.

There are over 300 recommendations in this report. They range through the full extent of the criminal justice system, and include: diversion from police custody, imprisonment as a last resort, the reform of the police and prison practices and the reform of custodial, health and safety practices, including a formal recognition of the State's duty of care to those held in custody.

Certainly, this whole report highlights the extent of the human tragedy. Not only the Federal Government but State and Territory governments must look closely at each and every recommendation and quickly define where the areas of responsibility must lie.

As I said in my opening remarks, it is interesting to note that the Minister has set out in his statement a series of pictures with regard to the 99 deaths. The average age at death was only 32 years. Of the 99 Aboriginal people who died, 43 had experienced childhood separation from their natural family; 83 of the 99 were unemployed at the date of their last detention; 43 of the 99 had been charged with an offence at or before the age of 15; and only 2 of the 99 had completed secondary education. I highlighted the point earlier that all 99 deaths were in some way alcohol related. The Royal Commission concluded that the standard of health of the 99, whose average age was 32, varied from poor to very bad.

If a similar study was done of all deaths in custody across Australia, we would probably find that conclusions of a similar sociological pattern of definition would be drawn. Therefore, the Aboriginal community should not be identified and singled out as having problems peculiar just to deaths in the Aboriginal community. I believe that a study of deaths in custody in the Australian community would also show a similar pattern in relation to problems relating to the person who committed suicide or died in custody.

I have some reservations about a couple of areas in the ministerial statement that was made today. The Minister seems to be concluding that there is a need for more bureaucracy. We are told that the need to address land rights or the land needs of Aboriginal people is crucial to solving this problem. Towards the end of the ministerial statement, the Minister also says that the issue of a treaty or the issue of an instrument of reconciliation seems to be a way in which the problem can be addressed. That is not the only issue that needs to be addressed. There should not be a preoccupation with limited views that will solve the problem.

Those issues on their own will not solve the problem. They are not the major issues. Land rights, bureaucracy and phoney treaties will not result in fewer deaths of Aboriginal people in custody. Those issues must be taken into account in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio, but people should not conclude that simply pursuing those areas as a matter of policy will achieve a lower rate of Aboriginal deaths in custody. I come back to the strong statement that was made with regard to the alcohol problem. It is interesting to make a comparison between Aboriginal deaths and other deaths of people whilst in police custody. A number of studies were done on this several years ago. As I said, very similar patterns emerge.

As parliamentarians, we have to question whether the same result could have been achieved with less expenditure. The amount of $31.802m is a high price to pay for a report that has been tabled in this place. There has been a degree of predictability in the resulting recommendations in terms of the need for change in the Aboriginal community-in lifestyle, in health, in education and in welfare; in relation to all of the issues that contribute to Aboriginal deaths in custody. Probably at least some $25m of that $31m has been wasted, in my view, and would not have resulted in one less death.

I know I am harping on the issue of Aborigines and alcohol, but I believe that this is the most important and fundamental issue to be addressed if we want to guarantee that there will be fewer deaths. I quote from the editorial of the Australian of 15 April 1991:

Alcohol is killing the Aborigines. Drunk Aborigines, most often men, are killing each other. Men abandon the wives and children of the ` `dry'' communities of the north for the alcohol-flush towns. Or else sly grog seeps into the communities. Too many Aborigines are perpetrators and victims of violent crime. Their health ruined, their families and tribal discipline in disarray, too many Aborigines are dying young.
Further on, the editorial says:

The statistics are stark. In Alice Springs, where 25,000 people live, perhaps 6000 of them Aboriginal, 7000 people were detained for drunkenness in 1988. Last year, 12,770 were detained. Last year, too, there were 12 murders in the town. All involved Aborigines and alcohol. In the Alice, a person is seven times more likely to be murdered than killed on the road. The victim is likely to be Aboriginal and-the figures show quite clearly-so is the killer. Across the nation, Aborigines in their young adulthood through to middle age face mortality rates up to 10 times higher than those of other Australians. Alcohol must bear much of the blame.
Errol Simper's article entitled `Toll soars in battle of the bottle' in the Australian of 13 April 1991 reports the Assistant Commissioner of the Alice Springs police force, Andy McNeill, as saying:

Most of our work involves alcohol and Aborigines. Sexual assaults, criminal damage, drink-driving, stolen vehicles, prowlers, excessive noise. I'm afraid the bulk of it is attributable to drunken Aborigines.

I represent the Northern Territory and the dilemma of this problem worries me daily. I am related to Aborigines. I have Aboriginal nephews and a niece. Because some 25 per cent of my electorate is exposed to this problem and all the other associated areas, I cannot walk away from it. The evil is alcohol. Whether we relate it to deaths in custody or to Senator Richardson's portfolio of Social Security, from where the basic primary income of Aboriginal families is derived, we do need to look at the policies that impact in so many of those areas.

I am critical that Senator Richardson has, with the wipe of a hand, walked away from looking at reasonable changes and the way in which money is paid through the social welfare system in Aboriginal communities, which is so necessary to the well-being and lifestyle of Aboriginal people. But the majority of the cash ends up often being spent on grog and results in the custody of Aboriginal people and the death of Aboriginal people. Unless we get back to some of those fundamental areas of change that are so necessary, although this report and the various commissioners have commented across the whole range, I am concerned that there seems to be a preoccupation in the report with policies for indigenous people, with fundamental changes that will not result in the necessary support systems for social areas that need so much change.

This report, as I said at the outset, is terribly important. It has cost us an arm and a leg. It has cost the Aboriginal community not just the 99 deaths that have been investigated but many more than that. The number of Aboriginal people who die in custody is small compared to the number that die in hospitals, hostels, homes and humpies, yet we have had as a focus of attention in the media for the last decade this constant preoccupation with the criminal system and the penal system. It is much wider than that; it is out in the community. There are many more fundamental problems underlying all of the issues that I do not believe this $31m report has gone anywhere near addressing.

Whilst we all must accept a degree of responsibility for the past, we must also look to the future and guarantee that Aborigines are not, by the policies we make, being locked into the nineteenth century. That is where the preoccupation with treaties, land rights and spirituality issues, which also arose yesterday in the debate on the report of the Resource Assessment Commission, would tend to take the Aboriginal people.

The young Aboriginal people in my constituency, hundreds of whom I meet every month, and in the communities that I walk around, want to participate fully in two cultures: in their own inherited culture and in the society in which they are presently placed. They want to live with dignity and integrity in the twenty-first century. Nothing is going to come from cocooning people in the past. I am concerned that the Minister's statement does not pick up this challenge with sufficient priority or urgency.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I indicate to honourable senators that due to the size of the document tabled today arrangements have been made for the document to be delivered direct to the offices of honourable senators this afternoon. Additional copies are also available on request from the Senate Table Office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I offer my congratulations to the main author of the national report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, Commissioner Elliott Johnston, QC, the other commissioners, Muirhead, Wyvill, O'Dea, Dodson, Wootten, and their staff, for the production of this historic document. We owe them a great debt of gratitude for providing us with a master plan for the conduct of Aboriginal affairs in this country as we approach the centenary of Federation. As a master plan, this report is comprehensive, fair, positive and constructive.

SPEECH.PARA: I have done some postgraduate studies in Aboriginal history and Aboriginal education. I have read some excellent books on Aboriginal issues. However, this report could replace the majority of well thumbed text books in its depth of understanding and its positive suggestions for future action.

At the outset, I make a plea for all of us as human beings, for all governments at all levels, to take this opportunity to build upon this $30m investment in Australia's future. Contrary to Senator Tambling's view, I take the view that $30m is a small investment in social cohesion, equality and justice.
We paid a high price in Queensland for the Fitzgerald inquiry and we are in the process of doubling our return on that investment in far-reaching changes to basic institutional structures.

The report established that a major reason for Aboriginal deaths in custody is the grossly disproportionate rate at which Aboriginal people are taken into custody. It is more than 20 times the rate for non-Aboriginal people. But the report goes on to highlight that, although something can be and is being done to reduce this rate by law reform and changes in policing strategies, there are still issues underlying the alienation of Aboriginal people and their continuing conflict with the law which cannot be solved by police and Aboriginal people alone. I quote from the preface of volume one of the report:

The key is to be found in the hearts and minds of all Australians. It lies in the recognition of the Aboriginal people as a distinct people, the indigenous people of Australia who were cruelly dispossessed of their land and until recent times denied respect as human beings and the opportunity to re-establish themselves on an equal basis.

I was most interested to note that Commissioner Muirhead, at the outset of the Royal Commission, announced that he saw his job as being not merely to understand how each person died-which may simply be of alcohol related causes-but why that person died. Thus this investigation into the deaths of 99 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the custody of police, in prison or in youth detention institutions was extremely thorough. In Commissioner Muirhead's words, `No effort was spared to get to the truth'.

Not only the cause of death but all aspects of custodial care and the orders binding on custodians were critically examined. It is important to raise, as others have, the fact that the commissioners did not find that the deaths were the product of deliberate violence or brutality by police or prison officers, but did find that generally there appeared to be little appreciation of and less dedication to the duty of care owed by custodial authorities and their officers to persons in custody.

The commissioners found many system defects in relation to care, many failures to exercise proper care, and in general a poor standard of care. The commissioners acknowledged that deaths in such circumstances breed anguish and suspicion. I join with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) in making a public expression of sympathy to the relatives of the deceased. I hope that this most thorough and open process of inquiry will have helped to allay those suspicions.

This inquiry has been unique in Australia's history because of its comprehensiveness and because the whole range of societal and historical factors which impact on Aboriginal lives came into focus from the many investigations into the deaths of so many of them which occurred whilst ostensibly under the care and protection of the State. I now turn to some of those societal and historical factors.

I go firstly to role of history. I share the view of Commissioner Johnston that little of Aboriginal history is known to non-Aboriginal people. A knowledge of any people's history is a key factor in assisting an understanding of those people. What we are now is not isolated from where we began. Many Australians know that Aboriginal people were dispossessed of their land without benefit of a treaty, agreement or compensation, but most of them do not know of the widespread violence and brutality associated with that dispossession. Our school textbooks did not consider that to be relevant history.

From this history, many things flow which are of central importance to the issue of this ministerial statement. The first thing is the deliberate and systematic disempowerment of Aboriginal people, starting with their land and proceeding to almost every aspect of their lives. They were made dependent upon government or non-Aboriginal pastoralists or other employers for every basic human need-for rations, clothing and living places. Decisions were made about them, for them, and imposed upon them. The extent of control of their lives seems incredible today, yet I can still remember the incredulity and shared outrage I felt about 15 years ago when an Aboriginal friend of mine in Queensland could not visit a relative on a reserve because the superintendent would not give her permission.

A knowledge of the history of the pattern of State intervention in and control of Aboriginal lives assists us to understand how a loss of independence leads to a loss of self-esteem. It helps us to avoid the convenient response of blaming the victim or blaming alcohol. I agree with Commissioner Johnston when he says that what is remarkable and what must command the respect and admiration of fair-minded people is that Aboriginal society survived all the assaults upon it. In addressing the symptom of the disproportionate number of Aboriginal people in custody, Commissioner Johnston highlights the more fundamental question-the empowerment and self-determination of Aboriginal people.

The Commissioner outlines three essential prerequisites to the empowerment of Aboriginal society: the will to renewal and to self-determination; the role of the broader society; and the policy of self-determination. With respect to the first of these prerequisites, I have just returned from an site inspection of Cape York and Thursday Island by a subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. We visited the Injinoo, New Mapoon, Umagico, Seisia, Bamaga and Thursday Island communities. In each case I am confident that the enthusiasm, the determination and the will to take control of their own lives which was evident will continue to grow. It is my view that recent local government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission elections have had a significant role to play in this feeling of empowerment at the local level.

The second prerequisite is the role of the broader society. I think Commissioner Johnston issues a real challenge to us here: a challenge to avoid simplistic assertions about alcohol, for example; a challenge to understand why our support of this process is necessary; a challenge not to retreat into hysterical stereotypical responses at the mere mention of Aboriginal people and land.

We must acknowledge that the economic base of Aboriginal people was completely destroyed by their being dispossessed of their lands. Their treatment since then has been such that, except to a limited extent in recent times, it has been quite impossible for them to achieve any economic base. That is why our support and government initiatives to legislate that support in respect of land is crucial and totally relevant to the issue of Aboriginal deaths in custody.

Here I make a brief comment about what is happening in my home State of Queensland. In one of his final reports on individual deaths, Commissioner Lew Wyvill says that the relationship between the Aboriginal community and land is `seen to be fundamental to their well-being'. He says that people in the Lockhart River community, where one of the deaths occurred, have been experiencing sudden and multiple pressures on their traditional relationships with land from development proposals for tourism, mining, space base development and freeholding and from already established restrictions on their hunting and gathering and on other uses of national parks. Part of the re-empowering process must involve the restoration to them of the power to draw upon those resources that come from their traditional attachment to the land.

The third prerequisite to the empowerment of Aboriginal people that Commissioner Johnston mentioned is self- determination-having in place an established method, a procedure whereby the broader society can supply the assistance I have referred to and the Aboriginal society can receive it, whilst at the same time maintaining its independent status and without a welfare dependent position being established between the two groups. Self-determination means that Aboriginal people determine their own priorities and set their own agenda.

I was most interested in Commissioner Dodson's words on this aspect of the report. Commissioner Dodson stresses that after what has happened to Aboriginal society people need space, time and distance to think out very carefully what they want to do with their own communities and their lives. He speaks of the need for a maturing of the relationship between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people; a deeper understanding of how each sees the other and why; and a bringing out of the common ground between us-the centrality of being human beings.

Commissioner Dodson suggests that, as Aboriginal people need time, space and distance for thinking through their position, perhaps non-Aboriginal Australia also needs to take some time to think through its position in relation to Aboriginal people and to ask ourselves whether we have not stereotyped Aboriginal people, whether as noble savages, scroungers, horsemen, childlike persons, servants or people addicted to alcohol. In the ultimate, self-determination is basically about people having the right to make decisions concerning their own lives and their own communities, the right to retain their culture and to develop it.

The report makes 339 recommendations and I can say that I have read them. The Minister has listed many of them and I will highlight others which are of importance to me. The fact that some of the recommendations are predictable, as Senator Tambling implied, merely underlines the fact that we have failed to tackle the fundamental issues in Aboriginal affairs over the past two decades in particular. It is absolutely superficial to isolate alcohol as a cause. Alcohol, and the resort to alcohol, is merely a symptom of fundamental causes such as the dispossession of an entire people. I turn now to some of the recommendations. The very first recommendation is an interesting one. The Commissioner recommends:

That the Commonwealth Government and State and Territory Governments, in consultation with ATSIC, agree upon a process which ensures that the adoption or otherwise of recommendations and the implementation of the adopted recommendations will be reported upon on a regular basis with respect to progress on a Commonwealth, State and Territory basis.
In other words, let us act on these recommendations; let us not lose them yet again; and let us report back to parliaments not less than annually. Other recommendations include:
That police standing orders or instructions provide specific directions as to the conduct of investigations into the circumstances of a death in custody.

That Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments provide access to all government archival records pertaining to the family and community histories of Aboriginal people so as to assist the process of enabling Aboriginal people to re-establish community and family links with those people from whom they were separated as a result of past policies of government.
That government and funding bodies reflect the importance of the National Aboriginal Language Policy in the provision of funds to Aboriginal communities and organisations.
That Police Services take all possible steps to eliminate:
a. Violent or rough treatment or verbal abuse of Aboriginal persons, including women and young people, by police officers; and
b. The use of racist or offensive language, or the use of racist or derogatory comments in log books and other documents by police officers.
When such conduct is found to have occurred, it should be treated as a serious breach of discipline.

That Aboriginal people be involved at every level in the development, implementation and interpretation of research into the patterns, causes and consequences of Aboriginal alcohol use and in the application of the results of that research.

That in responding to truancy the primary principle to be followed by Government agencies be to provide support, in collaboration with appropriate Aboriginal individuals and organisations, to the juvenile and to those responsible for the care of the juvenile; such support to include addressing the cultural and social factors identified by the juvenile and by those responsible for the care of the juvenile as being relevant to the truancy.

That the provision of housing and infrastructure to Aboriginal people in remote and discrete communities, including the design and location of houses, take account of their cultural perceptions of the use of living space, and that budgetary allocations include provision for appropriate architectural and town planning advice to, and consultation with, the serviced community.
That, in jurisdictions where drunkenness has not been decriminalized, governments should legislate to abolish the offence of public drunkenness.

That legislation decriminalizing drunkenness should place a statutory duty upon police to consider and utilize alternatives to the detention of intoxicated persons in police cells. Alternatives should include the options of taking the intoxicated person home or to a facility established for the care of intoxicated persons.
That governments which have not already done so should legislate to enforce the principle that imprisonment should be utilized only as a sanction of last resort.

There are many recommendations to the effect that units of Aboriginal history should be included in media studies, in school curricula, in police training units and in courses for journalists. I want to turn to the final recommendation. Recommendation 339 states:

That all political leaders and their parties recognize that reconciliation between the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal communities in Australia must be achieved if community division, discord and injustice to Aboriginal people are to be avoided. To this end the Commission recommends that political leaders use their best endeavours to ensure bi-partisan public support for the process of reconciliation and that the urgency and necessity of the process be acknowledged.

The Democrats acknowledge that urgency and necessity. We accept the Commission's description of the reconciliation process as the fundamental backdrop to reform and change. We have publicly supported the Government's initiation of such a process and we acknowledge how crucial cross-party support is to the success of this process.

Aboriginal people have been dispossessed; that is a fact. Aboriginal people have been imprisoned at a disproportionate rate; that is a fact. Ninety-nine Aboriginal and Islander people have died whilst in prison, in custody or in youth detention centres; that too is a fact. Aboriginal and Islander people have a right to know why this has happened and they have a right to expect that such an incidence of death will not continue.

This report gives such answers and assurances for constructive action. Aboriginal people do not expect us to walk around with our heads hung in shame, but they do expect us to acknowledge our role in their past and their right to control their own future. It is with this in mind that I conclude with the moving words of Commissioner Johnston in the preface to volume 1 of this report:

If other Australians can, in a spirit of justice and humanity, accord Aboriginal people this recognition, give them freedom to determine their own future and find their own place as a distinct people within Australian society, and provide them with the resources that are necessary to overcome the handicaps they suffer as a result of what has happened in the past, there can be hope of a freely negotiated reconciliation between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians. Then there may be an end to the situation where so many Aboriginal people live and die in custody.
It is my view that Aboriginal people are entitled to that hope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody involves problems that we, as a nation, really must try to resolve. One of the problems that emerges from this report is that our honesty, in examining our problems in public, creates an increasing perception internationally that we are a racist and intolerant nation. We are even equated by some people with apartheid in South Africa, particularly as a result of the activities of some extremist activists. This report is largely about perceptions. It is about perceptions of injustices and it is about attitudes. It is an important report in relation to perceptions in the sense that it is seen to have examined the problems of black deaths.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that there has been political bipartisan support for firstly, the inquiry itself and secondly, for the search for solutions to what is, in so many instances, a disastrous problem. It is important to establish first of all that in this report-which, as I said, is to a large extent about perceptions as well as providing a whole range of possible actions that may be taken-the commissioners have not found that any deaths were the result of deliberate, unlawful violence or brutality by police or prison officers. This report is not a police or prison officer bashing exercise and any attempts to either paint it as such or use it as such must be rejected.

However, the Royal Commission did find that there had been a failure to live up to the standards of care owed to those in custody. It found many system defects and many individual failures to exercise proper care and basic human compassion. That, I understand, is equally true of white prisoners and so to that extent it is a general problem.

The Royal Commission noted that, prior to its establishment, in very few cases initial investigations into deaths in custody were other than perfunctory and limited in focus, leading inevitably to deteriorating relationships between Aboriginal people and the broader community, to increased anguish and cynicism on the part of family and friends, and to the neglect of opportunities to avoid future deaths.

That is one of the problems of perception that this report has helped to resolve, and I hope that it has. I hope that the Aboriginal community will read this report and look at it in that sense and not take the view, as some people have, that this is some kind of cover-up. In other words, we have two extremes of potential attitude. One is that it is a police and prison bashing exercise, and the other that it is a white cover-up. I believe that this report is very important. The fact that it acknowledges that improvements have already taken place in Aboriginal-police relations is also important. I hope that everyone involved-the whole of the Australian community-will seriously look at the proposals that are aimed at resolving the problem of Aboriginal deaths in custody which, quite frankly, stems from the fact that there are too many Aboriginal people in custody too often, as the Minister said in his tabling statement. There is no doubt that the causes of this relate to a status in society. Low status, low self-esteem, leads to these problems involving a higher proportion of Aboriginal people than whites being in custody in the first place.

I think that it is important to see, as the Commission has established, the extent of the disadvantage of the 99 people whose deaths were investigated. Quite apart from the questions of childhood separation and so on which were raised by Senator Kernot, the facts are that: 83 of the 99 Aboriginals were unemployed at the date of their last detention; 43 had been charged with an offence at or before the age of 15; only two had completed secondary schooling; 43 were taken into custody in the period immediately before their deaths on matters directly related to the overuse of alcohol; and in all the remaining cases the Royal Commission concluded that alcohol was a contributing factor in their being taken into custody for the last time.

Senator Tambling dealt at some length with the question of alcohol abuse. The big question that arises is whether alcohol is the cause or the result of the problem. Is it the consequence or the cause of the disaster? That is a problem for which there is no ready, simple answer. We cannot say, `Okay, all that has to be done is to wipe out alcohol and all will be resolved'. If the basic cause of the problem is a loss of self-esteem, another method of salving the hurt of that loss presumably will be sought. On the other hand, there is a clear relationship between alcohol and every one of the problems outlined in the deaths of these 99 people. It is ludicrous to pretend that alcohol has nothing to do with the problem.

The royal commissioners say that the single most significant contributing factor to incarceration is the disadvantaged and unequal position of Aboriginal people in Australian society in every way, whether socially, economically or culturally. I think that leads to another question. Is it possible to remove that inequity for people who prefer to live a tribal existence away from what so many consider to be the marks of advantage in our society? There is a clear question that needs to be resolved. Is there a conflict between a traditional, tribal lifestyle and the factors that are seen as being of importance and of advantage in the Australian community? As I stressed earlier, there is no simple solution.

The fact that it all stems from the dispossession, by the settlers, of the Aboriginal people is a matter that has gone and which cannot be resolved. As the report says, the Aboriginal people have lost their way, and despair and hopelessness have been bred of the destruction of Aboriginal culture and the stifling of independence and initiative. Does that mean that they are gone forever, or that there are ways of resolving it? One would hope that emerging out of this report there will be ways of resolving that problem.

However, one of the ways of resolving it is not simply by throwing money at it. That is one of the interesting points made in this report. The Commissioner points out that communities today are still faced with a multiplicity of grants which effectively mean that agendas are being set elsewhere and that assumptions about what is best for Aboriginal people are made elsewhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —But we have always done that, Michael. Each successive Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has seen it as a social experiment for himself.

—I acknowledge that interjection. There is a massive problem involved in this. As my colleague says, governments seem reluctant to take the view that one of the ways out of this may well be to increase the role of Aboriginal community-based organisations.
—That is precisely what ATSIC was about.

—The interjection was that that is precisely what ATSIC is doing . The question is much more complicated than that, in the sense that there were large sections of the Aboriginal community who found that that solution was not the one they wanted. The more we look at the report the more we see how difficult it is to find appropriate solutions. As the report makes clear-and the Minister refers to this in his tabling statement-Aboriginal Australians must themselves have the will and capacity to put an end to their disadvantaged situation and take charge of their lives. The disaster is that they cannot do that while dominated by alcohol, while alcohol plays such an enormous role in so many of the problem areas of Aboriginal life-not over the whole of Aboriginal life, but over that part of it which is dealt with in this report.

SPEECH.PARA: What bothers me is that while the report says that Aboriginal people should take greater control of their lives, indeed that they should take charge of their lives, the report recognises that there will be a need for external control because it calls for a review of liquor licensing legislation, notably in the Northern Territory, with a view to reducing the availability of alcohol and meeting the needs of Aboriginal communities.

A clear example of the difficulties to be faced can be found where the commissioners say, on the one hand, that there must be greater capacity and freedom for the groups to look after themselves and, on the other hand, that we must take a paternalistic view about liquor licensing regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would suggest that there should be an Aboriginal commissioner on the liquor licensing board.

—I acknowledge that interjection. However, having an Aboriginal commissioner does not mean that the Aboriginal people will then have control of their own destinies. I am just using this as a clear example of the sorts of problems that emerge in trying to resolve a massively difficult situation. No matter what some Democrats think, there is no simple, easy answer.

SPEECH.PARA: The nature of the problem tends to be underlined in the hundreds of detailed and comprehensive recommendations that the Commissioner has made in his report. One recommendation that I totally support is the establishment of a national task force on alcohol abuse. I would hope that something will be done and is capable of being done. But I underline the fact that it cannot be done without the support, will and determination of the Aboriginal people themselves in this area.

I very much agree with the Minister's response to the Commissioner's report that as a nation we must not squander the opportunity presented by the report to act on an agenda of reform in Aboriginal affairs for the coming decade. That does not necessarily mean that in all instances we should blindly accept the Government's agenda. There is no doubt that there has been a very considerable level of bipartisanship.

But the process of reconciliation-which the Commissioner says is the fundamental backdrop of reform and change-may have many forms. There is certainly scope for different views about how to do it. For example, some people feel that an instrument of reconciliation is what is required. Others take the view that an instrument of reconciliation will divide the society more than unite it. Once again, this is a major problem.

As the Commissioner points out, the sad history of dispossession and so on needs to be recognised by all Australians as the primary cause of the current disadvantaged position of Australia's indigenous peoples. As he says, all Australians need to understand that the objective should be not to create guilt but to build compassion and empathy for Aboriginal people and their disadvantaged position in society. That should not lead us to the view that the Aboriginal people should not of themselves show a determination to assist in emerging from that disadvantaged position. That is why I would certainly be a strong supporter of increased participation by Aboriginals in determining their own fate on as many issues as possible.

It is interesting to note that the Commissioner and his report are clearly less enthusiastic than the Government has been about creating a document or instrument of reconciliation. The report says that the focus should concentrate on the process of reconciliation and not on a document or instrument, which might be one of the outcomes. I must say that I agree very strongly with that. I would hope that the Government would not seek to impose upon the Parliament and the Opposition, in terms of seeking to maintain a bipartisan approach, some document or instrument which the Commissioner has said really should not be the main element of the process of reconciliation, although it might be one of the outcomes.

I conclude by saying that bipartisanship has been an important element in past years. I remind the Senate that the slow but, nonetheless, steady improvements in the situation of the Aboriginal people since the 1967 referendum took place under a coalition government. I join with the Minister in saying that the families of those who have died, and indeed all Australians, have a right to expect that government at all levels and of all political persuasions will act together to ensure that further changes take place. I regret that I am not confident about the nature of the changes that will bring improvement. Change of itself is not necessarily for the better. I hope that the changes that will be taken will be for the better. But I stress that throwing money at the problem has been demonstrated to be not the right answer. I hope that, in examining the recommendations of the Commissioner, that will be recognised.

We all want to see the resolution of the disastrous problems of the Aboriginal people. No-one has any sole right to compassion on this matter. It is extremely difficult. To the extent that this report has focused attention on the problem, it will ultimately have been proved to be worthwhile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by congratulating Senator Kernot on her excellent speech on this very important subject, both in terms of the detail with which she covered the subject and the very perceptive way in which she understands the undertone which runs through this report. Reconciliation is really the matter that I want to pick up. Senator Baume concluded his remarks by talking about the disastrous Aboriginal problem. Quite clearly, this is a problem for Australian society; it is no less a problem for white and quasi-European Australian society than it is for the Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: The ministerial statement presented by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) pointed out that, while this began as an inquiry into Aboriginal deaths in custody, it then evolved into `an unprecedented national inquiry into the conditions of Australia's indigenous people'. It is important that we grasp this when we deal with this matter. Such a detailed understanding and insight into what has happened, what is happening and what needs to happen in this area is long overdue.

If we go back to the debates which surrounded the passage of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission legislation, honourable senators will recall that at that time the Government sought to include a preamble in the legislation which dealt with this matter of dispossession and alienation and the recognition of those things. As I pointed out at the time, that preamble had very little direct relevance to the particular legislation and, with the support of the Opposition, we moved an amendment which removed that preamble. But at the time I made a very strong plea that in its place a far more important document should be prepared and that should be an instrument of reconciliation and understanding, negotiated between the indigenous people of Australia and the non-indigenous people of Australia. I understand that that process is now in train.

I certainly agree with Senator Baume that it is not the document-it is not the words which will be written down on a piece of paper; it is not the legal importance or significance of such a thing-that is important; it is the process of reconciliation which must touch every single person in Australian society, whether Aboriginal or non-Aboriginal.

Dispossession does not mean just dispossession of land; it is dispossession of culture. It results from an arrogant disrespect, by mainstream Australian culture, for the values of Aboriginal culture. That is what lies at the heart of dispossession. Just as drunkenness is a symptom of some of the things that are wrong in this situation, so too dispossession of land is a symptom of dispossession of culture because land is such an important symbol in Aboriginal culture.

At this point I would like to introduce a term which I think is very valuable in describing what has been going on. We are all familiar with the term `racist' and the term `sexist'. I think it is useful to introduce the term `culturist' because I think the fault in Australian society lies in its inability to recognise the legitimacy and the value of other cultures-in this case, the culture of its own indigenous people.

We have been incredibly arrogant in our disregard for the values of Aboriginal culture and that is where we nonAboriginal people need to begin and, indeed, conclude that process of reconciliation. We need to give back to Aboriginal people a sense of the real value of their culture, both to them and to us. We need to do that because, as I will attempt to show later, the essential elements of Aboriginal culture-caring for land and caring for each other-are elements which are under-represented and less important in our society than they need to be for our own survival. We need their culture just as much as they need it. That process of recognition of the value of their culture will, I believe, give back to them some sense of the worth of that culture. I think that is the process of reconciliation that needs to progress.

At this point I would like to draw attention to an article by former Senator Stone which appeared in today's Australian Financial Review because, in my mind, it exemplifies precisely what is wrong with our attitude to Aboriginal culture and why we cannot address this problem as long as we have those attitudes. In this article Mr Stone is talking about Coronation Hill and the argument concerning whether that area-which is recognised in a report which I thought we were going to deal with yesterday-is recognised by the Jawoyn people as an important sacred site. He is talking about the question of Aboriginal land rights in the context of the broader subject of Aboriginal affairs. He says:
That includes the vexed question of Aboriginal land rights (so-called) and the associated question of Aboriginal ``heritage''.
My own position on these matters can be straightforwardly stated.
Aboriginal Australians are, like the rest of us, Australians. They are no less so because of their ancestry, but no more so either. We simply don't have Australians of different ``classes''.

Leaving that point aside, we do have Australians of very different cultures. Speaking specifically of the Coronation Hill site and the Aboriginal cultural associations with that site, he goes on to say:

When grown men, such as RAC Commissioners, seriously tell us that the major impediment to developing Coronation Hill is the asserted existence of some superstitious mumbo-jumbo dignified as Aboriginal ``culture'', I rub my eyes and ask myself if I am dreaming.

One could not have a clearer definition of the impediments which lie in the way of reconciliation between Aboriginal people and mainstream Australian culture. If one wanted to look for another example of the arrogance which we show towards Aboriginal culture, imagine, if you will, Madam Acting Deputy President, an Aboriginal person outside this country seeking to come into this country as an immigrant. I strongly suggest to you that that person would not be allowed into this country. The criteria which we have set in place, at least in the main part of our immigration program, are designed to attract people to this country who, culturally, have an exploitative attitude to the environment and to each other which is precisely that of the mainstream. We do not seek to attract to this country people who might have a different culture-a culture similar to that of our indigenous people.

The process of reconciliation, which I have said must permeate the whole of society and not just be simply a document-the document will be perhaps the ultimate stamp, the conclusion of that process-must involve mainstream Australian culture recognising the intrinsic value of Aboriginal culture for its own sake. That does not mean, as it has meant so far, simply allowing Aboriginal people to perform dances at concerts for money or allowing their art to be hung on the wall and sold for many hundreds of dollars. That is accepting Aboriginal culture on our terms, not on their terms. That is squeezing their culture into ways of recognition which we regard as legitimate, not the ways that they regard as legitimate.

I want to return to the question of the value of Aboriginal culture to the rest of Australian culture. This Government has said that it is committed to a process of establishing ecologically sustainable development-in other words, a form of civilisation in Australia which is capable of surviving in the long term without seriously damaging the environment in which it lives. The only objective evidence we have of a civilisation which has lived in this country, albeit with some damage but not such that it tested the ability to survive, is that of the Aboriginal people who have lived here for perhaps 40,000 years or more.

They have demonstrated, through their cultural approach and attitude to land and resources, the sorts of religious views that one needs to adopt if one is going to build an ecologically sustainable society. It is at that point that I think the mainstream, largely European, society can link hands with Aboriginal culture and say, `Yes, what you have in your culture is not only worth while and important to you-it is not only legitimate in terms of your own history or perhaps your own future-but there are also elements in that culture which we must adopt if we are going to survive as a civilisation'.

In that process I believe we can give great legitimacy to the Aboriginal people-give back to them their self-esteem. That is far more important than even the economic factors which Senator Baume mentioned. There is a great deal to be learned from indigenous cultures around the world. One thing which greatly disturbs me in relation to the Government and the Opposition's unwillingness to embrace the private member's Bill which I have put up in relation to the importation of tropical rainforest timbers is that there are in the world a thousand cultures already surviving or still surviving in rainforests-cultures which have unique abilities to survive in those situations, to preserve the environments in which they live and to live in those environments indefinitely.

We are in the process over the next couple of decades, unless we rapidly change, of totally destroying those cultures. They are cultures that we desperately need to preserve not just because it is humane to do so but because we need to understand what it is in some detail which has allowed those people to survive in that way. My God, we will not be able to survive if we continue down the road we are now following, with our profligate use of resources and our destructive approach to the environment.

This is a very important report in considerable detail, as Senator Kernot has pointed out. It fleshes out in detail the sorts of things which I have been trying to discuss by way of overview. The process of reconciliation is one which must permeate the whole of society if the specific problem with which this inquiry began and the many other problems which beset Aboriginal and mainstream society are to be satisfactorily solved both to the benefit of Aboriginal people and, very importantly, to the benefit of mainstream society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody is very significant, not only because it details with great care instances where Aboriginal people have died in custody but also because it looks at some of the underlying issues. Contrary to the view expressed by Senator Tambling, I believe that the $30m spent in assessing the issues which underlie this report is of no consequence. It is of no consequence when we are dealing with the despair and hopelessness of the original owners of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tambling also made much of the fact that alcohol was cited as a contributory cause in a majority of the cases that were investigated by the Royal Commission. That ignores the fact that alcohol is a symptom, not the cause, and it is altogether too facile to try to wipe off the thoughts, considerations and recommendations of this report by saying that it is all due to alcohol. One brief look at some relevant statistics might lead us to the view that there are other significant underlying causes.

The infant mortality rate-a very good measure of a community's well-being-for all Australians is 9.6 per 1,000. For Aboriginal people it is 29 per 1,000-three times as bad. Income per head of all Australians is $9,395; for Aboriginal people it is $4,829. There are other statistics which I could cite but will not due to time constraints. However, it is on the record that the Aboriginal community as a whole is solidly disadvantaged-that they who were the original owners of this country are living in our midst in a state of social dislocation and alienation, which is reflected in these deaths in custody.

Turning to the report, I find that much has been made of the fact that there was no intentional foul play, and we can be gratified that this is so. But people who take solace in that should have read a little further and should also have read the next comment that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) made, which summarises some of the findings of the report as follows:

Nevertheless, the report stands as an indictment of the operation of the legal and corrective services system in respect of the most disadvantaged group in Australian society, and of our society itself in allowing that situation to develop and to persist. The Royal Commission finds that there has been a failure to live up to the standard of care owed to those in custody; it has found many system defects and many individual failures to exercise proper care and basic human compassion.

The way our legal system is currently operating with respect not only to Aboriginal people but to almost all those who find themselves in contact with the corrective system needs a thorough look and overhaul. If this report is the first step to doing that, it has achieved one of its major and most valuable objectives.

One of the reasons that was cited in the report for the high incidence of death among members of the Aboriginal community has been the disproportionate representation of Aboriginal people in our prison population.
