I turn to a recent book by Fay Gale, Rebecca Bailey-Harris and Joy Wundersitz, entitled Aboriginal Youth and the Criminal Justice System. The Injustice of Justice?-a book I had occasion recently to review for the Journal of Social Alternatives. The authors demonstrate the stark facts: compared with other youth entering the legal system, Aboriginal youth is much more likely to be arrested in the first place, 43.4 per cent against 19.7 per cent; more likely to be referred to court rather than to the children's aid panel, 71.3 per cent compared with 37.4 per cent; and more likely to be sentenced to detention, 10.2 per cent against 4.2 per cent.

In all cases the comparison was made on the basis of offences or the suspicion of offences which were similar. The study examines decisions made at three critical points: police deciding to apprehend by arrest or by report; screening panels deciding whether to take any action, and, if so, whether to refer the case to a children's aid panel or to the Children's Court; and the Children's Court deciding on the various options of detention, bond, fine and discharge. The authors concluded that the racist orientation of people in the legal system was, in at least half the cases concerned, a major factor in determining the decisions thus made, and this is one of the messages of this report that we as a community, as Senator Coulter has outlined, must change. We must reach a point where we recognise Aboriginal rights, Aboriginal culture and Aboriginal traditions.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I was talking about the need for the Australian community to recognise that Aboriginal people can offer us cultural values that we need in the development of our own community. I believe that we do not have any right to be patronising about our culture as it compares with that of the Aboriginal people-their values and their spiritual understanding of the land that they occupied before we did.

SPEECH.PARA: Some years ago, I had the privilege of living for brief periods in a number of Aboriginal communities, and I learned to appreciate their honesty, their essential humanity, their tolerance and their lack of acquisitiveness-values that we could learn from and that we would do well to adopt. Yet we find that the Aboriginal community is living, within the greater community of Australia, in the most disadvantaged position of any group, and despite the well-meaning efforts of some, compared with the disregard of many others, we have not been able to offer them an equal place, their rightful place, in our community.

It is, of course, not only a matter of money, as somebody said here before. Sometimes it is, and I would like to emphasise again that I for one and the Australian Democrats as a whole do not begrudge the $30m that was spent on this report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I believe that it is money well spent if it makes our community sit up and take notice, if it shames us into taking some effective action. While it is not only a matter of money, material activities must be undertaken to enable Aboriginals to enjoy the same sorts of opportunities, the same sorts of life expectancies, that we in the rest of the Australian community have.

From my experience, mainly in the Northern Territory, I offer the comment that we, as the greater Australian community, should pick our best people-our best minds, our people who understand, who have sensitivity and who also have the capacity-to bring about a merging between the two communities in order to enable the Aboriginal community, over time, to become an equal partner in our nation.

Land rights and a treaty would be a starting point, but certainly that is not where it ends. Many of our laws need to be adjusted to fit in with Aboriginal culture and customs, and we should have the intelligence, flexibility, tolerance and capacity to bring this about. We have done it on one or two occasions in the past-for example, when the community development employment program and our notions of the unemployment benefit were adjusted to enable us to pay bulk amounts to Aboriginal communities so that they, in turn, could administer those funds in line with their own customs and concepts of authority and cooperation. We may need to do that again, and we should not get away with the idea that our laws are wise, all embracing and all powerful and that we can disregard different cultures and different values which we would do well to adopt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, which was tabled in this chamber today. First of all, I will say something in response to Senator Spindler. He said that he did not resent the $30m that had been spent. I resent the fact that we had to spend $30m simply to demonstrate symptoms which are well known. That $30m could have been constructively put towards ensuring that the inevitable, obvious and clear symptoms crying out for attention were addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing I want to say is that I personally have no guilt-a feeling which seems to pervade debates of this nature-about what happened, about the events that took place at the time of the Napoleonic Wars; but I do have a sense of subliminal anger and resentment at what I see happening today, driven by an all knowing white community.

One thing is clear about this report: it epitomises, highlights and crystallises the results of 200 years of white settlement in Australia. It demonstrates the results of 200 years of various on and off social experiments by the community as a whole or, more particularly, in many cases, by various succeeding Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs. What it demonstrates, what it highlights, are the tragic and wretched circumstances in which so many Aboriginal people live today. It shows the despair at the lack of hope and the evaporation of any likelihood of improvement. It certainly does not point to any future light on a hill. It is not startling to anybody in this chamber to read that the average age of those Aboriginals who died in custody was 32 years. I shall quote from the ministerial statement on the report:
Of the 99 Aboriginal people who died, 43 had experienced childhood separation from their natural families through intervention by State authorities, missions or other institutions.

Without question, those people in State authorities, missions or other institutions were doing what they felt overwhelmingly to be right, what they believed to be in the interests of the Aboriginal community. In the overwhelming number of cases, they were categorically wrong. The statement continues:
. . . 83 of the 99 were unemployed at the date of their last detention.
43 of the 99 had been charged with an offence at or before the age of 15 years.
Only 2 of the 99 had completed secondary schooling.
The Royal Commission concluded that the standard of health of the 99-whose average age was 32-varied from poor to very bad.
The average age of those dying from natural causes was a little over 30 years.

I have to say that my guess is that those statistics are not unique to Aboriginals who die in custody. They are probably not far from the norm for Aboriginals in society, as a result our best endeavours, as a result of billions of dollars being spent, as a result of pious, well-meaning, know all white people-zealots from the Left and the Right, zealots generally, who know no wrong.

We seem to believe that we have a prescription for the Aboriginal community that will solve all their problems. As is the case with so many issues that we are confronted with in this chamber, nobody has a mortgage on compassion and nobody has a mortgage on wisdom, but I suspect that the overwhelming majority of Australian people do have a deep sense of care and commitment to ensuring that all Australians have an acceptable standard of living.

I want to say that, in my view, the problems will not be solved by treaties, documents of reconciliation, or makarratas. That says it all because a makarrata is the expression used by a group headed, as I remember, by `Nugget' Coombs. It is an East Arnhem Land word which means the coming together after the letting of blood. Invariably it does not extinguish the conflict between the two waring groups. Perhaps more than anything else, it epitomises the difficulties that the Aboriginal community have had cast on them by us.

Land rights, makarratas, treaties and reconciliations will not help undernourished children get well. They will not help old people who are blind with glaucoma see again. They will not help old deaf Aboriginal women hear again. They will not give young people hope for an education. They will not give young Aboriginal teenagers a job, but they might give a warm inner glow to people who think that a piece of paper changes the social structure of society. Yet that is where we spend the energy, that is where we spend the money and that is where we spend the time.

There are those in our society who believe that will cleanse and expunge the sins of past events. Invariably those who push those issues so hard have a predetermined, preconceived notion about what is right and what is good, they know what is right, and there is nothing more dangerous than a man who knows what is right. I have to say that I find it almost frightening, certainly most disturbing, to watch zealot bigots in various spectrums of the political arena preaching their panacea, invariably dripping with sanctimonious self-righteousness or bigoted anger. Whatever direction in the spectrum they are coming from, they reek of some emotion which gives them a mortgage to know what is right for these people.

The tragedy is that these people inevitably treat the Aboriginal community in a manipulated sense. The Aboriginal community, as we have so often seen and as history has demonstrated, becomes the tool of these crusades. The Aboriginal community become the instrument of other people's causes. They become subject to that over which these white people's commitments are fought. They become the forgotten victims of the struggles between capitalists and socialists. They become the deprived victims of struggles between developers and anti-developers.

Perhaps there is no better example, without wanting to get into the politics of it, than Coronation Hill. I went to Coronation Hill. I took evidence, with a committee, from the Jawoyn people in what I would describe as a very relaxed, informal, natural environment. The three elders to whom Mr Justice Stewart now refers as the custodians-Peter Jetbulla, Nipper Brown and the third member whose name escapes me at the moment-said in a very relaxed but articulate and persuasive way that they had no objection to mining Coronation Hill. They had no problem with talk of a sacred site, no fear of a Bula in the area. Yet after the influence, the persuasion, and the interference of some, including a fellow named Cooper from the Northern Territory Sacred Sites Authority who from that point was determined to change their minds, we now find it alleged by Mr Justice Stewart that they do not want mining.

I have to say that I had no vested interest, nor did the committee, in persuading them in one way or another; rather we wanted to hear their evidence. Months later we find that they have become the forgotten victims who have been used, manipulated, intimidated, threatened and finally caused to take a different view from that which they instinctively wanted.

The document refers to drinking rights. I remember being in the north west of Western Australia on the very day on which the Aboriginal community got their drinking rights. Prior to that, as Senator McMullan would know, in Western Australia Aboriginals had to get citizenship. Citizenship was invariably granted to the Aboriginal community members on the basis that they wanted a right to vote. They would come before the magistrate or the justice of the peace who would examine their application. On examination, the Aboriginal applicants would always say that they wanted citizenship in order to vote, and never to drink. As I recall, the Constitution was changed so that Aboriginals could get automatic rights, and so they should have. The tragedy is that the battles for drinking rights, which now in some respects we are trying to retard, are fought over individual rights.

There are those who are saying that Aboriginals are not born equal but we will make them equal. They are not concerned with the effects, the ramifications or the consequences of providing a community, thus far denied alcohol, with the right to drink. They are determined to ensure equality of rights as though that gives some blessing and no pain, no distress and no destruction.

We have the same problem effervescing in education where there is a determination to make sure that there is access to equality, but not to equality in education. In parts of the north, where it would be sensible to provide a special English teaching category for Aboriginal children because they do not properly handle English, Aboriginal children were put into a class with white children to show that there was no discrimination. That simply meant that they bobbed and floated like jetsam and flotsam through their years of education, not understanding the language, never mind being able to read and write and learn. This happened because of bigotry from both sides.

We have seen how often money has been used as a substitute for constructive improvement in the quality of the lives of Aboriginal people. At the end of the day we can all see with clarity the consequences and the effects of these issues. We see Bob Collins take an Aboriginal group to demonstrate outside the Australian Labor Party convention in Hobart in support of mining in Kakadu National Park. I think Jabiluka was the mine. There were tens of billions of dollars in it for them, which they judged rightly to be their entitlement but which had been locked up because other people thought they knew what was in their best interests. Then we see the Northern Land Council running a different agenda for the Jawoyn people who can get equal rewards from the benefits that would flow from Coronation Hill. It just depends where one's politics are at the time as to the depravation that is caused to the Aboriginal community.

The real tragedy is that those matters that are capable of being addressed are not addressed, and are submerged in the virile and vigorous but quite unhelpful debate over land rights, treaties and reconciliations. One has only to go through the country areas of any State to see the level of health care that is available to the Aboriginal community. One has only to look at the number of Aboriginal children in country hospitals who are suffering from malnutrition, underdevelopment and deprivation. One has only to look at the disability inflicted as a result of illnesses such as glaucoma, trachomas, ear infections and the like. The necessary services and facilities are not available. Social diseases, like venereal disease, exist in these places because of a lack of proper education and a lack of concentration of care-frankly, a lack of interest in the well-being of these people and in keeping them healthy.

We talk about futility and yet we do not provide an education system that in any way enhances their skills. If they go through the process of education, what jobs are offered? For the past 100 years they have been leaving school with no English, no arithmetic-no basic learning. They simply go back to the station to ride the horses. But even that has now been taken away from them. So why in their own hearts and minds would they want to be educated when they know that at the end of the day they are not going into a job? There is no benefit to be had-there is no incentive, no reward. There is no cause for them to care whether they pass or fail, whether they go to school or do not go to school, whether they get pregnant at 14 or whether they get drunk at 13.
There is no incentive, and do we provide one? No. What we do is provide the ways and the means to ensure that there is everything else but an incentive.

We talk about the alcohol problem. What one of the Australian Democrats said earlier was quite correct: it is simply a symptom. That is not unique to the Aboriginal community. It is universal for society generally. It is a symptom of a latent, deep-seated problem of another nature. Modest as my knowledge is, it seems to me that most people who commit suicide seem to be in some way in total despair, lacking hope, self-respect and any prospects in their own heart and mind.

Yet, in many respects that epitomises what the Aboriginal people are offered for tomorrow: despair and no hope, and very often no reward for endeavour. It is acknowledged overwhelmingly by those vaguely informed that alcohol is a serious problem. But what would I get if I asked either the State governments or the Federal Government to give me a list of facilities or institutions that provide for members of the Aboriginal community who have an alcohol problem? I would receive an absolutely zero response. If one is an Aboriginal with a drinking problem, it is just too bad, mate. The Government's solution is to give the person another cheque. And yet, alcohol is seen to be a chronic cause of their problems.

The ministerial statement that I have read ever so briefly talks about reviewing the drinking laws. Quite frankly, we cannot legislate to stop drinking. The Dog Act still prevails for Aboriginal people and white people in Western Australia. Under that legislation, after a number of alcohol offences a person can be banned from licensed premises. Does anyone think that that ever stopped one single drunk from getting a drink? Of course it did not. It is social engineering to imagine that we can change people's lifestyles by law. I am reminded of the Soviets who tried to stop the sale of vodka because they thought the people were becoming alcoholics. What happened? The people cornered the sugar market. There was a shortage of sugar in the Soviet Union because all the moonlighters, all the bootleggers, had bought it all. So, the authorities had to allow the people to revert to their original hours of consumption.

We will not stop the alcohol problem amongst Aborigines simply by changing the licensing laws. I am not suggesting for a moment that this should not be done or that licensees who pour alcohol down the throats of either black or white people who are clearly intoxicated should not be prosecuted. It is already an offence under the licensing Act. However, there is absolutely no infrastructure at all to give assistance to those people who might want it. There is absolutely no counselling at all.

Finally, we need to acknowledge-which we presently do not do-the values, the views, the aspirations, the wishes, the wants and the lifestyle that members of the Aboriginal community want. That is what will give them some help and some hope-not our own social engineering, not our determination to make them appear to be equal, through dollars and cents. We must understand what it is that they want for themselves, their children and their extended family. We must make sure that in a proper and constructive way they contribute to that decision-making. Somebody said that it was intended that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) would do that. Frankly, I could provide a persuasive argument that it does the contrary. I fear that it does not provide for immediate, on the ground and close-to-home decision-making.

To the extent that this report deals with the tragic deaths of 99 people and that it cost $30m plus, I hope that some good really does come out of it. I hope that it is not just another statement about contemporary Aboriginal society. I hope that it is not just a collection of hypocritical words designed to soothe the deep inner feelings of those who purport to have a mortgage on compassion but rather a starting point in beginning to acknowledge what some of the fundamental problems are. Having read the ministerial statement, I have to say that, to my mind, it does not go to the heart of those matters that are intrinsic to a greatly enhanced lifestyle and future for the Aboriginal community.
Debate (on motion by Senator Brownhill) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I rise to speak tonight on the Industry Commission report No. 10 on statutory marketing arrangements for primary producers. The report, which is dated 26 March 1991, follows a reference to the Industry Commission to investigate Commonwealth, State and Territory statutory marketing authorities for primary products, excluding mining and forestry. In the report, the Industry Commission has taken a general approach to primary products and their statutory marketing authorities and makes very broad economic conclusions, as opposed to the recommendations on specific primary industry statutory marketing authorities.

In this general climate of deregulation, any changes that may follow from this report should be assessed from the standpoint of current arrangements. Many findings in the report are causes for concern, particularly from the point of view of individual rural producers dealing with the concentration that occurs in Australia with processors, suppliers and retail chains. In many cases, statutory marketing arrangements are the only thing standing between a fair market price and the exploitation of individual farmers in a market dominated by three or four major players.

I take as an example the grocery industry: 70 per cent of the Australian grocery market is in the hands of three major grocery chains. Because of their vast buying power, they can force growers and processors to give discounts and other up-front markdowns that reduce prices to below the cost of production. The countervailing market power of these statutory marketing bodies becomes even more important when the amount of brand ownership and vertical integration of these groups is taken into consideration.

The report makes the assertion that statutory marketing authorities raised consumer prices by about 0.3 per cent and taxed users and consumers of food products directly by some $550m. Relevant to the Commission's figures is the fact that the non-farm index-the consumer price index-has increased over the last 30 years by 755 per cent while farmers have received a price increase of 348 per cent in the same period. This means that consumers are getting a very low commodity price and very cheap food.

Another position that we must take into consideration is the threat of imported products being brought into Australia by major marketers and chains. The report also points to the productivity and efficiency gains that have been made by Australian farmers over the same period.

The report raises the question of trade practices protection for rural producers to countervail buyers' market power as opposed to the use of statutory marketing authorities. The report specifically questions the limitation under the Act which restricts the authorising of voluntary recommended price arrangements between fewer than 50 parties. I do not think that there would be too many statutory marketing authorities that would have less than 50 members.

If we are to replace statutory marketing authorities with trade practices protection-it is quite obvious that at the moment the Trade Practices Act is the weakest in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries and will not provide that protection to rural producers-the Government must address this problem before it exposes rural producers and primary industry, to the market forces that are concentrated in Australia more than in any other OECD country. We will never see the amalgamations or the aggregations of companies to the extent that we see in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The National Report on Schooling in Australia, put out by the Australian Education Council, is a very valuable document. The document contains excellent data for understanding what is and what is not happening in Australian education. In the time allowed, it is possible to address only a few of the issues raised.

I want to place my remarks relating to the report in the context of the call of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for the need for Australia to become the clever country. I was pleased to read in the report that the very first goal for schooling in Australia is:

To provide an excellent education for all young people, being one which develops their talents and capacities to full potential, and is relevant to the social, cultural and economic needs of the nation.

I searched the document in vain to see how, in the light of this goal, the Federal Labor Government was promoting that through programs to help the gifted and talented children of this nation. There were, quite properly, programs for a wide range of disadvantaged groups; but for the gifted children there was nothing.

This appalling gap in our national priorities was brought home to me during questioning of the officials from the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) at the recent Additional Estimates hearings. The Department revealed that the Federal Government was providing no funding in this area. When I started to question the senior DEET officials about this matter, Minister Bolkus stopped me, saying that such general questions were outside the ambit of the Additional Estimates hearing. Honourable senators can be assured that I will ask the same questions during the Budget Estimates hearings.

The highlight of the report was the section that outlined the initiatives in the area of excellence in education in my own State. The Government of New South Wales, like the Federal Government, has set out as its first goal for education to promote and reward excellence in all aspects of schooling and to provide parents with increased choice in schooling. But, unlike the Federal Labor Government, the Greiner Government has done something about it with its excellence and equity policy. Section 4 of the report on New South Wales, headed `Major Policy Initiatives', addresses freedom of choice and the pursuit of excellence. Among the initiatives relating to this goal are: basic skills testing program; assessment and reporting of student progress; dezoning of schools; the creation of selective high schools; senior high schools; high schools for the performing arts; technology high schools; and centres of excellence.

I take particular pride in the creation of centres of excellence in New South Wales schools, as I wrote the seminal paper on this for the then shadow Minister for education, Dr Terry Metherell. It is pleasing to see that so many schools are specialising and building their expertise in areas such as the performing arts, music and languages, just to name a few. As a result of these initiatives, parents have a greater opportunity to fulfil their aspirations for their family by sending their children to schools which better match their needs.

I would like to pay tribute in this place to the courage and tenacity of Dr Terry Metherell, who will go down in education history as the watershed Minister who turned the education system around against the entrenched interests of the New South Wales Teachers Federation. I am pleased to see that the current New South Wales Minister for Education, the Hon. Virginia Chadwick, is not retreating from the policy position which Dr Metherell established.

It is interesting to note that the Australian Labor Party is not proposing to abolish any of the initiatives that I have mentioned in its policy for the New South Wales State election. Where would it go? Would it follow the disastrous initiatives of the Victorian Government's education policy? I do not think anyone would be game enough to follow the Victorian Government on anything at the moment.

I will track with interest over the next few years the educational outcomes in the Victorian and New South Wales systems as Labor pursues in Victoria the cult of mediocrity with its philosophy of levelling down and as New South Wales pursues policies which move towards helping children achieve their potential.

What is the Federal Labor Government doing in this particular area? Three years ago the Senate Select Committee on the Education of Gifted and Talented Children brought down its report. What has the Federal Government done about it? According to the national report on schooling, it has done nothing. That is a national disgrace and it makes the Prime Minister's call for Australia to become a clever country very hollow indeed.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on Estimates Committee documentation and procedures together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report discharges a reference arising from the October 1989 report of Estimates Committee E. That Committee was critical of aspects of explanatory notes it had received and had broader concerns about the accountability of trust accounts and special appropriations.

The inquiry into the matters raised by Estimates Committee E took longer than was initially expected, mainly because of delays resulting from the 1990 Federal election and the almost total change of Committee membership that followed it. The duration of the Committee's consideration of the issues also reflects the importance of the subject matter.

The Committee took a broad approach to review of the Estimates process. The resulting report has two major aims. The first is to propose changes to Estimates documentation and procedures which the Committee members agreed could provide more effective and better focused Estimates hearings within the current scrutiny process. A second and more ambitious aim is to contribute to a larger debate about the effectiveness of the Estimates process and the use made of information provided to Parliament.

The procedural changes proposed in the report should draw wide support. The Committee recommends that scheduling of Estimates hearings be made more certain by setting firm commencement times, by requiring that no hearing extend beyond midnight, and by scheduling hearings in the same weeks each year. The Committee has also suggested that the possibility of scheduling hearings in non-sitting weeks be considered on the basis that moving Estimates hearings to non-sitting weeks should not increase the number of weeks that senators are required to spend in Canberra. The Committee also recommends a firm but achievable deadline for the tabling of explanatory notes.

Another recommendation proposes measures to reduce the huge volume of paper associated with the present Estimates process. The Senate might be surprised to learn that the explanatory notes, Hansards, and volumes of additional information produced in the last Budget Estimates process totalled almost 15,000 pages, all printed in multiple copies for uses that are mostly ephemeral.

A further change in Estimates procedures which could improve the quality of information available to Estimates committees would be for Ministers from the House of Representatives to have carriage of their portfolios' estimates at committee hearings, if they wish to do so. The Committee recommended that the Government consider allowing this to occur.

The Committee noted that the explanatory notes provide a misleading picture of the operations of quasi-commercial bodies operating on an accrual accounting basis under group two trust accounts. These bodies have become more significant in the Budget with the commercialisation of the administrative services portfolio. The Committee has recommended that Estimates committees have access to financial information on group two trust accounts, segmented to the level of business units within each trust account, regardless of whether the information has been audited at the time of Estimates hearings.

The Committee has also recommended that financial information on trust accounts, segmented to business unit level, be published after it has been audited. Another recommendation in this area seeks to remove an ambiguity in the principles for provision of services to government agencies by the Department of Administrative Services which might limit the Auditor-General's access to the records of trust accounts. It appears that no such limit was intended or has been applied, but the wording is susceptible to misunderstanding.

The various detailed recommendations in the report would make the existing Estimates process more tidy. I have argued elsewhere that the process could benefit from more substantial reform. It seems to me that the current process compresses too much of the necessary parliamentary scrutiny into the Estimates framework. It thrusts a mix of urgent and non-urgent tasks onto committees which have little continuity of membership or staffing.

Parliamentary scrutiny of the Executive surely would be served better by some separation of the various functions currently lumped together under the Estimates scrutiny label. I believe that the development of standing committees and the extent to which they now shadow ministerial portfolios justifies giving those committees the task of Estimates scrutiny. This would allow a more even spread of scrutiny work over the year. It would encourage standing committees to undertake more systematic monitoring of performance, based on annual reports as well as the Estimates documentation.

Standing committees could apply the current Estimates procedures just as easily as Estimates committees. All the aims of the present system could be achieved in that way with the added advantages of better-focused scrutiny by committees with greater continuity of membership and staffing.

The Committee was not able to agree on the significance of the problems with the present process or on major changes that could be made to the process. The nub of the argument, I believe, was summed up in a discussion paper prepared by the clerks for the Standing Orders Committee in 1985, which commented:

If [Estimates] Committees are seen simply as a more convenient method of conducting the examination of the estimates which used to be conducted in the Committee of the Whole, with the added advantage of questions being put directly to departmental officers, [the] Committees as they currently operate could be seen as entirely appropriate. If it is considered that the Committees should be undertaking a more intensive examination of the estimates, this would tend to lead to the conclusion that the task should be undertaken by the standing committees.

I am inclined to favour accountability mechanisms which will encourage public servants to be responsive to elected governments. I doubt that the structure of separate standing and Estimates committees which emerged as a by-product of political deals in 1971 is the best possible way of doing this, especially given the vastly greater amount of information routinely made available to committees 20 years later. An important chapter of the report deals with the limitations of the Estimates committees in reviewing performance of departments and agencies. It will be clear from the report that members of the Committee differed on such issues. Members differed especially in the weight they placed on the object of the Estimates process and on the effectiveness of the current process in auditing or evaluating program performance.

The Committee did not consult widely on major changes to the process and such changes deserve careful consideration and discussion by all senators. For those reasons, the final chapter of the report presents options and recommends that the Senate debate the Estimates process and possible changes to it.

The report was adopted after a rather long debate within the Committee. Although Committee members differed on the need for extensive change to the Estimates process and on the types of improvements possible, we did agree that Estimates scrutiny is important. The Committee was keen to achieve a compromise position on recommendations and I particularly acknowledge the efforts of the Deputy Chairman, Senator Watson, in this regard.

On behalf of the Committee, I also thank the staff who worked on this inquiry, especially Barbara Allan and Peter Hamburger. Dr John Uhr of the public policy program at the Australian National University, and formerly an officer of the Senate, helped the committee to clarify its ideas on these issues. The Committee is also grateful to numerous officers of departments and agencies for their work in producing substantial written submissions and for their oral presentations. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Estimates processes are a valuable link in the accountability chain that ensures that public administrative practices are open, honest and efficient. The Senate Estimates provide an important link between the people, the Parliament and the public sector. Some of the various roles of the Estimates scrutiny processes, including the monitoring of performance, the gathering of information and being a forum for debate during the committee stage of appropriation Bills may at times seem to be conflicting roles. Also, to the casual observer, the Estimates processes frequently give the appearance of being unstructured and on occasions give the appearance of being politically charged.

SPEECH.PARA: It was against this background that the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, under the chairmanship of Senator Coates, embarked on its inquiry arising from the request through Senate Estimates Committee E whereby there was an implied need to improve some aspects of the form of the program, management and budgeting presentations and other matters. Reviews not infrequently lead to change, but in recent years there has been a tendency to assume that all change is desirable. Opportunities occasioned by a reference such as this can often lead to a dramatic change.

I use this opportunity to add a word of warning that there is, nevertheless, a degree of responsibility required of senators to ensure that we do not discredit valuable and timely systems of checks and balances built up over many years to meet a problem in a particular area. That is, that we build on what has been constructed rather than overthrow something which has stood the test of time. By this I do not wish to denigrate in any way the scope of the inquiry. Indeed, quite the reverse, because the adequacy of the presentation of departmental explanatory notes and the monitoring by the Department of Finance is really the linchpin for senators' evaluations. The operation of trust accounts in many senators' minds has been less than desirable, and hence there has been a concern that the use of trust accounts at times can provide a vehicle where there is less than adequate scrutiny by the Parliament.

The evaluations by the Senate, particularly of departmental reports by various committees, has really been quite uneven across the spectrum. I remind honourable senators that there is an unwritten obligation on the part of us all to apply very thorough analysis and scrutiny to all reports that come before this place. To do this appropriately will require a degree of specialisation because there is always a tendency that the more politically sensitive areas will demand the greatest degree of attention to the detriment of others. There does need to be a coordinating body within each Party to ensure that parliament's role in reviewing the various operations of government is adequate and that it does not pass these jobs off to other entities including the Auditor-General, the Department of Finance, the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet or other such agency.

The report before the Senate was indeed a difficult one. I commend all the members who were prepared to compromise their earlier bolder resolutions to enable a report to be tabled without a minority addendum. The report now before the Senate indicates that there was not always unanimous agreement to all the suggestions that were put forward. But this is always inevitable in a report of this nature.

One issue farther down the track, which I believe I have a responsibility for signalling now, concerns the further evaluation of what I might term policy outcomes. While it is quite appropriate, for example, that the Auditor-General should report on the quality of the externally set indicators and provide information on how successful each program's goals have been, further intrusions into policy areas by external evaluators outside the parliamentary chambers could be dangerous. I suggest that it could leave such respected office holders as the Auditor-General open to claims of political bias if we pursued the matter too much further.

Such policy evaluations, I believe, are best kept within the chamber or within the political forums. The Auditor-General is widely respected across political parties and is one of the few officers in the public area who commands universal respect. I do not believe that we can afford to put a new responsibility on him or his office that could diminish in any way this built-up respect and impartiality.

A more current issue that has some relevance to this report is the forthcoming report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts concerning the scrutiny of government business enterprises (GBEs)-a matter which this report dealt with-and the manner in which these enterprises be subject to regular review. Parliament's evaluation of government business enterprises is essential despite their enhanced independent audits. The role of the Auditor-General is critical. This was recognised in the recommendation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts report 296 which stated:

. . . where the Federal Government has a financial interest in GBEs the Auditor-General should be the final auditor. The other device of assuring accountability is to establish social responsibility criteria including community service obligations on all GBEs.

In conclusion, I would like to reiterate the views of the Committee that the Senate Estimates process has succeeded over the years. As a demonstration of this progress, departments and agencies have become more careful and informative in their reporting. However, the Committee was mindful of an emerging problem which exists beyond the quality of reporting-that is, the question of the cost-effective use of the information of the Estimates data.

The Committee trusts that the report will provide an injection of some Senate enthusiasm for further constructive debate on improvements to the Senate Estimates scrutiny processes. However, the Senate must not in any way weaken the strengths of the existing system and improvements that have occurred since their inception. I wish to thank the Chairman, Senator Coates, for his forbearance, all members of the Committee, the Secretary, Peter Hamburger, and his staff for their tolerance, forbearance and resolve to produce a good report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TABLING STATEMENT FOR SENATOR DEVEREUX
Thursday 9th May 1991
CONSTRUCTION OF AUSTRALIAN EMBASSY COMPLEX, JAKARTA, INDONESIA

The report that I have just tabled deals with the construction of a new Chancery and associated recreational facilities in Jakarta. The Committee has concluded that there is a need to provide a purpose-built complex for the Australian Embassy in Jakarta to enable the mission to fulfil representative functions. The new complex is also needed to provide cultural activity space and staff amenities.

The proposed complex will be built on a recently acquired site in the Jakarta central business district. The limit-of-cost estimate for the work when referred to the Committee was $11.6 million at December 1990 prices. Because of the unexpected need to provide for on-site power generation, the estimated cost at the time of the public hearing in February 1991 had increased to $12.4 million. However, while it appears that on-site power generation will now not be required, the Overseas Property Group wishes to retain the additional cost in the estimate until this is confirmed. The Committee also recommended a further cost of $880,000 be allowed for expansion purposes.

In recommending that the work proceed, the Committee recognises Australia's need to develop a positive and constructive relationship with Indonesia. Although the relationship between Australia and Indonesia has not been easy for either country in recent years, there is an interest and willingness on both sides to improve those relations. We believe it is important that, as the relationship continues to grow in substance and depth, the Embassy remains capable of effectively monitoring and coordinating the full range of interactions.

The Australian Embassy is currently located in two physically separate buildings in the central commercial district of Jakarta, now dominated by large multi-storey buildings. The Chancery premises-one owned by the Australian Government and the other leased-are separated by a very busy ten lane major thoroughfare. The owned accommodation-a five storey building opened in 1967-is located on a narrow site which is congested by open air carparking, maintenance workshops, store and plant rooms, and recreation facilities.

This building has been progressively supplemented with leased space in nearby premises, as the Embassy's functions and staff numbers have expanded over the past few years. As well as detracting from the Embassy's efficiency and cost-effectiveness, through the separation of functions and staff, the present office accommodation is inadequate to satisfy existing needs, provides substandard office accommodation, and is adversely affecting the ability of the mission to realise its goals and objectives.

The proposal, therefore, is based on the need to house all Embassy staff in one building in an acceptable standard of office accommodation, to favourably reflect Australia's image in Indonesia, and to meet the Australian Government's obligation as an employer to accommodate properly its employees.

One matter of concern to the Committee was the proposed size of the complex. Because of the importance of Australia's relationship with Indonesia, it is inevitable that staff numbers will expand, thus requiring disruptive works to provide additional space. This was reinforced by the views of the Ambassador and staff in Jakarta. The Committee has, therefore, recommended that the project be expanded during the initial construction phase to include the shell of an additional floor and space for lateral expansion at a further cost of $880,000.

The Committee concluded that the site chosen for the new Australian Embassy complex in Jakarta is in a suitable location for its representation and administrative functions. It has also requested that it be provided with a copy of the energy audit of the complex, which is to be undertaken following its completion.

Concerns were raised by the Ambassador and staff in Jakarta over the architectural merit of the proposed project. The mission did not believe the design of the complex adequately reflected the importance of Australia's relationship with Indonesia. While not wishing to enter into a debate on the architectural merits of this project, the Committee believes the design rationale for Australian embassies should be reassessed. In particular, the Overseas Property Group should determine what designs are meant to achieve, for example, a sense of Australian identity, a prestige image or merely a functional solution to suit a particular design requirement.

Due to the restriction in the Public Works Committee Act 1969 on meetings of the Public Works Committee outside Australia and its external Territories, the Committee was unable to inspect the proposed site or existing Embassy complex in Jakarta. This is completely contrary to the normal practice of the Committee, which has always regarded site inspections as an integral and extremely important part of its consideration of a project. This matter has been raised before, and the time will come-given some of the complexities of projects about to be referred to the Committee-that it will decide that, without a site inspection, it is impossible to adequately discharge the mandate given to it by Parliament.

I know that there are costs involved, but given the nature of some projects, it would sometimes be cheaper for the Committee or a sectional Committee to conduct an on-site inspection, than the present unsatisfactory arrangements which often require local embassy staff and design and construction personnel to travel to Canberra to appear at public hearings.

In the case of the current Embassy project, due to the absence of a site inspection, the Committee was hampered in its consideration of the project, particularly in relation to the issue of size. The Committee believes that Section 12(1) of the Public Works Committee Act 1969 should be amended to allow it to meet outside Australia and its external Territories. The Committee has approached the Minister for Administrative Services on this matter.
I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to this report, Construction of Australian Embassy Complex, Jakarta, Indonesia. I note the absence of Senator Devereux, but I am sure he would concur with what I am about to say. This particular construction is of significance not just to us but also to our relationship with the Indonesian Government. In my opinion and, I think, in the opinion of the Public Works Committee, it is long overdue.

SPEECH.PARA: The cost of particular complex has escalated from $11.6m at December 1990 to a figure approaching $12.4m in February 1991. As a result of consultations, our Committee also recommended that a further cost of $880,000 be allowed for expansion purposes. That was as a result of particular worries that the Ambassador in Jakarta had and which he conveyed to the Committee, because he believed that our relationship with Indonesia- a very important relationship, I might say-would lead to increased activity between our two countries. As the Committee viewed this project and took evidence from those involved, we were of the opinion that the project could be expanded while the initial construction was going on-by a shell being constructed which could be fitted out at a later time. The Chairman of our Committee, Colin Hollis, and all the members believe that when we have overseas projects involving large amounts of money-in this case $12.4m-then at least an executive group of the Committee, if not all the members, should be able to view the site and get a feel for what is really happening.

I do not think it reflects very well on our architecture nor on other aspects. It was, to say the least, nothing more than an elaborate bomb shelter. People might think perhaps there is a possibility that there could be conflict there in the future, although I do not believe so, but I must say it was very disappointing to an Australian in a place like Tokyo, where we have so much diplomatic activity, to see that building. TALK.START.PARA: —You should have taken a video to bring back to show us.

I am drifting away from the subject at hand, but the point I am trying to make is that it is all very well to look at plastic models that cost $5,000 or $6,000 each and to view videos that cost up to $4,000 or $5,000 each, but the fact is that if we, as the oldest Committee in this Parliament, are supposed to give approval to projects of this magnitude. Particularly given our relationship with Indonesia, I think it is very important that some consideration by the Minister be given to allowing a representative group from the Committee at least to view the site and to see what impact it might have on the whole project. I understand that our Chairman has taken up this matter most vigorously with the Minister concerned. I do not know what his success rate has been, but I am sure, knowing Mr Hollis, that he will beaver away.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that I have said enough about this matter. The overall design of the building seems to fit in well with those types of architecture one sees in that part of the world. I think that those involved have done all they can, given the cost constraints and our situation and relationship with Indonesia. I hope that this new complex makes things easier for everybody concerned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This is document No. 11 and relates to the report by the National Board of Employment, Education and Training on higher education funding. The Higher Education Council is required to report to the National Board twice each year, in February and August, on the operation of educational profiles and the impact of the higher education contribution scheme (HECS). I want to deal with the section of the report which deals with education profiles. I have to say at the outset that this aspect of higher education receives scant attention in the report. There are, in fact, only two pages which deal with educational profiles compared with 14 pages on HECS plus several more pages of statistics relating to HECS.

Let me remind the Senate of the role of the Higher Education Council and its relation to the education profiles. The Higher Education Council has a legislative requirement to advise on two things: the principles on which funding decisions are made for higher education; and the detailed allocation proposals for funding to higher education institutions.

I turn to the very small amount of information which is provided in this report before the Senate. First, the report indicates that in 1990 visits to institutions were undertaken by three teams with up to eight people on each. Then there is a fair amount of detail about the composition of these teams. There were representatives from the Department of Employment, Education and Training; the Higher Education Council; and the Australian Research Council. Then the report talks about the favourable reactions of the institutions to their visits. On page three of the report the council reports on its important role as an adviser on funding in one sentence:

In carrying out these responsibilities in 1990, the Council advised the Minister on appropriate levels of growth and its allocation amongst groups of entrants and between undergraduate and postgraduate studies.

Finally, we have three paragraphs which deal with the concerns of the council in connection with education profiles. I now indicate the total amount of information which is contained in the report about this. The report says:

The profiles process could be streamlined to allow more flexibility in the size of the teams and the duration of the visits. There needs to be broader agreement involving all team members on the procedures of the visits. The agenda for the visits needs to be carefully structured and tailored to the individual institution. There is a query on the need for annual visits to individual institutions; visits every two or three years may be adequate.

That is it. There is no mention of the concerns voiced by institutions which have arisen as a result of these visits. This skimpy report provides no information about the extent of government interference with and intervention into higher education which have had catastrophic results. We now have a bureaucratically administered system dominated by ministerial discretion on the advice of the Higher Education Council which can only report on how and with whom it undertakes visits to higher education institutions.

Education profiles are agreements which are negotiated annually between the Commonwealth and the institution, but the results of these profiles have been a disaster. The Government now has considerable scope in telling institutions what they can teach, what research they can undertake and how they should manage their affairs. The education profile process opens the way for extensive government intrusion into matters where governments should keep out.

Universities are requested to respond to government inquiries into all aspects of teaching and research. The Government appears to have little understanding of how a university functions when these reviews and reports are requested with great urgency and detail. Higher education institutions waste a vast amount of their time and scarce resources in providing this information to the Government, but this report offers no information in return.

I wish to address some brief remarks to the report on the death of Robert Joseph Walker by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. The Commissioner found that excessive force was used in subduing him and certainly in stopping him from struggling when he was face down on the ground outside. This is another report in a long list of such occurrences. It would appear that this is one of a long list of cases in Western Australia in particular. I note in passing that there are four volumes of reports of incidents investigated by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody which have occurred in Western Australia compared with one volume for each of the other States. I believe that this lends considerable strength to the suggestion that an independent police complaints authority should be established in Western Australia.

I wish to speak on the report on the operation of the War Crimes Act 1945 for the period to June 1990. This report is tabled pursuant to section 21 of the War Crimes Act 1945 which provides that the Attorney-General shall, as soon as practicable after 30 June each year, cause a report about the operations of the Act during the year ended 30 June to be prepared and cause a copy of that report to be laid before each House of Parliament.

It is almost the end of this financial year and it is almost time for the next annual report to be tabled. I wonder whether the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) might at some stage explain why it has taken some 10 1/2 months for this report to be tabled. The report is prepared in accordance with the War Crimes Act. It is prepared in a very easy to read manner. It is not a terribly lengthy report; it is not one that contains information that is particularly difficult to obtain. In fact, most of the information in this report is information that was subjected to examination at the Estimates committees in September last year.

I wonder, then, whether the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) has-as he is required to do by the War Crimes Act-in fact complied with section 21, which states that he has to, as soon as practicable after 30 June of each year, cause a report to be made and laid on the table. I would think that the Attorney-General has breached his obligations under the War Crimes Act. One might wonder whether one should not ask that the matter be referred to the Attorney-General to ascertain whether he has breached his obligations under the War Crimes Act. It would really seem that, by no stretch of the imagination, could the early part of May of the following year be considered to be as soon as practicable after 30 June 1990. I think that is something that should be looked at by the appropriate authorities.

The War Crimes Act and the Special Investigations Unit that is set up under it is something that I have been somewhat interested in since coming to this Parliament. In the times that I have spoken on this matter I have said that we in this country should do nothing that would let criminals escape justice-particularly criminals involved in that horrific conflict which took place over the period from 1939 to 1945.

However, it has always seemed to me that the Special Investigations Unit will involve enormous expense for very little perceived result. I have heard on the radio that the head of the unit, Mr Greenwood QC-who I understand has a contract with the Government to head this Special Investigations Unit-has recently announced his resignation. I wonder what, if anything, prompted his resignation.

I note that the costs of running the Special Investigations Unit for the period up to 30 June 1990 totalled some $7 1/2m. Additional money was paid in legal aid services. I calculated at the Estimates Committee hearing in September that if one added together all of the costs of the Special Investigations Unit-legal aid and the cost of other resources that have been made available by the taxpayer-some $16m has been spent. It seems to be a lot of money, as the expenditure of all of that money has resulted in only 12 cases which may proceed to prosecution. There has been only one prosecution brought forward to date, and that is subject to a challenge in the High Court of Australia.

One wonders about the sensibleness of bringing forward legislation like this and instituting a Special Investigations Unit whose only tangible result seems to have been to pay a lot of lawyers, consultants and public servants a lot of money with very little result.
