SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

Paper No. 6 is the Industry Commission report on recycling, volume one. Other honourable senators have addressed this report and comprehensively considered its contents, but it seems to me that some other points are worth making. Even in glancing at the introduction I can see some outstanding points which should be brought to the notice of the Senate.

In the introduction to the report there is a graph which depicts the extent of recycling in Australia. At first glance it may seem that there are some discrepancies. For example, we wonder why domestic PET plastic is very low on the scale of recycling. The reason is that the recycling of that product means considerable net costs to society as the transport costs associated with this material are high. That is the sort of point which is made throughout this report and it is a point worth making.

I have seen newspaper articles about this report, the theme of which could be generally summarised as saying that not all recycling is necessarily good and not all recycling is the same as other recycling. This particular example of PET plastic is one reason why we should critically evaluate the concept of recycling to see what we are trying to do.

As a matter of fact, I think it would be more productive to consider recycling in a different light. Perhaps we could consider it as a productivity improvement. When the term `productivity improvement' is referred to in other spheres we quite often assume that it means achieving a greater degree of effort and energy from employees in an organisation. Similarly, if we are able to extract further productivity or more, or further, uses from any given resource, then that is a definition of recycling.

Further uses can be achieved from a raw material. Even after it has been used as one product, it is still possible to use that product again and achieve an increase in productivity from that raw material. With that in mind, a critical evaluation of whether that is worth while would include the close examination of the sorts of costs-both to society and the producer-that are associated with re-using that raw material.

Another point I can make from a brief reading of this report is that major advances in recycling would accrue from the increased focus on industrial waste, organic materials and especially building materials. I am sure, Madam Acting Deputy President, that you would be familiar with the amount of land fill space that is occupied in municipal waste collection areas by building materials which could be re-used for all sorts of other purposes.

Whilst I am on that point I should mention that many local government authorities are still not charging enough to cover the real costs of disposal. Quite often the costs of establishing land waste disposal areas have been ignored by local government authorities. For example, some of the emphasis now is on kerbside collection. If the charges for household kerbside disposal are based on rates, rather than volume or value, then there is no incentive at the moment to reduce those amounts. But, thankfully, we are seeing a situation where in the near future it may be possible to charge households according to the amount of volume that they generate as waste and so encourage the kerbside separation of waste materials and increase their potential for recycling.

While we are looking at the actual costs of re-using raw materials and gaining greater productivity from them, it should be apparent that in outlying areas the costs of collection of waste paper, for example, often exceed the benefits. Therefore, we wonder whether those areas should not pay the recovery costs in the cost of the product itself when they purchase it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. That concludes the consideration of government documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the resolution of the Senate of 31 May 1990 relating to the broadcasting by television stations of Senate proceedings be modified by omitting condition 6 in paragraph (3), which prohibits the broadcasting of the adjournment debate.

The purpose of this motion is to make a change that perhaps we all should have made a year and a bit ago when we decided to allow television into parliament in a live sense. As we all know, Question Time in the Senate, and now having been followed by the House of Representatives-which is an appropriate order in which these things should be done--

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—Hear, hear, says one of my colleagues. It is not called the lower house without good reason, some would say-although it would be unkind to say that at this hour of the night.

SPEECH.PARA: Nonetheless, the Senate decided before the House of Representatives that it was appropriate to let television cameras into this chamber. After all, representatives of the media can sit in the press gallery. Journalists from the print or the electronic media can repeat anything they have heard in this chamber and get a run with that in their chosen media. However, for a long time we somehow thought that, if proceedings in here were televised and people saw what really happened, it would be a bad thing. I do not want to dwell on this point because I am at a loss to explain why we thought that. I can see no cogent reason for coming to that conclusion-quite the opposite.

I should have thought that, the geography of this nation being as it is, the concept of having a democratic parliamentary institution which people can enter, as some members of the public are here in the public gallery tonight, to see what is happening, would make it mandatory that we use television, a modern medium of communication-although not that modern-to ensure that those who could not afford to come to Canberra for the luxury of seeing whether their parliamentarians were doing the job could in another way see whether their parliamentarians were doing the job.

At the moment we have not encouraged television stations to take the access that perhaps they should. At the moment Question Time is televised on a rotational basis between here and the lower House on a one day on, one day off basis, and all the television stations are permitted to take excerpts from all the parliamentary proceedings, except for the adjournment debate. That is what this motion seeks to deal with: to allow the adjournment debate to be televised. There is no good reason at all why that should not happen.

This is an extension of the original motion to acknowledge that the geography of this country demands that people have access to this Parliament. They do not all have the money to come here and see it happening on a regular basis-quite the opposite in the recession we needed to have. Therefore, Parliament should be accessible to the people through all forms of the media, including television. There is no reason why television should be disadvantaged over the radio and print media. That is why we have done this, and that is why I seek to extend the access of the television media to the adjournment debate.

One thing that has been very noticeable with allowing television cameras into this chamber for the rest of the parliamentary proceedings has been the competition that it has introduced. No longer can Michelle Grattan, Paul Lyneham or someone else who is here in Canberra and has the opportunity to come and sit in the press gallery write a version of what happens with no fear of competition. Any journalist around the nation can turn on the television, see what happens at Question Time and write a competing article-and if not write a competing article, make a different assessment of what either Michelle Grattan or any journalist one likes to name has said-and, having made that competing assessment, share it with his or her colleagues so that we have some competition in the media.

Those in the Press Gallery of Canberra have had a monopoly on the proceedings in this place for far too long, and the televising of proceedings has put an end to that monopoly. It has allowed other people, albeit only on every alternate day, to see what is happening at Question Time. At least all Australians, and other journalists in the news and current affairs programs, can make their own assessment of what has been happening here. So the introduction of competition in the media has been a good thing. I do not see why television should not be introduced into the adjournment debate to encourage a bit more competition in the coverage of that as well.

The only change this motion would make is that it would let my mouth, your mouth, Mr Acting Deputy President, and Senator McMullan's mouth move. At the moment, if one of us wants to say something on the adjournment debate which happens to be newsworthy and which the electronic media wants to run first thing in the morning-a difficult thing to do at 10.30 at night-if we happen to strike it lucky and do that, a stationary picture of ourselves is put on the screen and a live tape of what has been said is re-run.

How can there possibly be a debate on this? I am amazed that we need a debate about simply letting the mouth and facial features on that stationary picture move so that people can see parliament live as opposed to just a picture of who said something and the words they spoke. I raise an example of where that is important. We all know that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been prone, prior to developing aspirations to the Lodge, to call people sleazebags and scumbags and otherwise use what one might call, if one were in an ungracious mode, reasonably vitriolic language.

So it was with some pride that I watched the 7.30 Report with Paul Lyneham the other day covering the Hawke-Keating leadership crisis and battle, which played excerpts from Parliament of both these men. Instead of being told through the print media that Keating was a tough performer who used a bit of strong language to put people back in their box and that Hawke was basically pretty weak in defence of himself, the public could see the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) coming to the dispatch box in the lower House yet again-I think this was the second time this was shown-apologising for having made a mistake. The shoulders were down. They could see the body language; they could see the import of what was happening in a way that a print journalist tries to convey in his or her words but cannot always do. They did not have to read about it; they could see it.

When Paul Keating came to his defence and struck a chord amongst his colleagues because finally they had someone at the table who could do a better job than their Prime Minister of defending the situation that they were in, what did we see? We saw the Paul Keating we have all read about. I am proud that I moved the motion in this place that encouraged us to televise Parliament, which occasioned the House of Representatives to follow. Had that not happened, what we would not have seen was Paul Keating leaning over the table, almost climbing over the table towards his opponent, pointing his finger as though it were a dagger, saying, `You fraud' and pausing for a moment. Of course, we would not allow that in here, this being the upper House and called that with good reason.

He did not just call his opponent a fraud. He then came back and lunged forward again and said, `You disgusting fraud'. I am pleased that Australians were able to see that. This is the man who wants to run this country. I think it is a good thing that they can make their assessment, and not just of the substantive elements of policies that can be conveyed through the radio and print media. Through the television they can see some of the body language and some of the other aspects of a personality that can be conveyed through television which cannot be conveyed through radio or the print media.

So when I say that all this change will do is allow one's mouth to move if one happens to say something sensible enough on the adjournment to get coverage, that is true. However, I do not mean by saying, `all this change will do', that it is a small change in its impact, because it is a very big change. It will allow people in their lounge rooms, in milk bars, in hotels, in any place they choose to be where there is a television set, to see in part what is happening in their Parliament, and that is a good thing.

Some people have raised with me the concept that if we allow the adjournment debate to be televised we will all be kept here until 1 o'clock in the morning because all the windbags in this place will speak ad infinitum, at length, until everybody is bored to tears, with the expectation that because they have spoken on the adjournment debate, and now it is televised, they will somehow get on television. You and I know, Mr Acting Deputy President, and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) knows, that that proposition is rubbish.

The media will not cover a lousy speech simply because it can be run on television. There are thousands of lousy speeches made here and in the other chamber that do not make it to television for a very good reason, and the same criteria will apply to coverage of the adjournment debate. I do not make a case for saying that criteria is always the best. I have seen coverage of lousy speeches on television, but what I am trying to say is that the simple fact of televising does not ensure coverage.

What some then would say is, `But you are encouraging people to come in and do something dramatic that will get them on television'. People can do something dramatic now and they will get front page coverage in the print media and a hearing on the radio. There is little to be gained by diminishing one's standing amongst one's colleagues simply to get a short grab on a television program. I would have thought there was quite a lot to be lost in terms of career prospects. I think those people who raised those arguments are reasonably short-sighted.

There is another reason why we should allow the televising of excerpts of parliamentary proceedings to include the adjournment debate. I made that point the other day in a debate about Senator Bolkus's alleged improprieties in meddling in a tender matter-namely, it seems to me that a number of us here have lost sight of the fact that the whole purpose of this building, of the staff and the parliamentarians is not simply to have an Executive to shadow Executive bash.

There are individuals here, elected as parliamentarians, who have something to say. It may not be what the leaders or the executives of their parties want them to say. Like it or not, we are all elected by the same percentage of people. Some of the people on Senator McMullan's side might look at me and ask, `How did she get elected?'. Equally, some of us over here might look at some of the people on the Government side and say, `How did they get elected?'. But the bottom line, as drawn to my attention by the Clerk of this place when I joined the Senate, Mr Alan Cumming Thom, is this: all honourable senators are elected by the same percentage. Senator Hill, Senator Button, Senator Foreman and Senator Zakharov are not elected by a greater percentage than I am. We all have equal rights to speak.

We entertain this notion. I hope that it is eventually a reality. At the moment, most of the business in this place is Government Business, for good and proper reasons. Every now and then we have General Business, which is tick-tack between the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. But there are still individual senators who might have matters they want to raise that do not fit into Government Business or General Business because they are not endorsed by their own Party or by the Democrats. Heaven knows, it has taken a bit of time to get endorsement for this motion to become General Business. Perhaps I will not say any more about that.

It is appropriate that we have the adjournment debate televised. That is where people, who should have an equal right to express their views, can have their say. Why should those who, because of the vagaries of party politics and the party machines, have not been elected to the Executive, miss out on the chance to have their say on a matter that they think is important? Why should they have a lesser coverage of their matters than the matters that are dealt with up until the end of Senate business? No reason can be offered in answer to that.

If people want to say things in a stupid, outrageous and gaudy manner, simply to attract attention to themselves, they will be judged accordingly, not only by their peers in here-because we must not forget that this is not the most important place in the world-but also by their electorates. Let us encourage their electorate to see them behaving in this manner if that is what they are going to do. I am not prepared to say that that is what I think they are going to do.

In summary, because the nature of the geography of this country is such that not all people can afford to come here at any time to see what is happening in their Parliament, it is very important that Australians around Australia have access to their Parliament, not only through the print and radio media, but through the television medium as well. I see no reason for distinguishing between that business which happens to be Government Business, or business organised through argy-bargy between the major parties, and that of an individual senator.

I think it is important to extend coverage to the adjournment debate so that the media are subject to the same competition in covering it as they are in covering the rest of Parliament. In one sense, I see not much to be lost by simply allowing someone's mouth to move, but, in another sense, I see an enormous amount to be gained in terms of what the public can assess through coverage.

Fourthly, I made the point of how important I think it is that individual parliamentarians have the right to be covered in the same way as the major parties, the Executive and shadow Executive. Lastly, I made the point that those who seek to disparage this move by saying, `You can't trust senators. They will not do the right thing. Covering this on the television will all end up in a disgraceful mess', do a grave injustice to their colleagues. In the event that they were right, which only putting this proposal to the test will tell, the right of televising an adjournment could be withdrawn. Let me conclude by urging all senators to support this motion, to put televising to the test and to give it a run.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not a matter that has been discussed in the Government party room, but my understanding from the discussions which I have had is that the overwhelming majority, if not all members of the Government Party, are either strongly opposed to this or at least not inclined to support it in this format at this time.
—Especially the Whips.
—As my colleague Senator Foreman says, especially the Whips. He is perfectly able to express that on his own behalf if he wishes. I am not so ambitious as to speak on behalf of such powerful people.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say a few things about the motion to express my own views, of course, but also, in some part, the views of colleagues because I know that there is an agreement that we will try to vote on this matter tonight. Not everybody will be able to express their views, so I will try to say some things on their behalf.

First, I want to express a concern about what this debate-not this particular motion-says about our priorities. We seem to have a great propensity to talk about ourselves all the time. I do not agree with Senator Macdonald's and Senator O'Chee's motions, but I accept that they are about issues of profound social importance. I think democracy and the operation of the Parliament are matters of importance also. But how is it that we spend so much time talking about ourselves and how we manage our business, when really we could be talking about much more important issues? I do not want to dwell on that at great length, but it seems to me that again and again we come back to a wonderful preoccupation with ourselves and with our enthusiasm for the belief that the rest of the people have to hear what we have to say.

However, on behalf of Government members I say that we at least appreciate the fact that on this occasion we have had some notice of this motion as against the ambushes that have taken place when such issues have been discussed in the past, and which have caused a little anxiety. To get to the substance of the motion, let me reiterate the principle which I put forward here on other occasions when the general question of the televising of Parliament was discussed. I have the view that the Parliament is a public forum; that it ought to be available to anybody who wishes to report, broadcast or telecast it; and that no-one should be required to broadcast, telecast or report it.

From that it is clear that I do not have fundamental in-principle opposition to what Senator Vanstone is saying, because, if someone happens to be in Canberra, he can walk in here and listen to what is said. Someone can sit up in the press gallery, on behalf of Australian Associated Press, and report the proceedings to everybody, so I am not vehemently opposed to television having that right to do that as well. The principle is that this is a public forum. If somebody wants to take photographs of it or to film it, they ought to be able to. That is the principle involved.

In the end, if there had been more time for me to talk to my colleagues, I might have been disposed to vote that way, but there are some points to the contrary which I wish to put about simply proceeding to make this small excision rather than dealing with a more comprehensive body of reforms, of which this might have been one.

It is important to remember that since 1946 when the initiatives were taken about the broadcasting of the Parliament, there have always been separate rules concerning the adjournment debate. It has always been considered to be different from the rest of the debates, not just because the Executive does not control it-I shall come back to this-but because there are a number of options for backbenchers in both the House of Representatives and the Senate to speak and be reported and, in these more modern times, to be telecast. I think that is appropriate.

There has been the view that the nature of an adjournment debate is somewhat different. In the three years that I have been here I do not think that any of the more outstanding and colourful adjournment speeches have come forward. Those of us who have been students of politics for a long time can remember people, such as the then honourable member for Hunter, Mr James, who was rather famous for colourful adjournment speeches. I am not so concerned that the telecast of them would have lowered the standard of the Parliament but his speeches did have the capacity to adversely affect some individuals. I think that a study of the nature of speeches in the adjournment debate has some significance as to why people tend to deal with it separately.

It is a different thing to be reported in the newspaper in the circumstance where one has equal opportunity to respond to a matter that is raised. In my experience, a journalist tends to give individuals a chance to respond before reporting a matter, but usually it is not so easy to have equal opportunity to appear on the television news in response to something that is a good bit of footage. We all know that inevitably-irrespective of whether it is quite proper-a bit of colourful footage is sometimes more likely to make the news than a substantial, considered response.

Senator Vanstone referred to this. She did not agree with it, otherwise she would not be moving the motion, but it is true that concern has been expressed to me by a number of honourable senators about the impact that such a change might have on the duration and the nature of the debate taking place on the adjournment. I suspect that might be what my colleague Senator Foreman was referring to when he indicated that the Whips were less than enthusiastic about this proposal.

Unfortunately, while it is true that intelligent students of the media might realise that they would be much better getting up and making a short and effective speech rather than a long and windy one, we do tend to have colleagues-of course, none of us in this chamber at present would be included in that category-who think that all of their words are golden and therefore we have to hear all of them in half hour bursts in the adjournment debate regularly. The capacity to choose the most effective 150 of them to speak for a minute and a half does not seem to be the most pressing requirement and it does not seem to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —They will not get on telly.

—Senator Vanstone might think that and I might think that, but my colleagues and I are not persuaded that those honourable senators will not think that. That is what is likely to affect their activities and their decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: It may affect not only the duration but also the nature of the speeches. A number of the speeches in the adjournment debate that are made are not designed, in a sense, for substantial media coverage. They are issues that people feel are important, but they are very much of local significance and honourable senators might consider that they do not have another forum in which to raise those issues, although there are other forums that can be used. The adjournment is one which is sometimes used. Speeches made in the adjournment debate also provide an opportunity for major policy statements by independent senators, for example, who otherwise may feel that they do not have the opportunity to get these things on the record so effectively. They make half-hour speeches that most of us might not wish to listen to. Under the Standing Orders, they have the right to make them, but I doubt whether they would make riveting television.

There are two concerns. One is about the distinction between the nature of the debate that takes place on the adjournment and the historic recognition that that has had, and the other is about the impact that such changes will have on the duration and nature of the debate. I do not want to go into that at great length because it would unduly take up the time of the Senate on a matter on which, as I said, we have agreed that we wish to get a vote tonight. If we are to look at these sorts of changes, we ought to be doing it in the context of a review about the way the whole of the adjournment debate operates in this place.

I do not agree with the House of Representatives model where there are five-minute speeches and only six per night so that the business is guaranteed to finish at 11 o'clock. I do not think that restricting the number of people who can speak is appropriate. Apart from anything else, if the sixth person gets up and gives me a bucketing, I would not want to be unable to get up and reply. In the three years that I have been here, I know that honourable senators from both sides of the chamber have come down to speak in the adjournment debate, including Senator Foreman recently, and have responded to things that other honourable senators have said during the adjournment debate, and I think that is appropriate.

I do think that the House of Representatives has been sensible in reviewing the length of the speeches which people can make in the adjournment debate. The time when people need half an hour to speak in the adjournment debate, if it ever existed, has long passed. If a package of changes included a reduction in the length of time of speeches in the adjournment debate, part of it would tend to counteract any impact for more people to speak or for people to speak more often in that debate. That is not an unreasonable proposition to consider in the circumstance where we have proliferated the opportunities for back bench senators and independent senators to make contributions on issues that are not directly related to legislation before the Parliament. For example, we have the regular matters of public interest lunchtime discussions. It was originally considered that that was a time when non-controversial matters were to be discussed. That seems to me to be somewhat honoured in the breech. That does not horrify me. It is a forum that people are entitled to use. The distinction between that and the adjournment debate escapes me a little.

Because I do not want to speak for long on this matter, I shall sum up by saying that some of my colleagues are very strongly opposed to this proposition. I want to record that view on their behalf. I am not opposed to it in principle but I am concerned that it has been considered by committees of the Parliament on several occasions. In the time I have had to look at the proposition, I have seen that there was consideration in 1974 and again in 1986. The 1986 review did suggest that this question that Senator Vanstone has raised should be considered, not then in relation to television but in relation to the adjournment as a whole.

We do seem to be getting into the position where there is one of these debates every session. We had discussions last May and last October and here we are again. I do not know whether that will be the case next October. I would prefer to see changes such as this made with a broader base of support than it looks to me is likely to occur on this occasion, as I understand the feelings of those in the chamber. If we are to make such a change I would prefer to see it done in conjunction with a package of changes, particularly as to the way in which we manage the adjournment debate itself so that we are not just having a change that will have one impact, which many people think is likely to be adverse, concerning the direction and nature of the debate without any compensating changes.

If this proposition was in a more comprehensive package of changes, we would be less concerned about it. For those reasons, although I am not opposed to this in principle, I am not disposed to vote for it at this stage. On behalf of most, if not all, Government senators I can say that to a greater or lesser extent that reflects the views of all my colleagues, many of whom are vehemently opposed to it and others who, like me, are not so vehemently opposed but are not convinced that in the absence of a broader package of measures, this is an appropriate motion to be passing at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Vanstone articulately and entertainingly summarised some of the main arguments in favour of the motion. I am of the view that all parliamentary proceedings should be televised live, and so I ask myself: under the present rules which apply, what is different about adjournment debates that we have every night and the rest of the day's debates?
—They are even more tedious and repetitious.

—Well, probably one distinguishing feature, to use Senator Vanstone's words, is that Senator Kemp's mouth moves every night. But apart from that, look at the other avenues we have. We have Question Time, which I find to be very rehearsed, very strictly controlled, with rigid formulas, too many dorothy dixers and too many vexatious points of order. Then we can look at the House of Representatives grievance debates on Thursdays and the matters of public interest debates in the Senate which are televised and can be used at the moment. One has to ask oneself how it can be logical to deny us the opportunity to televise the adjournment debates which can be very useful and can be used constructively. I can cite the way in which Senator McLean, having tried other avenues of parliamentary procedure, used the adjournment debate to bring the important matter of Westpac malpractice before the Parliament and, in that way, before the public.

SPEECH.PARA: But it is not just a matter of self-interest; I think it is a matter of public interest. It is in the public interest that politicians and parliamentary processes be exposed, warts and all, in graphic, visual form. I acknowledge that there was certainly a novelty effect when Question Time was first televised. It was very obvious that people had bought new suits, they were very conscious of their hairstyles and their colour combinations, and they were getting all sorts of advice on what coloured clothing clashed with the leather behind them. But, I think that novelty has worn off. In the same way, I think the novelty of keeping the Senate here until 1 a.m., 2 a.m. or 3 a.m. would soon wear off as well. That happens now. I do not think the televising of debate would cause an extension of that beyond the bounds of normal human endurance, and I am sure that we would all make a point to that effect if it were to go too far.

I think I am right in saying that there really is not, as Senator McMullan said, a different view on the treatment of adjournment debates-that there has always been the legal right for the print medium and radio to cover adjournment debates, and that the main reason Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio does not cover them at the moment is the nightmare of irregular finishing times faced by programmers.

Senator McMullan expressed some words of caution, which I did note and which I think we all should note. But I think his reliance on the fact that one has a right of response in the print media is pretty thin. It really does not happen for the majority of us.

I have just touched on his argument about the duration of the debate. I am attracted to his promise of a review of the whole adjournment process but I do not think it is about to happen in the short term. I suspect that we will be waiting a long time. I would like to ask him to review Question Time while he is doing it. In the meantime, we have this illogical constraint upon us. I guess I am summing up the Australian Democrats view that all parliamentary proceedings should be televised live and, therefore, we support Senator Vanstone's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating a motion which seeks to amend a motion which was passed just on a year ago and which was amended in October last year. It makes me wonder why it has become necessary to seek to change the practice of televising Parliament when we have had so very little experience in this area. What is the hurry? I know of no clamour from people in the electorate who feel that they need to be able to watch the adjournment debate or excerpts from it. Like Senator McMullan, I can see the possible advantages and disadvantages that may arise from televised broadcasting of the adjournment debate but I do not think we need to make such a drastic and possibly costly change to procedures so early in our experience of parliamentary telecasts.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps if Australia adopts cable television-and that is another argument-we may find, as has been found in the United States of America, a greater demand for such services. But I doubt it. I believe that it would have been more helpful if Senator Vanstone had perhaps referred the matter back to the Standing Committee on Procedure for reconsideration, rather than use the time of the Senate on what Senator Powell referred to in an earlier debate as `not the most gripping issue ever raised in the Senate'. She was talking about the much wider debate on the principle of televising Parliament, not just televising the adjournment debate.

It was Senator Vanstone who, to her credit I might say, moved the original motion to televise proceedings, including the condition that she now seeks to remove-that is, the exemption of the adjournment debate. In my view, her most compelling argument then was the argument on the right of the public to have access to the proceedings of Parliament, to see it as well as to hear it. But, to my mind, the right of access does not necessarily extend to the adjournment debate.

In support of that point, I would like to refer briefly to the history of parliamentary broadcasts in this country. We were one of the first countries, at least in the English speaking world, to take that up. The first broadcast of the Federal Parliament took place in July 1946 after a recommendation was tabled a few days earlier by the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings. The first mention of disagreement on the broadcasting of the adjournment occurred during debate on the report. I quote from the Hansard of 5 July 1946, when the late Mr Harold Holt, who had been a member of the Committee, had this to say:
I agree with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Menzies) that the exclusion of debates on the motion for the Adjournment of the House is undesirable-

Mr Menzies had earlier referred to occasions, which we do not see any more, where the Prime Minister or the Minister on duty would actually adjourn the House early in order to allow for a particularly important adjournment debate. Those days have gone forever, I think. The quote continues:

but as many of the speeches made on that motion relate to one electorate only, and as the debates come on at a very late hour, it was thought that, at the beginning, at any rate, they should be excluded. It was also thought desirable that the listening public and the broadcasting authorities should know approximately when the broadcasting for the day would finish.

That is the point mentioned by Senator Kernot. That same Committee reported again a few days later, on 16 July, specifically on the matter that we are considering tonight. On that occasion, the Committee Chairman, who was the Speaker of the House of Representatives, had this to say:

Paragraph 2 of the First Report made it mandatory for the broadcast to continue until the adjournment is moved by a Minister. The committee examined the times at which the adjournment had been moved over a recent period of 12 months, and found that 47 per cent of the motions had been made before 10.30 p.m., 41 per cent between 10.30 p.m. and 11.30 p.m., and 12 per cent after 11.30 p.m. The committee also ascertained that the cost of extending the broadcast past 11.30 p.m., the time at which the second national stations normally close down-
which, of course, was a factor then, too-
would be approximately #50 an hour.
The sum of #50 an hour in 1946 was very big money. Further, he said:

It was considered that, even though the number of occasions on which the adjournment is moved later than 11.30 p.m. is likely to be relatively small, the continuation of the broadcast to a late hour cannot, as a general practice, be justified.

That is still the position today. When Senator Vanstone moved the original motion a year ago she referred to the question of cost when she cited the investment that Parliament has made in installing the sound and vision system in the House and implied that, as the capital cost had already been met, the cost of televising would be minimal. One matter that needs to be looked at before extending the times would be the additional labour costs involved and the consideration of whether any benefit gained justified that additional cost. It may be that such calculations have been made-I do not know. However, they would have to be part of any consideration of this proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been made and there is not any additional cost.
—I would be interested to see that.
—It is because the staff has to be here to relay it to your room in any event.

—Certainly those staff do, yes. The question of rising costs brings me to the issue over which I have grave doubts; that is, the possible effect of televising on the length and nature of the adjournment debate. Certainly that debate, as has been mentioned already, gives us the opportunity to raise matters that we cannot easily raise during the proceedings set down on the Notice Paper. There are also restrictions on what can be raised during the adjournment debate under Standing Orders. Much of what is raised is really parish-pump stuff, even in this chamber, aimed at a particular part of an honourable senator's constituency-whether that constituency be his or her State or Territory, part of that State or Territory, or a particular group in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: I can see the possibility of an exponential increase in the time taken in the adjournment debate, particularly as we allow a generous time for speakers on the adjournment. Instead of having to wait around until 11.30 or midnight-it is not only the Whips who have to wait around-we may find ourselves here more regularly into the early hours of the morning. Perhaps a condition of agreeing to broadcast the adjournment debate might be to shorten the time limit for speeches.

TALK.START.PARA: —Limit the whole debate.

—Yes. I note, too, that honourable senators seem to prefer the adjournment debate to the Thursday lunchtime discussion of matters of public interest, which often, as happened today, is underutilised. The adjournment debate is also the most likely occasion for controversial material to be raised. The thought of being on television might well encourage some of the would-be stars among us to further sensationalise. Thus the broadcast of the debate may provide a greatly increased workload for the Standing Committee of Privileges, as well as causing even longer debates, to which we are subjected already sometimes, either the same evening or the following evening when a claim made leads to a counterclaim or a defence-sometimes ad infinitum.

SPEECH.PARA: This assumes that the electronic media will be interested in the debate. If they are not, what is the point of the whole exercise? I think a bit more thought and study needs to go into the motion before we vote on it. I think it is unfortunate that we are voting on it tonight. I would prefer a proposal to come from the Procedure Committee rather than have a motion from a senator who, to me, does not seem to have thought it through-there are arguments both for and against the motion we have before us tonight-or perhaps a modified version of the motion. I believe that the motion requires and deserves further consideration before a decision is made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not listed to speak in this debate. I want to say briefly that I support Senator Vanstone's motion. I cannot see why anything that is said here should not be available to be seen by anyone. It is a bit of an elitist suggestion to think that the people of Canberra, if they are that way inclined, can come along and listen but that people in the remote areas of the country cannot listen to the proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: An interesting matter was raised in a committee meeting which I attended recently. Mr Hill from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) indicated, much to my surprise and the surprise of most members of the committee, that people meters show that the number of people watching Parliament Question Time varies from between 0 per cent, 1 per cent and 2 per cent. While that seems to be a very small number, if we calculate that out across the number of people in Australia, it is quite a large number. It is interesting, as Mr Hill pointed out, that the Australian-which is an quality newspaper read by people who are very interested in what happens in our society-is read by about 150,000 people. The ABC estimates that 150,000 people watch Parliament Question Time and that many of those 150,000 people prefer to watch the late night version, which comes on at about midnight, rather than the afternoon version. I support the Opposition's motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) notes that the then Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) said, at the time of World Heritage listing of the north Queensland tropical rainforest, that no one would suffer as a direct result of World Heritage listing;

(b) notes further that in the Courier Mail of 4 May 1991, notice was given of a total clearance auction of all sawmill equipment, mobile plant, motor vehicles, office furniture, computers, etcetera, at the APS sawmill in Ravenshoe;
(c) expresses concern that after an outlay of $7.6 million of taxpayers money the Federal Government has completely failed:
(i) to ensure the continued operation of the Ravenshoe Mill, and
(ii) to achieve any single benefit or assistance for the town of Ravenshoe to compensate for the suffering caused as a direct result of the World Heritage listing; and
(d) is of the opinion that an inquiry should be instituted into, inter alia:
(i) The economic and social impact of World Heritage Listing on the Queensland Wet Tropics Region,
(ii) all matters involving and incidental to the giving of grants and loans to the operators of the APS mill at Ravenshoe and to the expenditure of the same,
(iii) the Government's management, audit, reporting and supervision of the expenditure of $7.6 million given and loaned to the owners of the APS mill at Ravenshoe,
(iv) the closure of the main employment source at Ravenshoe and the resulting social and economic effect on the town of Ravenshoe,
(v) the prospect of new Government funded projects which will provide employment for those displaced from the Ravenshoe Mill,

(vi) further Commonwealth Government assistance to alleviate the social, business and economic problems in the town of Ravenshoe resulting from World Heritage listing of the rainforests, including the results flowing from the closure of the mill.

The motion seeks to do something about the catastrophe that has befallen the town of Ravenshoe, to correct that catastrophe and to give some hope to the people who live in that community. My colleague Senator O'Chee was to move a motion also dealing with Ravenshoe which is complementary to my motion.

It is quite obvious, having regard to the time, that there will not be the debate on this particular motion that I hoped there might be. We had agreed, by arrangement with the Australian Democrats, that we would restrict our speeches to a certain time to give the maximum number of people the opportunity to speak. As we are starting the debate 10 minutes before the adjournment, it is quite obvious that there will be no opportunity for anyone to speak at length on it. There will not even be time for me to finish the restricted speech that I had planned to give on this matter, which I consider to be very important, as do the people of Queensland, particularly the people of north Queensland and the Atherton Tablelands.

The motion that I have moved asks the Senate to do four things. First, it calls upon the Senate to note that the previous Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, now the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, said at the time the World Heritage listing of the north Queensland rainforest was being introduced that no person would suffer as a direct result of the World Heritage listing.

It is important that promises made by Ministers of the Government, in implementing government programs, should be adhered to. It is a sad indictment of our political system in Australia that people have little confidence in the commitments and undertakings that politicians give because they are often broken. The comment of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that no child would live in poverty by the 1990 is a particular example of why people do not trust politicians any more. Senator Richardson's comment that no-one would suffer as a result of World Heritage listing is a very sour joke at the present time to the people of far north Queensland.

To walk down the streets of Ravenshoe and other towns in the area and suggest to those people that none of them has suffered as a result of World Heritage listing will bring a very angry and even aggressive response. As businesses close down and families lose not only their life savings but also their houses, cars and dignity, as unemployment queues continue to increase, as the people of Ravenshoe refer to themselves more and more as a social service community, as youth crime continues to increase, no person in Ravenshoe can accept that he has not suffered as a result of World Heritage listing.

It may be unfair to blame all of the woes of the town on the World Heritage listing of the rainforest, but it is certainly a major cause. The people of Ravenshoe, in their current plight, believe that their situation is a direct result of World Heritage listing. It is not the case that anyone in Australia believes that we should not prefer our rainforests in far north Queensland and elsewhere, but the people of Ravenshoe believe that they have been unfairly treated in that their way of life, their employment, the sort of community they have known for many years, have all disappeared as a result of a Government decision. It is therefore important that the Senate should note particularly Senator Richardson's comment that no-one would be adversely affected by World Heritage listing and that that promise has not been adhered to and that Senator Richardson has not been able to deliver to the people of that community the commitment he gave at that time.

Secondly, the motion that I have moved tonight calls upon the Senate to note that an advertisement has appeared in a Queensland newspaper advertising a total clearance at auction of all sawmill equipment from the sawmill at Ravenshoe. That in itself is not an earth-shattering piece of news or happening, but it is the final death knell for the long saga that has been the Ravenshoe downward spiral since World Heritage time. I give credit where credit is due: the Government did in one way attempt to preserve the timber mill as an employment source in Ravenshoe but, in spite of this and all the other attempts, an offer made by a consortium backed by the Government to purchase that mill from the Westpac Bank, the mortgagee in possession, has been rejected. The Westpac Bank, through its receivers, has now indicated that it is no longer interested in selling the Ravenshoe Mill as a going concern and that it will be sold piecemeal. That means that the mill will never operate again and that the only regular and permanent source of employment in that community will be lost forever.

Thirdly, the motion asks that the Senate express its concern at the fact that, for an outlay of some $7.6m of taxpayers' money-your money and mine, Mr Deputy President, and the money of every other taxpayer in this community-that the Government has poured into Ravenshoe, not one iota, not one single benefit, has resulted. That is not a very good investment in anyone's language. It needs to be noted by the Senate with concern that the Government has spent $7.6m of taxpayers' money and has not achieved a single benefit for the town of Ravenshoe. The Government has failed to ensure the continued operation of the Ravenshoe Mill, which it was given $7.6m to do, and it has failed in any other way to achieve any single benefit. I think that needs to be brought home to the Senate, and the Senate should acknowledge that by expressing concern that that amount of money can be spent without any benefit at all.

Fourthly, the motion calls upon the Senate to express an opinion-only an opinion at this stage-that an inquiry should be instituted into a number of issues. I make the point for Senator Coulter's benefit that this is not a motion to refer the matter to a Senate committee but simply calls on the Senate to express an opinion that an inquiry should be held to look into a certain number of issues which are listed in the motion. One of them is the economic and social impact of World Heritage listing of the Queensland wet tropics region, a matter on which I intended to elaborate more fully, but time will prevent me from doing so. The motion also seeks to have the inquiry consider all matters involving and incidental to the giving of grants and loans to the operators of the APS mill at Ravenshoe and to the expenditure by the operators of the mill. It also seeks an inquiry into the Government's management-or should I say mismanagement-audit, reporting and supervision of the expenditure of that $7.6m of taxpayers' money.

I have spoken privately to Senator Coulter, who has some concern about this matter. I am sure that the Government, if it were to respond to this, would say that there has been a police inquiry instituted already and that the Director of Public Prosecutions is looking into the matter. Although the Government indicated as long ago as 16 October that this matter would be referred to the Attorney-General for investigation into what happened to this $7.6m of taxpayers' money, and that legal proceedings would be instituted if appropriate, nothing of any substance has been reported back to this chamber since that time. It is not for the want of inquiring.

I have a long list here, which because of a shortage of time I shall not read as I had intended to, of occasions since 16 October, when this matter was raised in this Parliament by me and my colleagues, particularly honourable senators from Queensland, on which inquiries have been made as to what has happened with the so-called investigation by the Australian Federal Police and the Director of Public Prosecutions into what became of the $7.6m of taxpayers' money that the Government is suggesting has gone astray. I am really tired of waiting for the Government to do something. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, and her office keep telling me that something is about to happen, that we are going to be told something, that a report is about to come out and that the investigation is almost complete. I have been told that for many weeks and even months now.

Would you believe, Mr Deputy President, that the one person who could contribute the most to this investigation-the accountant at the mill through whom all the money should have gone and through whom all the expenditure should have gone-who would be quite crucial to any investigation, has not, even as late as yesterday, been interviewed by the Australian Federal Police, the Director of Public Prosecutions, the Australian Securities Commission or anyone else? That suggests to me that the investigation that we are being told about is not a very good one at all, and that is the most polite way I can put it.

My colleague Senator O'Chee gave a notice of motion in which the accountant's name is mentioned, and it is indicated there, as long ago as 11 April, that he had not been consulted. I had mentioned that in a speech in the Senate prior to that time. Even since then and since drawing the attention of the Senate to the fact that the most crucial witness had still not been approached, nothing has happened. It makes me think that the Government's suggestion that a proper, sensible and responsible inquiry is being held is not truthful and is not something that we can rely on any more. That is why I want the Senate to make its own inquiry into that particular matter and into other matters relating to the mismanagement, the fiasco, that the name `Ravenshoe' has now become synonymous with.

My time having almost expired, let me say briefly that the inquiry that I am asking the Senate to express its support for should look at some positive features of what we may be able to do to alleviate and overcome the distress that has been caused to the people of Ravenshoe. I ask that the Senate express an opinion that the inquiry should, as well as the other matters I have referred to, look at the prospect of newly-funded government projects and at whether further government assistance could be given to alleviate the quite substantial social, business and economic problems which have confronted the town of Ravenshoe since World Heritage listing.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I want to refer to a matter of personal explanation that was made in the House of Representatives earlier today by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Bruce Lloyd. It is important to bring this matter to the attention the Senate. Earlier this week with regard to various questions and answers that were presented to Senate Estimates Committee D, a listing appeared for overtime payments for staff of members of parliament for the year 1 July 1989 to 30 June 1990 with a figure against Mr Lloyd's name of $84,795.64. That alerted Mr Lloyd to the matter. He knew it was obviously wrong because it did not accord with his records. He subsequently checked the matter with the Department of Administrative Services and was advised by a senior officer of that Department, Mr Paul O'Neill, that the figure was in fact wrong and that the correct figure was $38,424.46-a very dramatic reduction on the original figure which appeared against Mr Lloyd's name and very much in line with the expenditure that is normal for the type of office held by Mr Lloyd as the Deputy Leader of a parliamentary party. It is important that the Senate should note that quite serious affront and error which was on that occasion afforded to Mr Lloyd.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the same information, I would also like to refer to figures that appear against the Northern Territory electorate with which, of course, I am very personally involved and in which I have some considerable degree of interest. With regard to the overtime expenditure for the year ended June 1990, it is very interesting to note that the figure was $11,535 for Senator Collins; $54,021 for the House of Representatives member, Mr Snowdon; and $13,590 for myself, also as a senator for the Northern Territory.

For the subsequent nine-month period of overtime expenditure to the end of March 1991, the appropriate figure shown for Senator Collins was $3,304.12. Of course, that takes into account the fact that during that period Senator Collins became a Minister and naturally his staff electorate figures changed. In the same period, for the member in the House of Representatives, Mr Snowdon, the figure was some $47,903.86 and for myself the figure was $12,779.38.

The comparative figures for electorate telephone costs in the Northern Territory for the same periods-that is the financial year ending June 1990 and the nine months to the end of March 1991-show that Senator Collins incurred costs of $14,034 and $10,924 respectively. For myself the respective figures were $16,973 and $16,113 and for Mr Snowdon, the figures were $40,491 and $43,762, showing him to be the highest spending member or senator in the Federal Parliament over those two periods. It is important to note that whilst Mr Snowdon enjoys a second electorate office and the provision of an additional member of staff, the increases are out of all proportion to the average figures reflected for these types of expenditure.

These figures must also pose a number of serious questions. For example, with regard to the overtime expenditure I would point out that for the periods in question the President of the Northern Territory Labor Party, Ms Margaret Gillespie, was a member of Mr Snowdon's staff. Therefore, he should be asked to account in full for the figures that were applied there. Given the fact that, in relation to electorate telephone costs, Mr Snowdon is also listed as the highest spending member or senator in this Parliament, he should also be asked what proportion of the expenditure of well over $83,000 shown against his name in that period was for undertaking telephone polling. In fact, it is known that this is an activity that occurred from Mr Snowdon's office during that period. These are serious questions. I think the figures quite properly reflect that Senator Collins and myself are well within the appropriate average operating expenditures, but those shown against Mr Snowdon's name are out of all proportion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise briefly tonight some matters in relation to the Family Court in Adelaide. I notified the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate, that I was going to raise these matters. He understands that and will look at the Hansard. I simply say that to make it clear that he has not left this place ignorant of the fact that these matters were to be raised. I think he understands how important these matters are.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the finer detail of this matter will be raised in the debate on the appropriations under Estimates Committee E, but there are certain matters that should be raised immediately which are perhaps not appropriate for the Estimates Committee report debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am looking forward to it!

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President; I will remind you of that at the time, should you be in the chair. As I understand it from Estimates Committee E last week, Melbourne is still scheduled to get a new Family Court before Adelaide does. It is not just a new Family Court, it is actually a new Federal courts complex which will house the Federal Court of Australia, the Family Court of Australia and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: Melbourne is now scheduled, although I do not think this was so originally, to get its Federal courts complex ahead of Adelaide. This was the case when I inquired in the Estimates in 1990 and it is still the case now; nothing has changed. This is despite the fact that it was made clear after the Estimates of 1990 and has been clear ever since that there are serious security problems with the Family Court premises in Adelaide. This is generated primarily by the fact that the court is situated on a number of floors of a public building. It is not a dedicated courts building and, as I understand it, there is some difficulty in sealing off the lifts, the stairwells and the fire stairs, et cetera. It is just impossible to seal this area off and make it a courts complex with access only through certain limited points. That has created certain serious problems that have been detailed here before.

Senator Tate indicated in November 1990, when this matter was raised in the Appropriation debate, that the security problems in Adelaide were serious. It is obviously serious if judges lives are at risk-not that their lives are any more valuable than anyone else's. Nonetheless, it is a serious matter; just as it is a serious matter that lawyers, litigants and court staff may have their lives put at risk. Anyway, the Minister indicated that the security problems with the Family Court in Adelaide would be looked at and, to the extent that they could be, they would be attended to immediately. Also, these problems would be taken into account in any reassessment of whether Melbourne or Adelaide should get a new Federal courts building first.

Either the reassessment has not yet taken place because the situation has not changed and Melbourne is still going to get its Federal courts building before Adelaide does-the serious security problems which have been made clear to the Government in relation to the Adelaide Family Court should have occasioned a reassessment-or the reassessment has taken place and the Government has decided that the security problems in Adelaide are not serious enough to raise the priority of Adelaide over Melbourne. In any event, the Government is responsible for leaving the Adelaide court, its judges, lawyers, court staff and litigants at risk by not immediately beginning construction of a planned new Federal courts building in Adelaide.

A site has been picked out in King William Street and it sits vacant. I suppose that some people are happy about that because it has been nicely grassed and the shrubs that were put there on a temporary basis are now beginning to look pretty close to a rainforest, they have been there that long. Nothing has been happening on this vacant site. The plans have been drawn, the professions have been consulted about the adequacy of the plans and the appropriate placement of various resources for the Family Court within those plans, and now the building must be built.

One of the offered excuses for Melbourne's dedicated Federal Court building proceeding first is workload. This is a load of rubbish. Any idiot knows that Victoria by virtue of its population will have more Family Court matters to deal with than South Australia. What the Department does not say in its answer to the Estimates Committee about workload is that Melbourne has more courts and more judges. The simple fact that it has more cases in itself does not warrant Melbourne having a building that will be put up ahead of that in Adelaide.

Last week I was told by the Attorney-General's Department that there is another factor to take into account in considering which State should have its building put up first. Obviously there is not capital expenditure to spread around as some form of largess. Some priority has to be set. I was told that there is need for the Commonwealth to make a `major symbolic statement about its judicial presence' by putting up a building in one place or another. I think that is absolute baloney. What kind of statement will it make about the Commonwealth's judicial presence if a judge, lawyer, litigant or staff member in the Adelaide Registry is killed or seriously injured? I think that not putting up the building in Adelaide immediately continues to leave these lives at risk, and it is a risk that the Government should not be taking. It is certainly not a symbolic statement that the Government would want to have made. When finally some blood is spilt, the question will be asked: on whose hands does it fall? It will not fall on those people who consistently-and there are many in this category-have drawn this matter to the Government's attention. The Government may like to reflect on that.

The reason that I am raising this matter tonight rather than next week is that next Monday a somewhat regrettable exercise will take place. Four of Adelaide's five Family Court judges will be trotting down from their chambers-well, they will probably go in Commonwealth cars-to the District Court in Adelaide where they will be giving evidence as to death threats or threats made against their lives-I presume that can be paraphrased as death threats-two years ago by a litigant in the Family Court. It is best not to go into the details of the person's name and the rest of it, but charges have been laid against a particular person that relate to death threats having been made against these four judges. They will be going down to another court to give evidence about this. It will be bad luck if anyone is expecting a hearing in the Family Court in Adelaide on Monday, as only one judge will be sitting for a good part of the day.

The defendant in this matter, without naming him, who allegedly made these threats-and that is what the hearing is about, whether threats were made-has a known history and experience of bomb disposal, apparently gained in Vietnam. That should highlight the seriousness of this matter. That is not to say that Adelaide court judges are the only ones who have threats made against them, but it highlights that all Family Court judges do have such threats. Therefore, when the Government, the Minister and everyone admit that security in the Adelaide court is inadequate, one should seek to highlight how ludicrous it is to be talking about making major symbolic statements about the Commonwealth's judicial presence in Melbourne, when the symbolic statement it and we as taxpayers should be making is that our judges, litigants and court staff will be safe in their courts.

A recent Adelaide Advertiser article of 27 April detailing the launch of a book on domestic violence entitled In Whose Interest? indicated that women using the Adelaide court feel harassed and insecure in those premises. This is not to say that we should accord women any more special treatment than we do men, but it is to say that by virtue of the fact that the court, as I understand it, does not deal with homosexual marriages, half of the people there feel insecure and at risk. That is a disgrace. They want to access their rights given to them by this Parliament, but they feel at risk. Why? Because security in the Adelaide court is inadequate.

Informed sources tell me that the Adelaide judges are very worried about this matter. I do not know, but perhaps the Adelaide judges are a bit like some of the South Australian parliamentarians. We sometimes feel that we get outvoted by the large numbers in the eastern States. Sometimes we feel that there are too many people from the eastern States and we are pleased to have the Senate where we have an equal voice with those States. Perhaps the Family Court judges in Adelaide need the equivalent of a Senate to make their voices heard in the internal politics of Family Court matters about the risk-not the risk that they personally run but, as I have stressed, the risk run by litigants, court staff and lawyers. I further understand from informed sources that the Attorney-General knows these facts well. Now the Minister should inform us what he will do about the position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take up the Senate's time for too long, but I cannot let this opportunity pass without mentioning that today is the ninth day of May. We have just had a celebration in the Members Hall marking the third year of sitting in this Parliament. We celebrated 90 years of a democratic Federal government, and also the anniversary of the first sitting in Canberra of the Parliament in the old Parliament House in 1927. It greatly grieves me, as I go on my exercise trips out of this place down into the old rose garden, to go past old Parliament House and see a great community asset lying there idle, no doubt deteriorating and not in use. I think of a generation of children who were nine years old when we left there and who are now 12 but who, when anything is finally done, will be 15 or 16. That is a whole generation of youth who will not have the opportunity of going into the old building.

SPEECH.PARA: I see old Parliament House as a place which, with vision, could be used as a museum, with an education centre. It could also contain a dining room, and people could visit that building and have the joy and thrill of sitting where Menzies sat, or maybe others may be thrilled to sit where Whitlam sat. I see that kind of experience as having a commercial value. People could pay to go there and the building could contain some commercial enterprises selling souvenirs and so on. I think that in this place we have almost reached the figure of two million visitors. Many of those people in addition to visiting this building would have made a pilgrimage to old Parliament House.

I commend the work carried out by the guides during our three years in this place. As a person who uses the guide services extensively for visiting groups and school groups, I know what those guides have done to increase people's knowledge of Parliament. I know that they explain that although there may be only two or three members present in this chamber, many of us are working in our rooms. The guides have helped to enlighten people on their visits. Only recently I met somebody who brought their children here for four hours, and that family came back the next day because the boys wanted to return because there was so much to do.

Much of the credit is due to the Parliamentary Education Office and to the Parliament itself in the provision of services around the House. I am sure that some members have been to the area where the Apple Macintoshes are contained and have fiddled with the mice or mouses or whatever is the plural; I suppose that the word is `mice'. Many people put in their postcode to find out their local member. Many visitors view the film People in Parliament-and I do not mention this because Bob Collins and I are the two Senate stars-which is repeated over and over again. Although people show great interest in this place, old Parliament House lies idle.

The other day President Sibraa said to me in the corridors of this place-I suppose I should not mention conversations in corridors-how exciting it could be if some of the new modern technology could be used to put three-dimensional images to the speeches that we have on tape, as well as some of the new techniques that can be used to create visual images and messages.

I can imagine son et lumiere, or light and sound, performances in the evening where people could enjoy the beauty of the old Parliament House and the rose garden. There is the potential for all sorts of additions to the Parliamentary Triangle. What has happened? This Government has delayed taking action. This cannot be because it has not had notice. It is more than 10 years since we knew that that area was going to be empty and now it is sitting idle.

In answer to a question I asked yesterday, Minister Bolkus said that there were plans in next year's Budget. I am putting the Minister on notice. I will be watching very carefully, as will a number of people in the community who are very concerned about this, to ensure that the Budget contains provision for restoring the old Parliament House to a point where it can be visited by the public. If it does not, I will be on my feet again because the old Parliament House is a great attribute and a great educational facility. If we are to have a democracy in another 90 years, we need to strike a blow every day to encourage our young people to understand the history of our parliamentary democracy and to be proud of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not often in an adjournment debate that somebody gets up and supports another speaker. I do not even know whether under the Standing Orders it is the sort of thing one can do. I would like to commend Senator Patterson for what she has just said about the old Parliament House. I will not repeat all the things she has said.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year I was in America representing this Parliament at the United Nations. I found that the Americans are trying to hang on very closely to some of their history. The history of America is not that much older than the history of Australia but at least the Americans are cherishing and preserving many of the good aspects of their past. Countries progress from remembering their past to preparing for their future.

I commend Senator Patterson for bringing up the issue of the old Parliament House. I am saddened every time I go past the building. I presume that we tend to remember the places to which we first go. I suppose that it is a bit like Brideshead Revisited-the first things that one does in life are always the things that are most memorable.

The old Parliament House has a lot of history and wonderful things in it. It was only a provisional Parliament House but a lot of history was created in it. I support what Senator Patterson said tonight.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.53 p.m.
