QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 21 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the quantitative basis for the Minister's claim that 300,000 pensioners will be affected by the Government's deeming provisions.
(2) What is the quantitative basis for the claim in the February 1991 edition of Age Pension News that about 15 per cent of pensioners will be affected by the Government's deeming provisions.
(3) What criteria were used in deciding which pensioners would be sent the Investment Review Form in the week beginning 14 January 1991.

(4) Have any other pensioners been sent an Investment Review Form subsequent to the mid-January mail-out; if so, how many additional pensioners have been sent this form and what criteria were used in deciding that they would be included in any additional mail-out.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The estimate that around 300,000 Social Security pensioners would be and affected by the deeming rules was based on the number of pensioners whose departmental records indicated they were likely to be affected by deeming. In `Age Pension News' of February 1991 it was stated `only about 15% of pensioners' would be affected by deeming. The estimate of 300,000 pensioners affected represents around 14.3% of the 2.1 million Social Security pensioners.
Preliminary estimates of the number of pensioners actually affected by the deeming provisions are:
(i) 140,000 pensioners had a pension reduction on the 28 March 1991 pension pay day because of the deeming provisions (ie the rate of return on assessable cash and accounts was below 10%);

(ii) in addition, in the order of 200,000 pensioners reinvested their savings in cash and accounts in the period 22 August 1990 to 15 March 1991 to earn a higher rate of interest that affected their pension under the normal pension income test.

These figures do not include pensioners not yet affected by deeming, either because they had not returned the Investment Review Form before 28 March, or returned it too late for it to be processed before 28 March. They also make no allowance for the effect of deeming on new entrants to the pension after 28 March.
(3) The criteria used in selecting the pensioners to be sent an Investment Review Form were as follows:
Reduced pension categories
(i) Total of account balances over $2,000 (single) or $4,000 (married combined), and interest rate less than 10%.
(ii) No account balance on pension record but account interest recorded as greater than $200 (single) or $400 (married combined).
Maximum pension categories
(i) Total income (less account interest) plus 10% of account balance exceeds applicable income free area.
(ii) No account balance on pension record but account interest recorded as greater than $200 (single) or $400 (married combined), and total income is within $10 per week of applicable free area.

These criteria were constructed to allow Investment Review Forms to be targeted to clients most likely to be affected. Others likely to be affected in the following categories will be reviewed through other processes:
* pensioners with warrantees/nominees;
* pensioners paid by group payment; and
* overseas pensioners.

The first two categories are to be reviewed by separate processes because it was considered that these clients could have difficulties in understanding the deeming rules and completing the Investment Review Form. Overseas pensioners will be reviewed as part of the regular pensioner entitlement review cycle.
(4) Some 55,000 pensioners who meet the criteria set down in (3) were issued with an Investment Review Form subsequent to the mid-January mail-out.

The form that these pensioners have received was marked as a `reminder', but it was the first form they received. This resulted from an error in the computer program for the selection of pensioners who received the initial form. The program for the initial selection inadvertently omitted most pensioners with managed investments who should have received the initial form according to the selection criteria in (3).

This error was corrected when the computer program for the issue of the reminder forms was run. This resulted in the group with managed investments who did not receive the initial form receiving a reminder form. This was not evident, however, until after reminder forms had been dispatched to pensioners. Consequently, there was no opportunity to correct the situation.
Staff have apologised to pensioners making enquiries about this issue.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 21 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to valuations and property reviews carried out by the Australian Valuation Office (AVO) for the Department of Employment, Education and Training under Regulation 20 of the Student Assistance Regulations:

(1) How many valuers are employed by the AVO to assess properties for assets test purposes for the Department of Employment, Education and Training under Regulation 20 of the Student Assistance Regulations.
(2) How many valuations did the AVO carry out for the above purpose: (a) in 1989-90; and (b) from 1 July 1990 to 31 December 1990.
(3) For each state, how many of these valuations were carried out in areas outside the capital cities and other urban centres.
(4) How many of these valuations resulted in a valuation higher than the earlier valuation provided by the AUSTUDY recipient or his or her family.
(5) What guidelines, criteria or directions, both legislative and administrative, are used by the AVO when undertaking valuations for this purpose.

(6) Has the Minister or the Minister for Employment, Education and Training issued any guidelines, requests, Criteria or directives to the AVO in relation to valuations carried out for this purpose; if so, what are they.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The AVO provides valuation advice to the majority of Commonwealth Government Departments, a number of Government Business Enterprises and some State Governments.
No valuers are employed specifically to carry out valuations for Austudy purposes as the work represents just part of the Government's annual valuations program.
(2) In 1989/90 AVO received 376 requests for valuation advice from DEET. In the period 1 July 1990 to 31 December 1990 a total of 364 requests were received.
In some cases the requests sought more than one valuation. For example:
* the market value of the property as at
* the market value of the property as at
* the value of stock (market value)
* the value of plant (market value)
i.e. each valuation request may ask AVO to provide up to four valuations.
In 1989/90 a total of 656 valuations were carried out at DEET's request for Austudy purposes. In the period 1 July 1990 to 31 December 1990 a total of 711 valuations were determined.
(3) The number of valuation requests received by AVO from DEET in 1989/90 in the localities specified is as follows:

(4) In many cases the claimant does not submit an estimate of value when completing an application for Austudy. The information sought, therefore, cannot be provided.
(5) Subject to the answer in (6) below, no legislative or administrative guidelines are used by AVO when undertaking valuations for this purpose.

(6) The Department of Employment, Education and Training contracts the services of the AVO to value the assets of certain AUSTUDY clients as provided for under Regulation 20 of the AUSTUDY Regulations.

The Department uses a Review of Assets form for AUSTUDY recipients, their parents and spouses to declare their assets and liabilities. The information provided on the form is made available to the AVO. The form provides for the applicant to authorise the AVO to inspect and value the family's properties, and specifies the date for which the valuations are to be determined.

The AUSTUDY Regulations require that the full net market value of a person's assets be taken into account. The net value is defined as being the full market value of the assets described in Regulation 14, less the value of the items described in Regulations 15 to 18 (eg principal home, debt on assets).

The AVO's valuation reflects the full market value of the assets described in Regulation 14. All further calculations to determine the net market value, and to determine whether a ``farm or business'' discount applies, are the responsibility of DEET, not of the AVO.
Neither the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, nor the Department on his behalf, has issued any directions to the AVO in respect of the professional determination of valuations.
